PETITION.PARA: To the honourable, the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of Western Australia respectfully call on the Minister for Foreign Affairs to recall Australia's Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See, (Mr Brian Burke) and suspend his appointment while matters of propriety relating to his actions as Premier and subsequently which have been referred to the Minister are investigated, and moreover during the term of the Royal Commission into W.A. Inc.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

2. The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
3. These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Chubb Report on Higher Education for the Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. We, the undersigned, wish to signify our strong opposition to the Chubb Report on Higher Education for the A.C.T. which proposes that the Institute of Advanced Studies be separated from the Faculties of the Australian National University and the Faculties be amalgamated with the University of Canberra. We believe that the implementation of these proposals would mean the destruction of the Australian National University's national and international high standing and firmly established reputation as a centre of excellence in research and scholarship. The dismemberment of the ANU would severely affect the ability of both the Institute and the Faculties to attract, or even retain, high quality academic staff, funding and support. It would also adversely affect the recruitment of top students. The maintenance of the Australian National University, as it is now constituted-a national university with an international, national and local role-is of vital importance to the A.C.T. and Australia.
2. We call on the Senate to reject the recommendations of the Chubb report and to support the integrity of the ANU and the existing relationship between the Institute and the Faculties.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: ARTS, SPORT, ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 amends six Acts, and repeals one Act, of the DASETT Portfolio.

The repeal of various borrowing provisions in the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 and the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978 are the result of last year's decision by the Loans Council that the States and Territories will gradually assume full responsibility for raising and servicing their own Government debt.

In this context it is no longer appropriate for borrowings by the ACT and Northern Territory Governments and their statutory authorities to require the Commonwealth Treasurer's approval, nor for there to be standing provisions in the Self-Government Acts for the Commonwealth to guarantee such borrowings. These provisions will therefore not apply to borrowings made after 30 June 1991.

The repeal will not affect the Commonwealth's power under other legislation, current or future, to guarantee Territory borrowings for special reasons, nor limit the borrowing powers of the ACT or the Northern Territory.

The amendment of section 14 of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 will enable the Legislative Assembly of the ACT to legislate to establish a superannuation scheme for members of the Assembly and their dependants.

Section 14 must be read together with section 73 of the ACT Self-Government Act. Section 73 provides for the remuneration of members to be determined either by the Remuneration Tribunal or by enactment of the Legislative Assembly. There is currently a Remuneration Tribunal determination in force and there is conflicting legal advice as to whether an enactment could be made. Paragraph 14 (1) (c) provides that a member vacates his or her office if the member ``takes, or agrees to take, directly or indirectly, any remuneration, allowance, honorarium or reward for services rendered in the Assembly, otherwise than under section 73''.

Honourable Senators will understand that, given the conflicting legal advice in relation to the position of sections 14 and 73, as well as the risk to members of the ACT Legislative Assembly who may receive what could be unauthorised benefits, it was thought advisable to include new subsections 14 (3) and 14 (4). These subsections specifically exclude a superannuation scheme for members of the ACT Legislative Assembly and their dependants from the provisions of section 14, and hence also from the provisions of section 73.

The amendments to the Australian Sports Commission Act 1989 will bring reports on the financial transactions and state of affairs of the Australian Sports Foundation under the reporting requirements of section 63M of Division 3 of Part XI of the Audit Act 1901 (the Audit Act).

The Commission has previously included this information voluntarily in its annual reports, but it has been decided to formalise the arrangement following a request from the National Audit Office. It is also consistent with the Government's policy of applying to all Commonwealth statutory authorities the provisions of either Division 2 or Division 3 of Part XI of the Audit Act, which apply to public statutory authorities, including related bodies corporate, such as the Australian Sports Foundation.
The amendments to the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990 correct two minor drafting errors. They do not affect the meaning or application of the Act.
The Bill includes a number of amendments to the National Library Act 1960. Most are minor technical corrections and improvements.

The amendment to section 7A of the Act increases the power of the Library to purchase and dispose of assets, and to enter into contracts, without the need to obtain the approval of the Minister, from $50,000 by amount of money or value of property involved, as is currently provided, to $250,000. This new threshold will reflect the present scale of the Library's financial operations and correct the effect of inflation on the previous limit, which has remained unchanged for 18 years. The 1988 Review of the NLA supported a substantial increase in the threshold.

Among the amendments to sections 15 and 17E, and in new section 15A, is the removal of the requirement that the Governor-General notify in the Gazette the vacation of office and resignation of members of the Council, and of the Director-General, of the Library. The removal of this requirement from the Act was deemed appropriate given that Gazettal is not practice for other statutory authorities.

New section 21 of the Act will make the provisions of Division 3 of Part XI of the Audit Act 1901 apply to the National Library. This is in line with current Government practice to apply the provisions of either Division 2 or Division 3 of Part XI of the Audit Act to Commonwealth statutory authorities.

New section 21A provides the Library with a power to invest money held by the Library, other than on trust, that is not immediately required for the purposes of the Library, on deposit with an approved bank, in Commonwealth securities or in any other manner approved in writing by the Treasurer. This power is similar to that given the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority under section 54A of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975.

New section 27A will allow regulations to be made for the supply of liquor on Library premises, similar to that provided in the National Gallery Act 1975, the National Museum Act 1980 and the Australian National Maritime Museum Act 1990. This will provide the Library with its own independent power over the sale, supply, disposal, possession or control of liquor on its premises, and allow it to operate its catering facilities on a more commercial basis.

New section 27B will extend the regulatory powers to control the movement and conduct of persons on Library land and buildings, similar to those in the Australian War Memorial Act 1980, the Australian National Maritime Museum Act 1990 and the National Gallery Act 1975. The new section will allow regulations to be made to increase security to ensure the future safety of the national collection of Library materials and to prevent trespass to restricted areas.

The final amendment to the Library Act, to section 28, will increase the maximum monetary penalty limit for offences against the regulations from $100 to $500, as well as removing any reference to terms of imprisonment. This will provide a more appropriate penalty and make the limit consistent with that of other cultural institutions, such as the National Museum, the War Memorial and the National Maritime Museum.
The Bill also includes a number of amendments to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 to achieve two objectives.

The first of these objectives is to allow all money collected by the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service from leases, licences, permits and other authorities to be used by the Service in the pursuance of its nature conservation role. This is achieved by removing the current requirement in subsection 46 (2) of the Act that all such money be paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund, and specifying instead, through an amendment to subsection 46 (1), that the money must be paid into the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Fund.

The second objective is to allow the Director of the Service to invest money that is held by the Service but is not needed immediately. This is achieved by removing the prohibition on investment currently contained in Section 49 of the Act and adding a new section 49A. Section 49A specifies that money standing to the credit of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Fund that is not required immediately for the purpose of the Fund may be invested by the Director with an approved bank, in Commonwealth securities, or in any other manner approved by the Treasurer.

This power is also similar to that given the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority under Section 54A the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975. As well as allowing interest to be gained on money held in the Fund, this provision will allow the Director of the Service to accept bequests in the form of shares, securities and other forms of investment.
Finally, the opportunity is taken in the Bill to repeal the Darwin Lands Acquisition Act 1945, which is entirely spent.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 February, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Social Security Bill 1990. This is an area of considerable importance and interest to a great number of Australians.
—I believe that Senator Patterson wants the call. I call Senator Patterson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, you might be operating under a misbelief or a misinterpretation of what I want to do. I will follow the very profound speech that Senator Parer has made on the Social Security Bill 1990. This Bill is the first of its kind in this Parliament; it is a very large Bill. It has been put forward in an attempt to make legislation understand- able. It simplifies the legislation, particularly the area of social security where the legislation has been quite complex and there have been significant changes in previous years. It has been difficult for clients of social security to understand their rights in this area. Concerns have been expressed by some groups about minor changes that have been made in the legislation. I am sure that Senator Alston will address that matter when he speaks on the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is that simplicity does not always mean that the Bill is necessarily short, just like this speech will not be as short as I would have liked it to have been. The fact is that the Bill is now before the Senate. I think that Senator Alston will address many of the issues of concern, and I will concede to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in a bit of a quandary at the moment. At this stage, it would be fair to call Senator Lees as the Opposition has, in fact, had two speakers. I will call Senator Lees and then Senator Alston.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Bill 1990 represents a major and largely commendable undertaking by the Government. It is, in fact, a total rewrite of the Social Security Act into plain English form. The Department of Social Security does appear to have consulted very widely on this rewrite, something that perhaps it should have done on issues such as deeming. However, the result of this is a reasonably accessible piece of legislation. I do have doubts as to whether it actually is in plain English, but I share the general community view that it is certainly a lot clearer than it was and as clear as could be expected when dealing with such a complex and difficult area.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly impressed by the overall restructuring of the Bill which makes it much easier to locate relevant clauses and considerably easier to find specific information. A number of other innovative features also contribute towards making this a much more accessible piece of legislation-certainly far more accessible than its predecessor.

I will go through a few of these: an index of words and phrases used in the Bill which directs the reader towards the clauses where they are defined; the method statements that appear at the foot of some sections which explain the way the clauses operate, or provide a step by step guide on the carrying out of some of the most complex calculations; the standard rate calculations contained in chapter 3, which have made what were virtually indecipherable sections into much more useful provisions that, although still requiring a fair degree of concentration, certainly make it easier to calculate payment rates; and notes at the foot of some clauses which clarify points of interpretation or the relationship between the clause and taxation requirements or State laws, and provide a cross reference to other relevant clauses in the Bill.

It is fair to say that there is general consensus among the relevant community groups and agencies that this Bill represents a fair outcome for a difficult and complex task. I have been in contact with a number of organisations which have been most interested in the process, and they have not raised any major concerns at all about this Bill with me. As I mentioned earlier, there have been some digs about what lawyers and legislators think is plain English but, generally, the word is that the Government has done a very reasonable job. Credit should certainly be given here where credit is due, and I commend the Government for its effort with this Bill.

There are some minor policy changes within this Bill. But these are generally positive and, if anything, improve the situation for clients. In fact, in many instances they actually implement what is already departmental practice. I will go quickly through some of these changes. There are minor changes to the pensions income base; compensation recovery; Social Security Appeals Tribunal requirements; debt and compensation recovery; benefit income test; information gathering and notification powers; sickness benefit; special benefit; and entitlement status. These are relatively minor changes and certainly we commend them.

As I have said, we do not have any great problems with this rewrite. Therefore, we are rather surprised that this Bill will be taken to the committee stage, but we look forward with interest to listening to any problems that others may have found.

With regard to amendments, the Australian Democrats would like to amend virtually the entire piece of legislation. However, we are treating it as a rewrite and, therefore, as it is not, we believe, the legislative vehicle for any significant changes in social security policy or practice, we will be leaving the many amendments that we would like to move until we see this Bill reappear in, probably, no longer than about a month.

However, I would like to move on to some general concerns. While the rewrite may be a cause for praise in terms of its relative accessibility, it is the content of the Bill and the Government's continuing targeting of the victims of the recession-the recession which it admits that it engineered-that warrant condemnation. There are now significant numbers of Australians living in poverty. They endure a standard of living well below that afforded by ordinary, average Australians. They simply do not have access to many of the things more well-off Australians take for granted-regular work, education for them and their children, leisure and social activities.

It is easy to become bored by talk of poverty or homelessness, or people queuing for food or financial assistance. Unfortunately, as a number of media articles have pointed out to us in the last couple of weeks, the `I'm all right Jack' philosophy is well and truly entrenched in this country. Those people who are lucky enough-those of us who have jobs that we know we are going to be able to hang on to, have roofs over our heads and enough money to decently feed, clothe, educate and support our children-do not seem to have come to an understanding of how hard it is for a growing number of Australians to survive.

We must continue to acknowledge the human cost of this recession and squarely pin the blame on the Government not only for its policies which have got us into this position but particularly for its continuing unwillingness to assist the victims of these policies. We are facing massive increases in unemployment as a direct consequence of this Government's policies. More and more families across the country are finding it impossible to make ends meet. These are not just families in our cities but, more and more, families in rural communities.

This week the Adelaide Advertiser quoted a financial counsellor with the Para District Counselling Service in Elizabeth as saying that she was alarmed that people struggling to meet their basic bills were now cutting costs by forgoing food and medicine. Yet we still have no commitment from the Government to help voluntary agencies deal with the consequences of the recession that we had to have. The plain fact is that people on statutory incomes do not have enough money to live on.

I will now look specifically at some of the figures. I am using poverty lines released by the Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research for September 1990. The line against which the income of a single adult was measured in September 1990 was $151.70 a week. Consider then the young single unemployed person aged 20 years or under, who is not living at home and who is barely surviving on $105.15 a week. Even if we include the maximum rent allowance of another $30.00 a week, that this person may have been entitled to, this young person is still barely surviving well below the poverty line.

The poverty line for single parents with two children was $255.40 a week in September. A sole parent with two young children, receiving a basic pension, additional pension for the children, the mother's and guardian's allowance and family allowance, would only be just on the poverty line with an income of about $225.60 a week. The poverty line for an unemployed couple was $316.10 a week in September. A couple with two young children receiving unemployment benefits, as well as other entitlements for their children, will have an income of about $310 a week or $6 below the poverty line.

It may seem that we have no great cause for concern if people are living just above or below the poverty line, but what the research indicates quite clearly is that the poverty lines are very basic levels of cost. If a family is surviving at the poverty line level, or even with a margin of a few dollars above or below it, it is barely covering its most basic needs and will be maintaining a very austere standard of living. For many of these families it is not just for one month or two; it is for month after month, indeed year after year.

The poverty line is a useful test of how families are living and, although it cannot be seen as a hard and fast measure of living standards, it is widely accepted, as Jenny Trethewey points out in her book Aussie Battlers, that:
. . . families living just below and just above the poverty line share a subsistence living standard and a common battle to make ends meet.

Indeed, Jenny Trethewey's research is particularly illuminating because it shows a number of ordinary Australian families who are up against it and are battling to survive, through absolutely no fault of their own. As Bishop Peter Hollingworth says in his introduction to Aussie Battlers:

. . . the families in this survey have had very limited control over their life circumstances and have behaved as responsibly as they could in upholding the interests of their children as their primary objective.

The fundamental causes of their problems relate to marriage and family breakdown, increased levels and longer periods of unemployment, high housing costs and low levels of government income support for children. All these causes point to the central issue at stake which is that it is intolerably hard to raise a family on a very low income in a society where living costs are so high.

What all this suggests is that there is a growing number of ordinary Australians and their families for whom life has been reduced to a question of daily survival. This is verified by the number of people turning up at-and being turned away from-welfare organisations providing emergency assistance and relief. These people are not knocking on the Salvation Army's door for the heck of it. It is not their idea that it is somehow enjoyable to beg for help from St Vincent de Paul. It is not some sort of holiday for them to have to wait for hour after hour in a community centre just to get food vouchers. They are cash-starved, their children are often hungry and they simply do not have enough money to make ends meet.

Yet what do we get from the Government and the Opposition? From the Government, we have had several years of hacking away at the social security budget until even the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) last year agreed that it simply could not take any more cuts. We have seen payments to young people slashed, a pharmaceutical charge introduced for pensioners and beneficiaries, and the introduction of a liquid assets test on applicants for unemployment and sickness benefits. We have seen a reduction in the availability of rent assistance and the introduction of measures which discriminate against pensioners and beneficiaries, while genuine reform of the taxation system slips further and further off the agenda. And as for the Opposition? It plans to cut people off unemployment benefits after nine months because it thinks, as Senator Alston said in an article by Adele Horin in the Sydney Morning Herald on 26 February, 1991:
The mere fact you will have a cut-off point for unemployment benefits will concentrate the mind.

No wonder the author of this article, Adele Horin, called the Opposition's policy `heartless in the extreme'. Apparently, according to the Opposition and Senator Alston, people on unemployment benefits are actually having a wow of a time, they do not really want to work or their minds are just not sufficiently concentrated on the task of looking for work.

I wish Senator Alston would talk to some of the families who are queuing outside our welfare agencies and explain his policies to them. He should talk to those people queuing outside the Adelaide Central Mission. He should tell that to the hundreds of young people who recently applied for one videotape operator's job right here in Parliament House, or the several hundred people who turned up for just two jobs with the Melbourne City Council recently. Tell it to the hundreds of unemployed people of all ages in my home State of South Australia who have tried anything and everything just to get a job. They are prepared to go to the Riverland to work in very extreme conditions for very low wages. They are prepared to do anything, as they are desperately seeking work. Senator Alston should also tell it to the 18 unemployed people-that is an old statistic; I would suggest it is even higher-applying for every job vacancy. That is only an average. That gives no indication that there are often hundreds of applicants for every unskilled job or jobs requiring low skills.

With the Labor Government's popularity in decline, Australians need to look very closely at the alternatives being offered to them by the Opposition. If they do, they will see that they are not just getting more of the same-they are getting worse. Essentially we have seen the Government move away from a social security system which was designed to be a safety net, which idea has had bi-partisan support for many years from many governments. Over the past several years, we have seen this Government start to pick at the safety net and stretch it until holes begin to appear. Today we are seeing the consequences of people falling through these holes.

Our social security system used to be driven by the attitude that we helped those who, through no fault of their own, were in financial need. We have taken significant steps away from that and have embraced the notion of targeting, which attacks the very concept previously underlying the social security system: it would apply universally to those Australians who lacked sufficient funds to maintain themselves and their families. Indeed, the Government has succeeded in making the system an administrative nightmare, with more and more hurdles being put in the way of those trying to seek minimal support. It has taken a targeting approach to its extreme, with no tangible social benefit to show for it. For example, in a report issued last year, the ACT Council of Social Service said:

In 1947 a Special Benefit was introduced to pay anyone in financial need who was not entitled to other Commonwealth income support payments, provided they were not involved in industrial disputation. The Department now has a set of administrative instructions in place which has divided this Special Benefit into 32 different granting categories. Apart from providing unproductive employment to staff of Social Security, such excessive regulation serves no other purpose than to make it more difficult for people in economic need who do not have an entitlement to other forms of Commonwealth income support to obtain any payment. This defeats the original legislative intention and serves no worthwhile social purpose.

This exemplifies the new Australian Labor Party attitude to income support. The concept of security has well and truly disappeared from our social security system. It is time we recognised that people need income security because they are without financial support. That is the reason we need a social security system.

What is going to happen as more and more holes appear in the safety net? What will happen as more and more people fall through this so-called safety net? Where does the Government think they should go? I can tell honourable senators where they end up. They do not suddenly miraculously get jobs or find other sources of income; their minds are not suddenly so concentrated that they can start up their businesses again or buy back the farm or go out and find a non-existent job. No, they end up on the steps of welfare agencies. I quote from the Adelaide Advertiser:
The debt project officer with the South Australian Council of Social Services . . . Mrs Margaret Galdies, described the lack of resources available to the agencies as a `sad indictment on society'.
`When agencies which are seen as a last resort by many can't help any more, where do people go?'

Surely, this must be a clear indication to the Government that not only are its economic policies not working but also the social security system is failing to provide adequate support for the victims of these policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition similarly welcomes the introduction of the Social Security Bill 1990. We see it as a major step forward to have a new plain English version of what has hitherto been an incredible nightmare, even for lawyers, let alone ordinary members of the public who have tried to wade their way through the current mishmash and complexities of the Social Security Act and the more than 100 amending Acts that have been added on since 1947. We therefore regard this as a very positive step, one that we hope will be replicated in other areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, it has been said to us that the rewrite does not involve any major policy initiatives. I have to say that the Government has been less than forthcoming in detailing what changes there have been. A document headed `Policy Changes' has been made available. It seems to have emanated from the legal section of the Department of Social Security, but it is almost entirely concerned about the impact that these changes will have on DSS staff rather than on the policy nature of the changes. Therefore, I continue to require the Department to spell out the details of the changes to a greater extent and also to specify whether there is any cost to revenue involved.

On the face of it, many of these changes seem minor and, as others have said, the agencies which are very vigilant in those matters have not, to date, expressed any significant concerns, although the welfare rights unit took the precaution of establishing a task force to consider in detail the implications of the Bill and, on the basis of the discussions that we have had with the unit, it is to provide to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs any matters of concern in the course of this day. If it does not have those concerns, then I imagine there would be no need for the Committee to have a meeting because it would mean that there really is not anything to contradict the Government's assertions that this is simply a rewrite and does not involve any policy changes of significance. I think, if we proceed on that basis, then we should all be welcoming what is, hopefully, going to be a new era for those who have to deal with the complexities of this legislation on a daily basis.

I would like to say a few brief words about the area of social security in general. I am prompted to do so, in particular, by the very selective and misleading remarks of Senator Lees. It is very unfortunate that those who address themselves to the human misery and plight of those who suffer from a range of disadvantages are not prepared to look at the causes of those disadvantages. Once again, we simply had a litany of complaints and political criticisms; but we had no attempt to address the underlying root causes of poverty. I think it has been said by many, and I certainly echo the sentiment, that the greatest antidote to poverty is employment.

What is critically needed at the present time is to get Australia back on the track, to re-establish a rising standard of living-one that will enable ordinary Australians to have access to jobs and not to have to be reliant on social security. To the extent that people are, despite their best endeavours, unable to obtain employment, there has never been the slightest suggestion that the Opposition would see them go wanting. That is why I find it somewhat distressing, but perhaps not altogether surprising, that Senator Lees would make no mention at all of the corollary of the policy that we took to the last election, which involved the provision of special benefits for those who were unable to obtain employment within a specified period.

It is also, I think, somewhat less than frank for the Australian Democrats not to put that sort of proposal in an international context and to acknowledge that no other country in the world has an open-ended system of providing unemployment benefits. The Democrats seem to think there is no such thing as incentive; that one should simply take people at face value and, in effect, provide assistance to all those who ask for it. I do not believe that is the responsibility of government; it would be an abdication of responsibility. The Government's responsibility is to satisfy itself that people are in genuine need and that, despite their best endeavours, they are unable to look after themselves; that is the concept of a safety net which we continue to endorse.

We certainly take the view that the voluntary agencies do a magnificent job and we find it surprising that the Government has been reluctant to provide any additional resources to those agencies despite the obvious significant increase in calls on their largess. We would certainly take a different approach. We would regard the agencies as much better barometers and judges of need and channels through which we believe resources could be provided much more effectively than through the current bureaucratic mechanisms. So I reiterate that we do not regard social welfare as a residual area. It is a critically important area of social and human need but it is not there simply for the availability of anyone who wants to call on it: it is there as a last resort. That, clearly, must involve targeting.

The notion that somehow we ought to have a universal system simply does not make sense in this context. It might make sense to Senator Lees and others in the context of superannuation or age pensions where it is often argued that we ought to have a national scheme that would be funded either by contributions made during a person's lifetime or simply through the tax system. But to argue that somehow social security ought to provide universal coverage is a nonsense. Who are we providing assistance to? Clearly, we have to define the eligibility requirements, and then we have to be satisfied that people are within those requirements. That is what targeting is about. Targeting is about the efficient delivery of social security benefits to those who are in need of them.

To the extent that one can eliminate the application of benefits to those who do not need them-either because they misstate their position or because of bureaucratic inadequacies-then one has a much reduced capacity to provide additional assistance to the very people Senator Lees is concerned about. That is precisely our concern; our agenda is not to go about reducing the welfare bill for the sake of it. Our concern is to ensure that the welfare bill, which on any calculation is a very significant proportion of government outlays, is used in its most effective manner. That means recognising the needs of those in the community who are the victims of a failed economic strategy that has seen the economy in decline and now in recession-with depression perhaps around the corner-and trying to assist those people in a range of ways. The last resort of those ways will be social security. Unless the Democrats are prepared to target and to look at those most in need then they have a nonsense of a policy. It seems to be again just another example of the Democrats wanting to wring their hands and pretend that somehow they are the only ones concerned about these issues, without any serious attempt being made to ascertain the priorities or to try to identify more effective ways of ensuring that people's needs are met in this area.

I conclude by saying that the Social Security Bill is a welcome move. We hope that there will not be any unintended consequences that emerge subsequently but we do believe it will provide a boon to all those many users of the Act and whose numbers presumably are also on the increase at the present time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always welcome to see support for initiatives such as this from the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. I am sure all honourable senators welcome an initiative by the major government departments and instrumentalities, when redrafting important Bills, to which citizens must have access to exercise their rights, to express them more clearly. Recently I have had cause to have special responsibility for and interest in various of the tax Bills. I have seen the conflict that one can get into, in the sense to which Senator Patterson referred, between simplicity and brevity, between simplicity and certainty and between those things and equity. Once we start building in special provisions to take care of the special circumstances of individuals confronted with complex circumstances in a complex society, it does not necessarily mean that something that is written in simple language will be simple legislation because we are legislating to administer a complex society.

SPEECH.PARA: Without entering into the little spats between the Opposition and the Democrats over the Social Security Bill, I welcome their support for it, the statements they have made and the principle they have espoused about the initiative of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) and the Government to introduce this plain English version of the legislation. I hope that at the committee stage people will see that it has achieved its purpose of simplicity without any unforseen and adverse consequences. Such a major drafting exercise is always difficult. I look forward to the continuing deliberations of the committee on the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Pursuant to the order of the Senate agreed to on 19 February 1991, the Bill stands referred to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs for consideration and report by 11 March 1991.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Senator McMullan)-by leave-proposed:

That the order of the Senate, of 19 February 1991, requiring the Standing Committee on Community Affairs to present its report on the Social Security Bill 1990 by 11 March 1991, be modified to provide that the Committee present its report on or before 9 April 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion. In doing so I indicate, perhaps in more detail than I did a moment ago, that at this stage we would be confident that there will not be a need for the Standing Committee on Community Affairs to conduct an investigation. But out of an abundance of caution we thought it desirable that all the various interest groups and agencies which take a particular interest in all matters relating to social security should be given an opportunity to provide their views to the Committee. To date I have had discussions with the secretary of the Committee to ensure that the welfare rights unit is fully aware of its entitlements to provide material. I am not aware to date of whether it has done so. The Australian Council of Social Service has indicated that it does not have concerns and, to my knowledge, there are no others who have expressed interest in lodging submissions with the Committee. So at this stage we are hopeful that there will not be a need for the Committee to conduct its hearings, but that does not interfere with the timetable that has been outlined by Senator McMullan.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 March, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Companies (Insolvency Assistance) Amendment Bill, which amends the Companies Act 1981. That Act has now been superseded by the corporations law, but it remains in force in relation to matters arising before the new national scheme laws commenced. The new national scheme laws already contain provisions which are virtually identical to the provisions of this Bill. The purpose of the Bill is to allow a court to order consolidated meetings of a holding company and its subsidiaries to consider schemes of arrangement. Thus, where a group of companies is in financial difficulties and it is proposed to put in place a scheme of arrangement so that the group can continue trading in the interests of its creditors, this can be achieved by having the court order joint meetings of a holding company and its subsidiaries to deliberate on and approve a scheme of arrangement.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation at present under section 315 of the Companies Act is that a company seeking court approval for a compromise or arrangement with its creditors must first seek a court order for meetings to be held of the creditors or members whose rights are affected. Separate meetings of each class of creditor and separate meetings of each class of shareholder in relation to each company are normally required.

It became obvious in the case of the winding up of the Hooker Group in 1989 that this can be grossly impractical. The provisional liquidators in that case were faced with convening around 500 separate meetings of various creditors in relation to various subsidiaries in the group to approve the scheme of arrangement. The delay involved in convening and holding such a large number of meetings could obviously have disastrous ramifications for a company in serious financial difficulty.

This Bill is put forward in response to the Hooker case. It provides for a court to order consolidation of meetings where there are more than 30 subsidiaries or fewer than 30 subsidiaries but circumstances exist that justify the consolidation. The Opposition supports the Bill because it brings the Companies Act, the old law in transition phase, into line with the new corporations law. All companies which are in financial difficulties, regardless of whether they are covered by the old law or the new, will have similar mechanisms available to them in the consideration of schemes of arrangement. This is obviously a fair and equitable situation.

The very fact that the Government has been forced to introduce a Bill to facilitate the setting up of schemes of arrangement for companies in financial difficulties is a damning indictment of the policies that have brought about the appalling deterioration in this country's economy. For example, bankruptcies are increasing at an alarming rate. In the year to June 1990 there was a 10 per cent increase over the previous year. This increase, disturbing enough in its own right, was completely eclipsed by the 1990 September quarter figures which show an increase of 32 per cent over the September quarter of the previous year. Then the December quarter figures show an increase of an incredible 56 per cent as compared with the same quarter of the previous year. Yet, as we know, Mr Deputy President, according to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), this was the recession we had to have.

What the Government seems to have forgotten is that bankruptcies and company liquidations are not just statistics. Every bankruptcy and every liquidation is about a person whose financial problems are so severe he or she has had no choice but to resort to this drastic course of action. For all those who have been forced out of business due to the Government's policy of maintaining crippling interest rates and a massive drop in demand for products and services because of the recession, it must be small comfort indeed to know that, according to the Treasurer, it was a recession we had to have.

At least this Bill will assist in some small measure by facilitating the process of liquidation in relation to holding companies and subsidiaries to bring the provisions in the Companies Act into line with the procedures set out in the corporations law. As I indicated, for these reasons the Opposition feels the Bill is worthy of support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Companies (Insolvency Assistance) Amendment Bill 1990. The background to the Bill is that a company in financial difficulties may make a compromise with its creditors and members and, provided the necessary formalities are complied with and the scheme is approved by a 75 per cent majority, a scheme of arrangement will then bind all members and creditors of the company.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed scheme of arrangement must then be approved by the court to ensure that it is bona fide and not unnecessary or contrary to public policy. The court will then usually order the necessary meeting or meetings. Members and creditors may be directed to separate meetings where their interests are so dissimilar that they cannot consult together with a common interest. The court can also order separate meetings for particular classes of creditors, such as unsecured creditors or members; for example, ordinary or preference stockholders.

At each meeting ordered to be held by the court the scheme must be agreed to by a majority in number representing three-quarters in value of the members or creditors present and voting. After the meetings have occurred and the requisite agreements have been achieved from the members and their creditors, the court must ensure that the meetings and other statutory obligations have been complied with. Provided that public policy considerations do not preclude the arrangement, the court will sanction the arrangement and it shall bind all members and creditors of the company.

So far, so good. However, because of the above requirements, the scheme of arrangement remedy is a nightmare when a huge corporate group is involved. Since the 1987 stock market crash in particular, large corporate group crashes have become commonplace. One prominent crash was that of real estate giant Hooker Corporation. The proposed scheme of arrangement for Hooker would have involved about 500 meetings and could well have been unsuccessful. That company sought a change in the law for its specific circumstances. This was not acceded to. However, the need for general provisions to cover such situations was agreed to and they are now the subject of this Bill.

The Bill will enable a court to order meetings of creditors of a group of companies with 30 or more wholly-owned subsidiaries on a consolidated basis where the scheme of arrangement will have the effect of transferring assets, property and liabilities to the holding company. This is expected to significantly reduce the total number and cost of meetings necessary in complex schemes of arrangements.

The Bill was actually previously distributed as an exposure draft but has been modified since that exposure in one respect. The exposure draft only applied where there were at least 30 wholly-owned subsidiaries in the group of companies. The current Bill provides an additional power for the court to order a consolidation of meetings where there are fewer than 30 wholly-owned subsidiaries where the circumstances justify such an order. The Australian Democrats support the Bill, including this particular change, without amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government thanks Senator Hill, representing the Opposition parties, and Senator Spindler, representing the Australian Democrats, for their support of this very important measure, which is designed to facilitate schemes of arrangement for complex company groups by allowing creditors of different companies in a group to be grouped together for the purpose of approving the scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite apparent, and it has been commented on by previous speakers, that what was needed was a capacity within the court to order meetings of creditors of a group of companies on a consolidated basis where the scheme of arrangement will have the effect of transferring assets, property and liabilities to the holding company. This consolidation will reduce the total number of meetings to a manageable number.

It was quite apparent that in some instances, where a particular collapse has led to many hundreds of companies being involved in a number of States, the number of creditors' meetings required may run into the hundreds. Of course, that can present an enormous impediment to the creditors of a group of companies seeking an arrangement or compromise. So something had to be done. The Government has believed for some time that this remedy is the best way to proceed. Indeed, all State and Territory governments under the ministerial council arrangements thought this was the way to proceed. Mr Bowen initially released an exposure draft on behalf of the ministerial council indicating that this was also the Government's view.

Since that time, interested groups, including the Insolvency Practitioners Association of Australia, the Law Council of Australia and the States corporate affairs commissions have all indicated their support. No doubt that is why the chamber is ready to pass this Bill during the course of today's deliberations.

I think it is important also to note that the power being vested in the court is an additional power. The court already enjoys certain powers under the Companies Act; it has certain discretions in determining the classes of creditors and protecting the interests of creditors. Of course, its paramount duty is to protect the interests of creditors. There is nothing in this proposal which displaces or modifies that very important overriding consideration that the court must direct its activities to securing the interests of creditors in this complex area.

I believe that the cooperation now forthcoming will enable these complex corporate structures, when they collapse, to be the subject of a much more efficient method of coming to a scheme of arrangement. I believe that it is also important that the provisions, which this Parliament has already included in relation to the new corporations law coming into effect on 1 January, be available in relation to the windings up which may have commenced prior to 1 January 1991. I believe that in so far as this Bill virtually amounts to providing for the pre-1 January 1991 situation of the policy, which the Parliament passed into law in relation to post-1 January 1991 corporations matters, obviously it should receive the support of this chamber. I commend its passage to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Family Law Amendment Bill 1991 is a reform Bill. Family law reform is always a controversial and difficult subject. This Bill has a long history and a long period of negotiation behind it, of which I will relate a little in a moment or two.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, I remind the Senate that the last time I spoke in this place on the subject of family law reform was just before Christmas when I was acting for my colleague Senator Brownhill, who was out of the country on parliamentary business. Senator Brownhill has had a project to encourage the setting up of a parliamentary committee to re-examine a number of aspects of family law which have been causing ongoing stress and difficulty within the Australian community, in particular the very challenging subjects of custody, property determinations, access, the cost of family law matters and such related issues. When I last spoke on this issue, I indicated that agreement had been reached between the Opposition parties and the Australian Democrats on a decision to set up such a committee.

I hoped that the Government, recognising that it no longer had the numbers, would take the next step, logical and sensible in our view, and that was to come to the party and agree to cooperate in the formulation of a set of terms of reference that could best achieve the objectives of all within the Parliament who are interested in the subject of family law reform and, in particular, that the Government would then agree that the committee not only be a committee incorporate utilising senators, but a select joint committee that could bring into account the interests and expertise within both chambers of the Parliament.

I am pleased that the Government at the last moment has seen the commonsense in that proposal and has indicated that it agrees to Senator Brownhill's proposition that there will now be set up again a joint select committee to examine the aspects of family law that I have mentioned, and other aspects. I commend those who have been involved in the process of negotiation, particularly my colleague Senator Brownhill who has pursued this issue because he believes that it is right and that these controversial areas of law need to be revisited and also on behalf of a very large constituency which has put its faith in him. He has demonstrated that that faith was well warranted.

I mention that history because some of the aspects that are in this Bill before the Senate today normally would have been before that committee, and some issues of practical concern that will be raised in relation to this Bill and the reforms that we are being asked to implement into law today no doubt will be put to the joint select committee, probably to be known as the Brownhill committee. Therefore, the Parliament itself, in that considered environment, may well come back in some months time and say that the reforms that we might implement today could or should have been varied.

Dealing with what is before us without the benefit of that committee's deliberation, at least we have the comfort of knowing that the issues encompassed in the Bill have been subject to debate for a long time. In particular the proposed amendments result from studies conducted by the Family Law Council and conclusions which are set out in two reports. The first report is entitled Child Sexual Abuse 1988 and the second Cinderella Revisited: Rights and Responsibilities in Step Families. The latter report was put down in 1986. In the case of one report for practically five years and the other for nearly three years, the advice contained within the committee reports has been considered and debated. Out of that process this Bill was produced and was put down in the House of Representatives in May last year, with an invitation that the public comment on the proposed amendments.

As is the normal case in family law matters, the shadow Attorney-General received considerable assistance from the community suggesting changes. That assistance came not only from the community, the clientele of the family law structure, but also from professional bodies. I particularly mention the assistance given by the Law Council of Australia and the Law Institute of Victoria. However, as is the wont of lawyers, the advice was not always the same. In fact, in some instances these eminent legal bodies came to the Parliament with conflicting advice, forming different conclusions on the same suggested reforms. Nevertheless, it is our responsibility then to decide what we are prepared to support, taking into account the advice of eminent persons.

The Bill makes a number of amendments to the existing provisions of family law, particularly in the very difficult area of child abuse. The Bill makes amendments to provide for the reporting of child abuse by Family Court staff to State and Territory child welfare authorities. That is mandatory reporting and is one of the more controversial aspects of the reform package.

It provides for legal protection for Family Court staff who report child abuse to child welfare authorities; it provides for child welfare authorities and other interested persons to intervene in cases involving alleged child abuse; it limits the number of medical and psychological examinations for children obtained by parents involved in custody and access disputes; it inserts an express provision in the Family Law Act requiring the Family Court in certain proceedings to have regard to the need to protect children from abuse; it provides protection for witnesses from abusive or hectoring questioning, and it gives statutory force to the Family Court's practice of admitting hearsay evidence of statements made by children to adults about abuse suffered.

The Bill deals with the difficult subject of step-parent adoptions. It provides that a step-parent adoption does not put an end to existing custody, guardianship or access rights under the Act, unless the Family Court decides that the step-parent adoption is in the child's best interests. The Bill also deals with the question of transfer of custody or guardianship and makes an amendment to stop parents transferring custody or guardianship to non-parents by means of Family Court consent orders or by registering child agreements with the courts.

There are other amendments of slightly less consequence. The first deals with stamp duty. It seeks to ensure that child agreements relating to ex-nuptial children enjoy the same exemption as maintenance agreements for children of marriage in relation to stamp duties that could be levied by State or Territory governments.
It also empowers the police who are authorised under the Family Law Act to arrest a person and to enter and search premises for the wanted person. There are a number of additional minor amendments.

I now deal briefly with the question of step-parent adoptions. I understand that in recent years there have been a number of cases where parents have used adoption procedures to establish a new family unit consisting of the children, one natural parent and a new spouse, being the step-parent. This has been looked at by bodies interested in reform of this area. I refer in particular to the previously mentioned 1986 report on step-families which was put down by the Family Law Council. It commented on the inappropriateness of adoption as a method of establishing the legal status of a stepchild in a step family. The Council preferred and recommended an alternative approach of allowing the Family Court to determine the parties' custody, guardianship or access rights under the Family Law Act.

The clauses that are before us today make clear that a step-parent adoption does not put an end to existing custody, guardianship or access rights under the Act unless the Family Court decides that the step-parent adoption is in the best interests of the child. The Law Council has been somewhat critical of these changes. I understand it argues that the Court has adequate powers as things stand but, on balance, we have decided that further clarification and confirmation cannot do any harm. Because we definitely support the spirit of the amendments, we will be supporting them here today.

On the question of transferring custody or guardianship, the Bill is designed to stop parents transferring custody or guardianship of children to non-parents by means of Family Court consent orders or by registering the child agreements with the Court. These provisions are aimed at ensuring that in future any arrangement that comes before the Family Court that involves conferral of custody or guardianship on non-parents will be scrutinised by the Court to determine whether those non-parents are suitable parents to have custody or guardianship of the child. The only objections that the Opposition has noted to that have been of an administrative nature-concerned about the administrative and financial impact that this might have. But in principle we support the reform and therefore do so in this chamber today.

I mention the exemption of child agreements from stamp duty. That is something that we support. I mentioned also the child maintenance provisions, in particular that part of the Bill providing that a child agreement, in so far as it makes provision in relation to the maintenance of a child, is of no effect if an application for administrative assessment of child support could be made in relation to a child under the provisions of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989. We support that provision.

We support also the provisions that deal with increasing the police powers in this area-that is, the capacity of police, where they are authorised by the Family Law Act or a warrant issued under the Act, to arrest a person and, when they reasonably believe that a person to be arrested is in or on a particular searchable place, they may enter and search that place without a search warrant, presuming that the provisions of these amendments go through today. That reform has our support. Of course, police have similar adequate powers under other pieces of legislation-particularly State legislation-but it has been believed and demonstrated from experience that this extension is also necessary to adequately enforce the provisions of the Family Law Act. We accept that advice. I understand that it has in fact come from no less eminent a person than the Chief Justice, who called for this extension to ensure that police are able to apprehend people who breach domestic violence and other orders issued by the Family Court.

There is an increase in penalties under the Bill. In particular, the monetary penalty for an offence of wrongfully removing a child from Australia is increased to $18,000 from the present $10,000. Someone who contravenes a court order will attract a penalty of $6,000 for a natural person and $30,000 for a body corporate, which is an increase. The offence of wrongfully publishing the identify of parties to proceedings will attract increased penalties. We support those changes. Particularly, I personally support the penalty that deals with someone who wrongfully removes a child from the jurisdiction, which has led, I know from my personal previous professional experience, to quite horrendous family stress in seeking to locate the child, fearing for the child's welfare and adequately seeking to resolve the domestic conflict over that child when the child has been removed from the jurisdiction.

I said at the outset that the major reform contained in the Bill is that in relation to child abuse. One has difficulty in imagining many less pleasant subjects than child abuse. Regrettably, abuses of children do occur; and do occur within family situations; and do occur at times of family break-up. When they do occur, it is obviously important that the authorities, acting on behalf of the community as a whole, have adequate powers to properly intervene to protect the interests of the child. The family law in this country, as it deals with children, has been developed on the primary premise that the interests of the child should be paramount.

One of the more difficult subject matters has always been that of the reporting obligations of officials when they come across circumstances of child abuse or alleged child abuse. Certainly, if I think of my home State of South Australia, under our State laws there are now, in many different areas, mandatory obligations to report evidence of child abuse. This reform that is put before us by the Government today seeks to impose mandatory reporting procedures where allegations of child abuse are made to Family Law officers. To do so has therefore required the Government to seek to define `abuse', which in itself is not easy. I readily concede that. Nevertheless, I accept that it is something that has to be defined if one is going to start imposing mandatory requirements.

We in the Opposition have wrestled with this question and the detail of the Government's legislative proposal. Whilst we certainly believe that cases of abuse should be reported, we do believe that the drafting put to us by the Government is too wide. We do believe that its definition of `abuse' is too wide. In fact, some of our suggested changes were taken up in the other place by the Government; for example, to some extent, the definition of `abuse'-particularly, as I understand it, where it is in the very difficult area of psychological abuse-and some of the provisions have in fact been tightened. But we are still of the view that, when an allegation is made, the professional should be able to assess, in the circumstances of the allegation, whether it should be reported to other authorities. Therefore, we favour placing perhaps a greater responsibility on the professional to make that judgment than the Government does by its amendment, which is to, without discretion, oblige the professional to report the abuse.

The Opposition has also said-and the Government picked this up and accepted it-that, when an allegation of abuse is made against a person, that person should be notified of the abuse. We moved an amendment to that effect in the other place. The Government decided in its wisdom on that occasion to accept that amendment. We are pleased that that has happened. Nevertheless, we come to this chamber still believing that the provisions are too wide and that a discretionary procedure would be a better direction to take. Therefore, I will be moving similar amendments on that issue to those which were moved in the other place.

I hope that our direction in this issue is not misinterpreted. In no way would we want to be interpreted as having a view that abuse should not be reported and that it should not be regarded as horrendous; but there are cases where allegations are wrongly made and there is a responsibility to remember the interests of others. We have taken those into account and, as I said, we have placed the onus and the responsibility back on the professionals to use their good judgment and their experience wisely. That is the rationale of the amendment that we put in that regard.

I mentioned a hearsay question in passing. It has been the practice of the Family Court to accept hearsay evidence in terms of an allegation that has been made by a child to an adult. In this instance, which is an unusual instance, we accept that practice. The court has always got a discretion as to how it receives that evidence and the weight that it places upon it. The Government, however, by its amendment, has sought to legislatively formulate the practice. We do not think it is necessary; we think that it is further limiting discretion. I think that we have some support from professional bodies in our view in that regard. I understand that the Law Council of Australia in particular has regarded the Government's amendment as unnecessary.

We did not press our view in the other place. We were proposing to move an amendment to that effect, but accepted in the end that the Government's amendment does not go much further than to formulate in written form what is an existing practice and, therefore, with the reservations I have just expressed, as was similarly put in the other place, the matter was not pressed.

Another difficult but important question is: who should have the right to intervene in family law matters? The Government, in its amendments, has sought to list those who will have a specific right of intervention. We believe that intervention should always be at the discretion of the court and that leave should be given. We have an amendment to that effect and we will be moving it today. It is an amendment that was put in similar terms in the other place. It also actually increases the list of nominated persons who have an interest and who have, therefore, the right to seek leave to intervene. We certainly believe that in the unique circumstances of family law in the interests of children there will be more cases than in other jurisdictions where leave is given for an interested party to intervene, but we do think that leave is the correct method rather than simply to provide a right in the legislation.
We generally find in practice that leaving discretion to judges is a better method of operation in this area rather than being too rigid. We believe that the Government is seeking to be too rigid.

There is a provision included that I wanted to mention. It provides that a child is not to be physically, medically or psychologically examined for the purpose of evidence in proceedings without the leave of the court. We support that. It seems to us to be a sensible reform.

With those comments, I indicate, therefore, that we support the direction of reform contained within the Bill before us. We support most of the detail, but we will be moving again some of the amendments that we moved in the other place that we believe are still worth pursuing. I have mentioned them during this contribution, particularly that dealing with discretion rather than mandatory obligations in relation to child abuse. On the whole, as I said, we commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the correction to the explanatory memorandum of the Family Law Amendment Bill presented in the Senate on 5 March 1991. The correction is necessary to take account of a number of typographical errors in the explanatory memorandum. These errors resulted from renumbering provisions of the Bill following amendments to the Bill in the House of Representatives. The details of this renumbering were not available prior to printing of the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Family Law Amendment Bill 1991 today, I realise that everyone in this chamber would be aware of my interest in family law reform and my efforts in trying to establish an inquiry into certain aspects of the Family Law Act and interpretations of it. I would like to personally put on the record my thanks to Senator Hill for his help and assistance-I was away representing this Parliament at the United Nations last year-when this Bill was brought up for debate in an attempt to establish an inquiry into the Family Law Act. It was a policy of the Liberal and National parties to have an inquiry into certain aspects of the operation and interpretation of the Family Law Act at the last election. I am very happy that that will now come to fruition. I am also very happy that some members of the Parliament will now be supporting that inquiry. I thank Senator Spindler for his cooperation and support in getting that inquiry on the way.

SPEECH.PARA: The Family Law Amendment Bill is one of a number of amending Bills to the original Family Law Act of 1975, and is indicative of the problems that beset family law. Indeed, there have been 21 separate amendments to the original Act since 1980 when the last parliamentary inquiry was undertaken into a review of the original 1975 Act.

This latest amending Bill has had an on again, off again history, but I am not implying any criticism of the Government because of that; in fact, the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) is to be commended for allowing this Bill to be exposed to public scrutiny and comment by various interested community groups.

There have been a number of aspects of this legislation, both general and legal, on which the community has expressed views and concerns, but perhaps the most sensitive, and certainly one of the most provocative and emotional issues to become intertwined with family law is the question of child sexual abuse. I hasten to advise the Senate that I am in no way an expert, nor would I ever consider myself to be an authority on the question of family law. It is a very emotional area and I know the traumas and the problems that are associated with it. I think that my electorate has many more family law constituents than the electorates of any senator or member of the House of Representatives. Since this Bill was set up, people have written to me expressing their concerns that it was not working quite as well as was intended by those in this chamber and those in the other place.

It would seem that there has been an increase in the number of sexual abuse cases. Whether the incidence is on the increase or whether more people are now coming forward to report them, I am not sure. Nevertheless, a number of sexual abuse allegations are being made in disputed custody cases. Therefore, I think it is vital that these allegations are investigated quickly for all concerned. In his second reading speech, the Attorney-General said, `The issue is significant in a number'-and I would contend many-`of family law cases'.

The issue of whether mandatory or discretionary reporting should apply in such cases is difficult to resolve and there are arguments to support either view. I defer to the shadow Attorney-General and his superior legal knowledge on this question when he suggests that the arguments against mandatory reporting far outweigh those in favour. I believe that his view is shared by others in the field. Personally, I tend to support mandatory reporting in areas of child sexual abuse. When figures are available that suggest that one in 11 children born in New South Wales in 1987 will be reported and confirmed as abused children by the time they reach the age of 16, one can understand the extent of the problem.

I draw to the attention of the Senate, and would like it recorded, the appreciation people in the community have for the active role that Rosemary Sinclair plays as President of the National Association for the Prevention of Child Abuse and Neglect, known as NAPCAN, which is trying to create a climate so that child abuse will not happen. She is the wife of the right honourable Ian Sinclair, member for New England.

I will express a personal concern that it seems that allegations of child sexual abuse appear to be the popular line-for want of a better word-in disputed custody cases. I am concerned at the trauma which the child involved in the allegations suffers. A part of the original Act that seems not to have been addressed-I will not say neglected-in every case is the children who are involved in separations.

As the honourable member for Macquarie, Mr Webster, said in the other place on this subject, the whole situation that surrounds child abuse is very disturbing. He said he did not think we had reflected enough on the implications of the situation for the role of the family in this area, and I endorse those views. The issue is one that we, as a society, really need to examine in far greater depth.

Let me return to the Bill and particularly those clauses which involve the taking of evidence from children, a difficult exercise at any time. In the criminal courts over many years it has been problematical, and certainly in family law cases even more fraught with problems. I note that the Law Council of Australia also expressed concern with this aspect of the status of evidence of children in child abuse allegations.

There are many aspects of this Bill and I think that Senator Hill has covered every aspect very well, in the way that he always does as the Leader of the Opposition in this place. Therefore, I will contain my remarks to those that I have just outlined.

Family law will never be perfect and we will never have legislation that suits everyone. However, while our proposed amendments are patching anomalies as they are brought to the attention of the legislators, I believe that the time is overdue for a proper overhaul and detailed examination of the legislation as a whole. I am happy to say that that time is now close at hand. I trust and hope that the joint committee to be set up next week will, because of its bipartisan support from all members of this Parliament, achieve wise counsel and be able to make recommendations for amendments to take away some of the concerns of, and the heartbreak for, people in the community. I support the amendments moved by Senator Hill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Family Law Amendment Bill 1991. I also wish to take this opportunity to comment first on the establishment of the joint committee of inquiry into the operation of the Family Law Act. I thank Senator Brownhill for his generous acknowledgment of my participation in developing the current terms of reference. It should be noted that this committee of inquiry now also has the support-somewhat belatedly-of the Government, and that the Government also adopted a constructive approach to the development of the terms of reference.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, I am pleased that I was able to get agreement to include the costs of actions brought before the Family Court; that previous reports will now be considered, because we do not wish to reinvent the wheel; and that the adversarial nature of our law as it impinges on family court disputes will be examined. It has always been my view that at least two areas-industrial relations and family matters-should not be resolved in the terms of our adversarial legal system.

I am also pleased that the inquiry will include examination of and, I hope, recommendations on measures other than simply narrow legal amendments to the family law as it stands. By that I mean an examination of alternative methods of dispute resolutions; greater emphasis on mediation and counselling, including counselling well before a marriage is at the point of dissolution; and a generally more positive and supportive set of measures, including increased legal aid, than are currently afforded by the legislation.

I now turn briefly to the Bill before the Senate today. I note, as have speakers before me, that it deals with one of the most traumatic areas-child abuse-that has increasingly come to the notice of our society. It is one that deserves detailed and thorough examination by all of us. I am pleased that the Government has adopted a very constructive approach throughout the progress of this legislation, and has sought the views of the community as well as all parties.

The Australian Democrats support the Bill as initially introduced and now including the Government's amendments. I do not intend to rehearse the detail of the legislation which has been put on record by Senator Hill.
