However, on two major points the Australian Democrats prefer the Bill and the amendments as they are now taking shape as provided by the Government, rather than the amendments proposed by the Opposition. One point is the difference between discretionary reporting and mandatory reporting. On the basis of the large discrepancy between cases of child abuse that are generally considered to occur in the community-and I concede that some of these estimates may well be out of court, so to speak-and the cases that are actually reported, one would have to take the view that we should make it obligatory for people to report any suspicions of such cases that come to their notice.

The Democrats believe that this is too important an area not to make it mandatory to report such cases. To the extent that the Opposition's amendments introduce an element of discretion in these matters, we believe the Government's version is to be preferred. We recognise that this is not a black and white case and that there are considerations on both sides but, on balance, this is the position which we will take.

The other matter on which we differ from the Opposition is that we believe that an element of psychological abuse should be included in the definition of child abuse. We believe, on the basis of consultation with practitioners in the field, that it would be unnecessarily narrow and not realistic to exclude that element in the definition of child abuse.

Mainly on those two points I reiterate that the Australian Democrats will support the Government's amendments in preference to the Opposition's amendments. We note that one Opposition amendment which requires the service of a true copy of the notice upon the person who is alleged to have abused the child, or from whom the child is alleged to be at risk of abuse, has been accepted by the Government and we welcome that. I do not intend to prolong this debate, and simply reiterate that the Australian Democrats will support this Bill and the Government's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak in support of the Family Law Amendment Bill 1991. I feel, as I am sure every senator in this chamber does, that any legislation that is brought before this House in support of the family and, in particular, the protection of children should be given top priority in view of the deep concerns expressed in the past not only by me but also by other senators on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation was first presented in May last year. Now, almost a year later, we are debating it. Given the Government's history in relation to family law, that process is typical. I listed myself to take part in this debate so that I could speak generally about the Family Law Act, its bureaucratic intrusion into the family structure and the subsequent effect that it has had on our national morality. Of course, we know of the deep concern in the community about many of the operations pertaining to the Family Law Act. This concern is not necessarily concern about the Act itself but often its subsequent consequences.

Many areas associated with the Family Law Act cause a lot of concern. There is ample evidence to indicate that, regrettably, child abuse, in many forms, is common in our society today. It is essential to identify typical symptoms associated with any form of child victimisation and to establish the means with which to deal with them. The killing of the innocent unborn child for social and economic reasons and for gender engineering is in any thinking person's mind the ultimate in child abuse. I would encourage all honourable members and senators to think very deeply about and heed the cry of the innocent unborn.

It is essential that every assistance be given to promote early detection of abuse and protection for those who are unable to adequately verbalise their experiences. These traumatic experiences rob children of their childhood. Any changes in legislation that can be of assistance to reveal instances of child abuse must be commended in view of the alarming incidence of child abuse in this country.

I would like to take this opportunity to make a number of general observations about the Family Law Act. This legislation is before us today because increasingly Australian men and women do not hesitate to tear up marital commitments, shirk marital obligations and abuse their former spouses and, in particular, their children either by neglect or by physical abuse.

It is 15 years since the Family Law Act came onto the Australian legal landscape. No-one would deny that this has left us plenty of time in which to examine not only its effectiveness but also many of the consequences of decisions in this field. Calls for amendments to, and reviews of, the Act have nearly been as long as the history of the Act itself.

Divorce is a dreadfully sad thing and, if it is to be dealt with, it has to be dealt with in terms of sympathy, firmness, fairness and justice. I do not believe that there is a person in this chamber who would want to go back to the arguments advanced just after the beginning of the second half of the nineteenth century. I do not want to do that and nobody else in this chamber would. But what we have to remember is that when there is a divorce it also represents the breakdown of another family unit. The family has been the basic unit in Australian society, despite the great changes that have taken place in recent decades. I do hope that, despite all the evidence to the contrary, the family will continue to be just that-the basic unit.

Shiploads of convicts may not have been the most promising material for establishing family life but their gradual emancipation and re-entry into free society, and the arrival of free settlers, ensured that the vast majority of colonists shared the joys and sorrows of family life. In earlier days the family was closely knit and its extended members remained in close touch with each other. Increasing mobility in society breaks up these close networks as people move from one part of the continent to another, and even overseas.

The restriction of family size has seen the extended family go nuclear and brought greater exposure to hostile social forces. These hostile forces are increasing rather than diminishing. They are responsible for the loss of work opportunity; increasing poverty; a widening gap between the affluent and the needy; violence in society as well as in the family; the increasing liberalisation of laws with regard to pornography; the threat of war; and a prevalent sense of apprehension, acquisitiveness and the search for immediate gratification.

The truth is that the family, large or small, is the basic unit of society and the health of society depends ultimately on the stability, well-being and harmonious functioning of that unit. It was once said that civilisation can be lost in a single generation if the value systems are not preserved and passed on through the family. This Act in its entirety has led to a disintegration of many of those value systems.

The Act was not a simple logical extension of previous divorce laws in Australia; it was a very radical and fundamental change. I believe that the Family Law Act itself was one of the most discriminatory, ill-considered and badly drafted Bills to ever be introduced into the Australian Parliament. It discriminated against women and against those men who do not want their marriages to be dissolved at the whim of the other part of the marriage.

Many leaders in the community from the professions, among the social workers and in the churches have pointed to the changes which have been introduced into the nature of marriage and threaten the stability of the family. The Act proceeded on the basis that men and women are equal in the matrimonial situation.

It is a fact of life that, the longer a marriage lasts, the more the women's independence, and particularly her economic ability to fend for herself, becomes less. This element is wholly overlooked by the Family Law Act. It fails to give women the protection and support to which they are entitled as wives and mothers of future generations of Australians. It takes away from women security and legal safeguards and, in the guise of enabling marriages which have broken down irretrievably to be dissolved with dignity, enables all marriages to be dissolved on the unilateral decision of either party on two months' notice. In other words, it reduces marriage to a purely temporary union with little or no protection for women and children.

The Family Law Act has turned marriage into a cheap, temporary union which may be dissolved on the unilateral decision of one party. It creates a climate which will lead to a lighthearted approach to marriage. Many of the predictions by speakers in the House of Representatives when this legislation was first introduced have come to haunt us. Frank Stewart, who was a Minister in the Whitlam Government at the time it was introduced, was a fierce opponent of the legislation. He said:
Under the cloak of removing injustice, humiliation and indignity from divorce, new injustices, new humiliations and new indignities are created.

What could be more humiliating, more unjust, or cause greater distress and hurt to a spouse than to be abandoned without cause by his or her partner merely at the whim of such partner as a matter of convenience on 12 months notice?
This is not divorce because the marriage has irretrievably or otherwise broken down; it is the destruction of marriage by abandonment.
Another speaker, Kevin Cairns, said:
The powerhouse clauses-
of the Act-

. . . concern the nature of the marriage itself, and make it clear that the package no fault is not a package that has any truth; that the so-called relegation of indignity and bitterness is not relegated.

All that is done is that it is swept under the carpet and allowed to fester in the hearts, minds, activities and feelings of those who have been wronged, which in most cases is the dependent partner in a marriage. It certainly is not a Bill which has anything to do with the rights or equality of women in that situation.

And that is what we are seeing today. Many honourable senators would be aware of the large number of constituents who have come to them with complaints. Let us ask ourselves what have been the social and economic consequences for the community of this Act? As predicted, the first consequence has been an increase in the number of divorces in the community. There are at present approximately 41,000 divorces every year in Australia; that is, one in every three marriages breaks down in Australia every year. What a sad and telling statistic. This compares with a yearly average, prior to 1975, of 17,000 divorces, or one in every seven marriages.

Secondly, we have seen the provision of support services and court structures which impose a financial burden on the community. Thirdly, the parties to broken marriages suffer financial and emotional burdens in making new homes and in establishing new personal relations. Fourthly, the consequences of broken homes on children of such marriages have increased in proportion to the number involved. They have suffered psychological damage through family collapse, the loss of security, torn affections and both emotional and material disturbance. In a letter to the Australian newspaper the Bishop of Toowoomba said:

I believe that the Family Law Act which made divorce available to either party after 12 months separation struck a heavy blow at marriage and the family. I believe that Act is primarily responsible, indirectly, for the present state of homelessness which affects families as well as children.
He asked whether some government would have the courage to examine seriously the content and implementation of the Family Law Act.

Let me say how pleased I am that my colleague Senator Brownhill has called for a review of the Act and that the Government has agreed to his plea in this regard. I, with other honourable senators, certainly look forward to the outcome of this joint inquiry that will be held. I understand from what Senator Brownhill has said that this inquiry will start work on this matter next week. I certainly hope that it will result in improvements to this Family Law Act.

I regret to say that socially our community has suffered directly as more of its individual components manifest partial or total collapse. Directly the community suffers because a family collapse contributes to an erosion of these values which buttress marriage and family. Financially, the community is obliged to bear a substantial portion of the direct costs of family breakdown. These costs include the maintenance of those parties and their children unable to support themselves without social security assistance; the administrative costs associated with increased demands upon the legal system; the increased demands upon by the Australian Legal Office; the increased demands for child-care centres, and the increased demand for services to deal with the psychological and physical ill health of disadvantaged one-parent families.

Indirectly the community bears an even greater financial burden. It is the cost of anti-social behaviour and the cost of the new generation of unstable marriages which become evident as the children of broken homes reach adulthood. Society has altered since the introduction of the Family Law Act and, as has been demonstrated, not necessarily for the better.

Today we will put in place legislation that will further determine the nature of the family and bring further stability and safety into the marriage relationship, particularly with regard to children. I do not think that there is any sinister conspiratorial attack on the family unit in what is being proposed in this legislation although I do not doubt that those ideologically opposed to the traditional family will experience some satisfaction over the situation. Rather, this legislation is the natural and necessary response of lawmakers acting prudently to achieve justice for the weaker parties and, in particular, children.

I find the whole situation that surrounds child abuse very disturbing. I do not think that we have reflected fully enough on the implications of the role of the family in this area. We certainly seem to be oblivious to the continuing erosion of those intangible bases of human relationships in marriage-the family and society-which this Bill both reflects and produces.

Whilst we are discussing a Bill which is tremendously important with regard to the protection of children, we still have some very glaring areas in our community where we are neglecting the causes of the problem. We also have to be able to say that we have done our utmost to make sure that the causes of this problem are fully dealt with and that we have a clear conscious. We should not be running around trying to find statistics and arguments which cast some doubt on the case I am putting forward. I believe it is correct.

In conclusion, it is our duty to alert the Australian community to what is gradually but surely occurring in Australia. There is less compassion, self-sacrifice and self-discipline in human relationships. There is more and more bureaucratic intervention in those relationships and this too is not helping the stability of the family. Family values can be concentrated on and children can be made secure in the family situation. I think that this is very important when we think of the attitude to child abuse, the matter that we are discussing today. If we had more stable families there would indeed be less child abuse.

It is very sad that intervention is necessary in this instance. It is not that I think these amendments are not needed; they are needed. But it is very sad to think that such a Bill is required and that we have to make provision for this kind of attention in the society in which we live.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join my colleagues today in making a small contribution to this debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill 1991. In doing so, I point out that this important Bill has a number of significant consequences for the way in which the existing Family Law Act currently operates.

SPEECH.PARA: Principally, it will require counsellors with the Family Court of Australia to report cases of child abuse to child welfare authorities. It also seeks to allow the Family Court to admit as evidence hearsay statements by children, and it will also protect witnesses from abusive, insulting, oppressive or repetitive questions. In addition, the amendments ensure that the adoption of a child by a step-parent will not, without the court's approval, end the custody, maintenance, guardianship or access rights of the child's natural parent.

This Bill comes before the Senate after a considerable period of debate. Originally introduced into the House of Representatives in May last year, it was withdrawn in December to allow detailed consideration, amendments and input from interest groups. It is a disappointment that, when the Bill was considered by the House of Representatives in late February, the Government was not prepared to accept a number of the coalition's very important amendments. I will deal with them in more detail later.

Initially, I would like to take the opportunity afforded by the discussion of this Bill to raise a number of issues relating to the Family Law Act. One has already been referred to by my colleagues, and I remember Senator Bjelke-Petersen raising the point. I and many others in this place share a common experience in having received distressing representations from constituents regarding the operation of the Family Law Act as it currently stands. These are particularly distressing personal matters in which one often feels powerless to act. If there is a common theme throughout these representations, it is the very contentious issue of custody of children and distribution of matrimonial property.

In the past few weeks at least four men, a couple of whom were very distressed, visited my office not only because of the custodial side of the marriage break-up but particularly the financial side. In one particular case the person speaking to me said that the arrangements that had just come to pass had taken away any incentive he had to continue in his line of work. He felt any extra income that he could generate was taken away from him. I do not wish to pass blame in this matter but, on the other side of the coin, his former wife was lucky enough to marry a person who was quite well heeled, and the person in my office felt it was unfair that he should have to pay so much money when his wife was so well off. I know that also works the other way.

The introduction of the Family Law Act about 15 years ago heralded a new era in relation to the operation of family law in this country. There is no question about that. It removed the concept of guilt and introduced a `no fault, no questions asked' system.

It is clear that the introduction of the Family Law Act has removed a number of very significant burdens in relation to ending what could be considered unsuccessful marriages. We should realise, however, that at present there are around 41,000 divorces each year in Australia, as Senator Bjelke-Petersen just mentioned. This compares with the average, prior to the implementation of the Act, of 17,000-or one in seven marriages.

The Australian Institute of Family Studies, in a recent report on the subject of divorce, has indicated that divorce and separation are costing Australian taxpayers $2 billion each year in supporting parents benefit payments, legal aid and the costs associated with the Family Law Act. No-one would advocate a return to the system where we had private investigators snooping around in an attempt to catch a partner out. Nor would we welcome the blaze of publicity which often accompanied the reporting of such actions. There is an increasing number of Australians who complete their dealings with the Family Court feeling distressed and cheated. In 1980-81 a parliamentary inquiry, chaired by my colleague the honourable member for Dundas, Mr Ruddock, examined the operation of the Act. Unfortunately, whilst this inquiry received bipartisan support and made a number of recommendations, its findings lay on the table.

It is, therefore, long overdue for the Act to be reviewed, and I welcome, as I am sure the Australian community will welcome, the review of the Family Law Act which has been instigated in the Senate by my colleague Senator Brownhill. It is a shame that he is not present to hear me put on record my congratulations to him for the very single-minded and forthright manner in which he has pushed this matter. I think in years to come the people of Australia will owe him a debt if what comes out of this inquiry, as he hopes it will, rectifies a lot of the problems being faced by people who, unfortunately, are being forced to separate and endure all those problems that go with it. The review will provide a very positive forum by which the community can bring to the attention of the Parliament difficulties currently associated with the Act and which, ultimately, I trust, we as representatives of the people will recognise.

Returning to the Family Law Amendment Bill, which we are discussing at present, I will address perhaps one of the most sensitive and controversial subjects relating to the Bill, that of child sexual abuse. This is a particularly distressing subject, but we cannot afford to put our heads in the sand and ignore it. The National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children was established in Australia in 1894. Unfortunately, attempts to deal with this subject have been hampered because of a community perception that what occurs within the privacy of the home is nobody else's concern. Research carried out by the Western Australian Department for Community Services reported that 52.4 per cent of parents believe they legally own their children, and 64.7 per cent believe that what happens inside the family's home is nobody's business but the family's.

It is important to remember that the problems associated with such abuse are far reaching. My colleague the Hon. Ian Sinclair in the other place indicated that over 90 per cent of those who currently occupy the gaols around our country have been abused in some way as children. While such abuse is not necessarily sexual, it nevertheless highlights the scale of the problem of the abuse of Australia's children.

One of the problems which have confronted the Australian Bureau of Statistics, through its welfare statistics branch, has been the very difficult task of collecting data to provide an overview of the extent of this most serious problem. However, given the diversity of State legislation and the fact that many such instances remain undetected, the extent of the problem has been impossible to define.

What has become apparent, nonetheless, is that the increasing professional focus on this subject has identified that the number of children reported and confirmed as being abused has increased. Perhaps an example of the situation is the 1987 analysis by the New South Wales Department of Family Community Services research branch. Based on the data compiled by that report, it is predicted that 9 per cent of children born during 1987 will be reported and confirmed as abused children before they reach the tender age of 16 years. This is a very sad figure, but I believe it should act as a catalyst to us all to do something about it.

The provisions contained in the Family Law Amendment Bill relate to the recommendations of a committee established in 1985 by the Family Law Council to examine and report on cases involving allegations of child sexual abuse. That Committee recommended that the Family Law Act of 1975 should be amended to provide more explicit recognition of children's needs for protection against abuse. It also recommended that the hearsay rule not apply to children's statements and that notification of child sexual abuse should be made to relevant State or Territory child welfare authorities by legal practitioners, Family Court counsellors and others associated in that area.

Clause 12 of the amendment Bill sets out the procedure to report cases of child abuse. Clause 14 allows child welfare authorities to intervene in cases involving allegations of child abuse. Clause 17 will limit the number of medical and psychological examinations for children which parents can obtain in custody or access disputes. One of the more contentious clauses is clause 15, which will allow the practice of admitting hearsay evidence of statements made by children to adults concerning abuse to which they claim to have been subjected. As I have indicated previously, the coalition does not oppose the broad range of this Bill; indeed, we support it. But we have very real concerns about the application of some of these clauses in the practical sense because we believe that they may result in the Bill not functioning to its full potential.

I would like to deal briefly with the aspect of the Bill pertaining to the mandatory reporting of suspected child abuse cases. This section will require court personnel, be they counsellors, welfare officers or registrars of the court, to notify immediately any suspected case of child sexual abuse. It could be argued that the introduction of a system of mandatory reporting may act as a deterrent. Experience in areas of jurisdiction involving mandatory reporting has shown that quite often groundless reports can be made and statements given which, with some very minor examination of issue, are proven to be worthless. It is certainly arguable that the introduction of mandatory reporting could discourage affected parties from seeking assistance from individuals such as court counsellors and that this would serve to inhibit the resolution of the dispute.

One of the major aspects of any counselling situation is that of confidentiality. To remove that appearance will obviously seriously hamper the counselling process and the ability of the professionals involved in this work to pursue their roles effectively. The Law Council of Australia has already expressed its opposition to mandatory reporting and to murky conditions contained in the current Bill, which differentiate between mandatory and discretionary reporting procedures. It has been suggested that a more appropriate course of action would be for the initial reports to be made to the court and not to the child welfare authorities. This would allow the Family Court judge to direct proceedings in the most fitting manner. Personally, I support this view and trust that our amendment will be successful. Clause 15 seeks to introduce a section to allow the admittance of hearsay evidence of statements made by children to adults about the abuse they have suffered or are alleged to have suffered. The entry into the area of hearsay evidence is dogged with potential problems. Once again, the Law Council of Australia has been quick to recognise these potential problems. When the Law Council undertook its report on child sexual abuse, it recognised the uncertain state in relation to the admittance of statements made by children outside the courtroom. There appears to be no uniformity in this regard. On some occasions courts have accepted such evidence, but this, as I have said before, is not always the case.

Whilst the Law Reform Commission has indicated that first hand hearsay evidence should not be excluded if it is the best option, the difficulty is in establishing what represents first hand hearsay evidence. Generally, it is regarded as a representation by a person who witnessed the facts referred to in their statement. There are also inherent difficulties, as the Commission indicated, in that it should be at the discretion of the court to reject such evidence if it was considered unfair that suitable notice had not been given to the other party.

The amendment Bill which we have before us differs significantly from the views of the Commission, and we are therefore obliged to move an amendment. Briefly, I will outline clause 14, which inserts a new section 92a which provides that, where allegations have been made that a child has been abused or is at risk of being abused, five categories of persons are allowed to intervene in the proceedings as of right. These are: a guardian of the child; a person entitled to the custody of the child; a person responsible for the daily care and control of the child; a prescribed child welfare authority; and a person who is alleged to have abused the child. This provision does not include persons who have been granted access to the child and has been drafted in different terms to the existing provisions of the Act.

In summary, I would like to acknowledge that the Family Law Amendment Bill is a bipartisan attempt to correct some of the anomalies within the existing Family Law Act, and the amendments proposed by the coalition attempt to clarify the points of confusion. The impetus for a review of the Family Law Act has now commenced. I know that this will be very heartening to many who have suffered profound emotional trauma as a result of their personal experiences with the Family Court. This is not to in any way lay blame at the feet of the Family Court but rather to concede that there are problems inherent within the current interpretation of the Act which must be addressed by the Parliament at a later date. We cannot allow another inquiry such as that which occurred in 1980, with little result. Ten years down the track we should learn in every possible way from our mistakes and address these matters in the short term rather than the long term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those senators who have contributed to the second reading debate of this most important Family Law Amendment Bill. I believe it is a most significant series of amendments which the Senate is considering this afternoon. I believe the seriousness with which the contributions have been made indicates that senators from all sides have deliberated long on the matters dealt with in the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The primary matter dealt with in this Bill is to do with those allegations of child abuse which can be made in the course of proceedings or in counselling sessions associated with the operations of the Family Law Court of Australia. Indeed, child abuse is a matter which is now recognised as one of great concern throughout the whole community. I notice Mr Kerry Berwick, former Mayor of Devonport, in the public gallery. He will know that the first occasion on which I had to perform a public duty as a senator in 1978 was when, on the north-west coast, I opened the first meeting, I think it was, of the Child Protection Assessment Board. Since that time, I have taken some interest in these matters-up to the reception of the report of the National Committee on Violence. That Committee published the horrifying fact that, if one looks at the age groups of the inhabitants of Australia and asks which age group is most vulnerable to being killed, that is, which age group is most likely to be murdered, the normal run of the mill reaction is to think in terms of young crims and thugs between 18 and 24, or the frail elderly who may be hit over the head by some intruder into their house. But the fact is that, overwhelmingly, the age group which is most at risk to homicide in Australia is those between birth and 12 months of age-twice as many per 100,000 as in the 18- to 24-year-old age group. That is the most extreme case of child abuse-the deprivation of life and of all the rightful expectations of the youngest and most vulnerable members of our community, those who have just been born up to those one year of age.

But there are many other forms of abuse, and these can become known to those who operate in the Family Court, either because parties make allegations to that effect or because the Court counsellors themselves or Court personnel become aware of the situation that is alleged and have reasonable grounds for suspecting that a child is being abused or is at risk of being abused. In that situation, the Government, after much consultation, has decided to clarify the law to make clear some of the areas of concern to Court counsellors and other Court personnel and, indeed, parties. The scheme proposed is that it be mandatory that a report be made when that reasonable suspicion of child abuse having occurred or being likely to occur has been aroused.

These amendments have been guided by the findings and recommendations made by the Family Law Council in its 1988 report on child sexual abuse. I believe it is important to have the foundation of that report as the underpinning of this particular Bill. The Family Court has, over the years, established its own procedures to try to deal on an administrative basis with child abuse allegations, but this particular provision for mandatory reporting will make clear the requirement of our society in dealing with this most difficult area and it will also to that extent, in making clear what the responsibilities of court personnel are, provide them with a degree of certainty and a degree of guaranteed legal protection which will enable them to more readily make these particular reports of their suspicions to the relevant and well-qualified State authorities.

In that regard, I believe it is important to recognise that it is the State welfare authorities, child welfare authorities and child protection authorities which have this expertise. There are many other groups in our society, and I too would like to acknowledge the work of Mrs Rosemary Sinclair in establishing in the public mind, through the national committee which she heads, the terrible incidence of child abuse in our society. But it is for the professionals, the child welfare authorities-without being unduly subservient to their expertise-which quite clearly are the ones which ought to have the prime carriage of investigating and dealing with these allegations once they are made.

To that extent, the Law Council suggestion that judges of the Family Court should vet allegations of abuse before they are sent to child welfare authorities seems to the Government not to be appropriate. The expertise for investigating these allegations lies with the State or Territory child welfare authorities, not the Family Court. The Chief Justice of the Family Court of Australia has indicated that he regards that process as being too cumbersome, and he would not seek it, that is for sure. I believe there might also be some delay in investigation of allegations of child abuse if this procedure put forward by the Law Council and apparently attractive to some members of the Opposition were adopted.

I believe there has been some modification of the Bill in the course of its passage through the other place which has made some concessions in line with suggestions made by the Opposition. For example, the mandatory reporting is to be limited to the more serious categories of abuse. I understand that in clause 4 of the Bill `abuse' is now defined to mean:
(a) an assault, including a sexual assault, of the child which is an offence under a law, written or unwritten, in force in the State or Territory in which the Act constituting the assault occurs; or

(b) a person involving the child in a sexual activity with that person or another person in which the child is used, directly or indirectly, as a sexual object by the first mentioned person or the other person, and where there is unequal power in the relationship between the child and the first-mentioned person.

I believe that that accords very much with the proposal put forward by the Opposition in another place as to the definition of what should count as child abuse when one is considering the obligation of mandatory reporting. Once again, there will be no criminal penalty for failure to report. Administrative procedures within the Family Court will deal with those Court personnel who do not carry out their obligation. They will be burdened with that duty of mandatory reporting only where they come across the allegation of abuse in the course of their duties, and not otherwise.

In trying to get the balance right, obviously this Parliament is being invited to tip the balance in favour of the reporting to relevant authorities so as to provide a chance for an abused child to be removed from that situation of abuse or prevent abuse from actually taking place.

Opposition members have raised some other matters on which I wish to comment, which may save time at the committee stage. As far as intervention in proceedings as of right is concerned, the Opposition has apparently proposed that a person with access rights to a child, or any person with an interest in the welfare of a child, ought to be able to intervene as of right. This amendment is not acceptable. The Family Law Council looked at those persons who might be permitted to intervene as of right and the Government has looked at that report as the basis for compiling the list in proposed section 92a.

One ought to emphasise that an access parent will have a right of intervention in his or her capacity as joint guardian of the child or as the alleged abuser, and that ought to be kept in mind. Other people who have an interest, who have access rights or are considered to have an interest in the child's welfare-for example, quite often grandparents and other relatives or neighbours think they have an interest-can persuade the court that they can usefully contribute to the proceedings and get leave of the court to make a contribution to the court's understanding of the situation. So it is not as though such people are to be excluded; they simply have to seek the leave of the court.

Only in recent weeks the United Kingdom Parliament has moved very urgently to clarify the question of hearsay evidence in that jurisdiction to overcome a recent decision by the Court of Appeal that there was no legal basis for admitting hearsay evidence of children in family law proceedings. That has certainly been the established practice of the Family Court of Australia. I believe it is one way of protecting children from the necessity of being drawn into court proceedings as a witness, being called by a party in a custody or access dispute.

In any case, the Government believes that, whereas the hearsay rule is normally applied in proceedings in courts in Australian jurisdictions because the judge should have regard only to those matters which parties can speak of from their own knowledge as they appear before him as the arbiter or umpire in the particular dispute, in the Family Court the judge is not in that position. He or she is charged with the paramount duty of protecting the interests of the child. The child is outside the conflict, if you like. It is thought that the rule against hearsay cannot in all circumstances be said to be required simply because a person dealing with a matter has the status of a judge.

I believe that I have dealt in passing with most of the concerns raised by Opposition members with the Family Law Amendment Bill, but I think they would concede that it has emerged from the other place with considerable alteration which meets, at least in some measure, their concerns. The Government was happy to adopt those modifications of the clauses.

Basically, I think that the public will be interested, as the Senate gives its support to the second reading of the Bill, that we as a parliament are dealing with the very real situation where court personnel become aware of child abuse, or allegations of child abuse. We have provided a mechanism which requires them to inform those personnel who can best protect the interests of the child, to try to remedy the situation or indeed to prevent it occurring. For that reason, and because of the many other important amendments which are made to the Act by way of the clauses of the Bill, I commend the second reading of the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

`(3) An order may be made by the court pursuant to this section upon such conditions as the court thinks fit.

`(4) Where a person intervenes in proceedings by leave of the court pursuant to this section, the person is, unless the court otherwise orders, to be taken to be a party to the proceedings with all the rights, duties and liabilities of a party.'.''.

The first amendment deals with mandatory or, in our preference, discretionary reporting. The second is simply consequential upon that amendment and the third concerns intervention and our preference in that regard. Mr Chairman, pressing your liberty for a moment, I wanted to mention one matter earlier, which I now seek to put on the record, concerning hearsay evidence. I said in my contribution to the second reading debate that we had a different point of view but we were not going to press it. There was one incidental matter to that which was our view that where the practice is adopted, which is now going to be codified, of a child reporting to a parent and a parent giving evidence in circumstances where it would not normally be acceptable evidence, the person about whom the allegation is being made in that form should be advised. We simply put that on the record in this instance. Perhaps it is something that Senator Brownhill's joint select committee that is being set up might also look at-presuming it comes within its terms of reference.

With regard to the two more substantial questions, I have put the argument for discretionary as opposed to mandatory reporting during my second reading contribution. There is nothing further I wish to add to that. We have had some discussion with the Australian Democrats and I understand that they are not with us. That is another reason why it is not worth holding up the Committee on the issue.

Regarding intervention, in my speech at the second reading stage I put the argument that a better procedure would be that leave be sought for appropriate parties to intervene. We see no shortcoming in our alternative. We see the advantage that it gives to the court-the discretion. As I indicated, we have added to the list two extra categories of persons possibly seeking to intervene-in particular a person who has been granted access to a child and any other person with an interest in the welfare of a child. Those people should be deemed as groups with an entitlement to seek leave to intervene. So our list is extended by the extra two categories. At this last moment I ask the Government to give the amendments due consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, in the short time available to it, has given due consideration to the amendments moved by the Opposition in this place. I think we dealt adequately at the second reading stage with the mandatory reporting of child abuse. The Government believes that mandatory reporting will give the best chance that an abused child will be removed from the situation of peril, where that child is so vulnerable to sexual or physical abuse, or enable a preventative strategy to be adopted so that the child does not find itself in that very perilous situation.

SPEECH.PARA: This will be a matter of reporting to competent and relevant authorities vested with the expertise to deal with the allegation. In relation to that, this mandatory reporting matter has been of concern to court personnel. I understand that the professional organisation-the ethical and standards committee of the Australian Psychologists Society-has said that the Bill is consistent with the Society's code of professional conduct. I believe it can now be undertaken in both a legal and professional sense without undue concern by court personnel who may become aware of these allegations and form a reasonable suspicion that there is some foundation to them.

As for the hearsay matter, which Senator Hill touched upon, it is important to note that in the House of Representatives an amendment was made to clause 12 so that 70ba (2)-I know Senator Hill is taking a great deal of interest in this matter-now reads that the party must file a notice in the prescribed form in the court hearing the proceedings and serve a true copy of the notice upon the person who is alleged to have abused the child or from whom the child is alleged to be at risk of abuse. I believe that would cover Senator Hill's concern at least to that extent.

I have already dealt with the matter of intervention rights in passing in my contribution to the second reading stage of this debate. I emphasise that persons in the categories which the Opposition sought to give a right to appear before the court can appear by way of leave of the court. They simply have to persuade the court that they can usefully contribute to the proceedings. I believe in many instances that can be done, but they ought not to have a right simply by falling into a category as vague as those who have an interest in the child's welfare.
I believe the Government cannot support any of the committee stage amendments put by the Opposition and I ask the Senate to adopt the Bill as put in the chamber by the Government.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

This first quarter of 1987 was a period of non-management. . . . . . gave advice, but had no power to direct . . . regarded his management responsibility for managed loans as being purely nominal, and the position continued to drift.
At the end of the first quarter of 1987, it was decided to formally transfer the management to the Westpac unit.

This decision was not implemented as quickly as was planned. This was partly due to stiff resistance from Westpac risk management, who doubtless feared they were being handed a can of worms, and partly due to a lack of drive on the part of PPL executives.
The management vaccuum thus remained in force until late June, 1987 when most contracts were terminated and five managed customers were transferred to Westpac risk management.
In short, managed forex loans was a bad idea, introduced at the worst possible time, and badly managed.
The dollar fared well from late 1986 to mid 1987, and given the management vaccuum, PPL was clearly lucky that it did.
In September, 1987, complaints made by managed borrowers had come to . . . attention and he asked . . . of . . . to look into the matter.
This led to . . . letter of 7th September, which is Attachment 3. The views expressed in this report and in that letter are substantially the same.
As a result of . . . letter, . . . was asked to direct an investigation into the matters raised in it.
SECTION C-MY CONCLUSIONS AND MY REASONS FOR THEM
C.1 CONCLUSIONS
1. According to PPL's own documents, PPL:
. told clients it would do a professional management job;
. told clients that it would adopt a conservative, `when in doubt, hedge' approach to risk management.
2. PPL's own documents acknowledge that:
. PPL did neither of these things; and
. this failure caused loss which would not otherwise have been incurred.
3. Trading conditions during the relevant period were such that all a prudent manager could have done is to have hedged and stayed hedged for the duration. This:
. was objectively what PPL should have done;
. would have been consistent with PPL's representations as to the policy it would adopt.
4. As a result of 1-3, a number of clients did significantly worse than the fully-hedged position.

5. PPL undoubtedly took points which, at best, exceeded its entitlement and to which, in my view, PPL had no entitlement at all. PPL probably switched transactions between its own account and its managed borrowers accounts.
6. The exemption clause in the Power of Attorney signed by managed borrowers will not operate to defeat actions which are available to those borrowers based on:
. point taking and deal switching;
. failure to follow the conservative management policy which PPL represented to clients it would follow.
7. As a result of 1-6, it is likely that managed borrowers would succeed against PPL.
8. The measure of damages will be:
. the amount lost via the taking of points;
. the profit lost via the switching of transactions;
. the difference between the fully-hedged position (plus, say, 20% to approximate the point at which clients should have been fully hedged) and the position actually achieved.
9. Clients will be slow to commence action because of:
. the breadth of the exclusion clause in the Power of Attorney will deter clients (who don't know of the deal switching and point taking and the damaging PPL documents) from commencing action;
. their lack of knowledge of how damaging PPL's documents are;
. the lack of success of OCL actions to date;
. the high costs involved

10. Given 9 and given full-time hands-on management by a suitable executive having total responsibility, suitably supported by state managers, it should be possible to keep liability at a manageable level.
C.2 REASONS FOR CONCLUSIONS
CONCLUSIONS 1 &2: THE ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS CONTAINED IN PPL'S OWN DOCUMENTS
I wrote to you on 22nd October and attached to that letter a collection of documents.
Many more documents have been examined and a number of them are very damaging.

I see little point in adding further documents to the bundle, however, because the documents attached to my letter of 22nd October illustrate the extraordinary extent to which PPL's own documents support the conclusions I have reached. The bundle is Attachment 2 to this letter.
All those reading this letter should read these documents-they are devastating.
CONCLUSION 3: TRADING CONDITIONS-THE OBLIGATION TO HEDGE
Between the beginning of 1985 and November this year, the Australian dollar depreciated:
. 53% against the Swiss franc;
. 32% against the $US;
. very significantly against virtually every other currency.
An inter-bank trader can have one of three postures with respect to any given currency:
1. long;
2. short; or
3. out of the market.
Importantly, when the inter-bank trader goes short or long, he is under no necessary added risk in doing so.
The risk manager is in a very different position:
. Firstly, he can't go out of the market-he is managing an offshore borrowing which is a fact of life;
. Secondly, if the loan is in currency A and the manager shorts that currency, his managed client is a double risk;

. Thirdly, if he keeps the managed loan hedged most of the time, the cost of the loan will equal (or perhaps slightly exceed) the cost of onshore borrowing. It is precisely to avoid these costs that clients have borrowed offshore and, regrettably, some of them would have had difficulties in servicing their loans at onshore rates;

. Fourthly, an inter-bank trader is aware that a certain level of buying and selling will tend to alter prices and can take this into account in his trading activities. A risk manager is not in a similarly fortunate position. If his clients are long a total of, say, $US100 million and he is going to close

There is an alternative view which asserts a market convention that a modest amount of points may be taken; the number of points being designed merely to recoup the costs of carrying out the transactions.
The PPL forex section made extensive use of a suspense account for significant periods of time.
The suspense account was used to `park':
. transactions which would otherwise have caused difficulties with Reserve Bank imposed limits;
. transactions before allocating them to a managed borrower or to PPL's account.

Transactions put into the suspense account were entered into suspense account books, which were kept for this purpose. These books have disappeared and an extremely diligent search has failed to find them.

The absence of these books greatly hinders the unravelling of transactions and this difficulty and the difficulty in establishing when, in the course of a day's trading, a particular transaction took place, have prevented us from quantifying the profits which PPL made from point taking.
Notwithstanding this, the following factors cause me to believe that a court would find that point taking occurred:
. the 6.4.87 memorandum from . . . which is part of Attachment 2;
. spot checks of deal slips and position sheets done at the direction of . . .;
. the extraordinary comparative profitability of PPL trading on its own account compared to its trading record for managed borrowers;
* the extraordinary trading volume which was otherwise at variance with PPL's represented management policy.
Deal Switching

The loss of the suspense books makes it impossible to form a firm view about deal switching. However, the position sheets disclose some transactions which would probably cause a court to infer that deal switching had gone on. I have interviewed a PPL employee whose first-hand observation was that some (albeit unquantifiable) deal switching did go on, and I think it probably did.
CONCLUSION 6: THE EXEMPTION CLAUSE WILL BE OF LITTLE ASSISTANCE IN THESE CIRCUMSTANCES

All managed borrowers signed a Power of Attorney which contained a widely drawn exemption clause. That exemption clause will defeat actions (both in contract and tort) based on a failure to exercise sufficient care and skill.

The High Court decision in Darlington Futures Ltd v. Delco Australia Pty. Ltd (68 ALR 385) makes it clear that, as a matter of construction, clauses of this sort will not be allowed to defeat claims based on point taking and deal switching, because these depend on allegations of deliberate dishonesty.

Even if, contrary to the view expressed above, the exemption clause was held to defeat a claim based in contract for point taking and deal switching, PPL would still face an identical claim based on breach of fiduciary duty.

In its Hospital Products decision (United States Surgical Corp. v. Hospital Products International Limited (156 CLR 41)), the High Court said that it was reluctant to introduce fiduciary duties into commercial relationships unless there was a genuine element of control by one party over the affairs of the other, with a consequent vulnerability of that party.

I have little doubt that a fiduciary duty existed here because of the total control which PPL had over the managed loan and the vulnerability of managed borrowers which resulted from this total control.
Liability for breaches of fiduciary duty cannot be contractually excluded because they are not based on contract.
Section 52 of the Trade Practices Act creates an obligation not to carry on business in a misleading fashion and this obligation cannot be contractually excluded.
PPL represented that it would keep clients fully hedged, except in advantageous situations, and failure to do this leads to a liability under the Act which cannot be contractually excluded.
CONCLUSION 7: MANAGED BORROWERS WOULD SUCCEED AGAINST PPL
This needs no expansion in the light of the discussion which has preceded it.
CONCLUSION 8: THE MEASURE OF DAMAGES

It will be obvious from my discussion of the difficulties of quantifying point taking and deal switching in Conclusion 6 that a court will face the same difficulties which I have faced and will probably not be able to make a precise calculation of the relevant loss/loss of profits.

This will not deter a court from doing rough and ready justice as best it can on the evidence available. This is clear from the long-established cases of Chaplin v. Hicks (1911) 2 KB 786 and Howe v. Teefy (1927) 27 SR (NSW) 301 and from the more recent decision of the Full Court of the Federal Court of Australia in Enzed Holdings Ltd &Ors. v. Wynthea Pty. Ltd &Ors (1984) 57 ALR 167.

The Enzed Holdings decision concerned calculation of damages for a breach of s.52 and it is thus authority for the proposition that a court will adopt a similarly robust approach to overcome any of the difficulties in determining precisely when hedging should or should not have taken place reviewed in my discussion of Conclusion 3.
CONCLUSION 9: CLIENTS WILL BE SLOW TO COMMENCE ACTION
The following factors will make clients slow to commence action:
. Breadth of the exclusion clause
For reasons discussed, the exclusion clause will not operate to defeat claims based on point taking and deal switching, but clients are unlikely to be aware that these breaches took place.

The exclusion clause will not defeat actions under the Trade Practices Act, but most clients will be unaware of how clearly PPL's oral representations are recorded in PPL's documents and will assume that proof that the representations were made will boil down to oath versus oath.
. Lack of Knowledge of the Damaging PPL documents

A number of management/personality/frustration factors which we have discussed led to PPL producing documents which were unusually selfcritical. Most organisations tend to produce documents which are unduly self-justifying. Most clients would not expect PPL's documents to provide them with the treasure trove which they in fact present.
. Lack of Success of OCL Actions to Date

Both reported OCL actions have gone against the borrower and one other was discontinued with considerable publicity. None of these actions involved managed OCLs but there is a tendency, nonetheless, for these results to act as a deterrent to action.
. The High Costs Involved
Many borrowers (particularly in these troubled times) are not flush with cash and they would doubtless perceive that PPL would defend proceedings grimly.
CONCLUSION 10: GIVEN SUITABLE MANAGEMENT, LIABILITY SHOULD BE CONTAINABLE TO A MANAGEABLE LEVEL
As I indicated in my discussion of Conclusion 4, the total extent to which managed clients' positions fell below fully hedged was $12.5m million.
This is not to say, of course, that clients will limit claims in this way; any client who brings action will probably base his claim on his total capital loss.
PPL can be reasonably confident, however, that a court would regard a comparison with the fully-hedged position as the appropriate starting point.

As discussed in reviewing Conclusion 8, a court would then reduce the difference between the fully hedged and actual position by an appropriate allowance (say, 20%) to reflect the fact that PPL was not operating with perfect hindsight.
This reduces the potential liability to approximately $10m, but with potential claimants affected by the matters discussed in reviewing Conclusion 9.
Shrewd exploitation of these difficulties, as discussed in the next section, should keep the loss to PPL at something like 30-50% of this potential liability, ie between $3m and $6m.

PERSONNEL
My recommendations are straightforward and are essentially those made in Section 3 of my letter of 22nd October.

You will recall that I recommended the appointment of a suitable executive to deal full-time with these managed loans. That executive should have full authority over these loans, subject only to direct reporting to . . .
That executive should be supported by the relevant PMOs in New South Wales and the state managers.

. that so far as managed loans are concerned, they are to report directly to the chosen executive;
. that managed loans are to be given the degree of priority determined by the chosen executive.
It is important that the above be implemented as quickly as possible.
STRATEGY
PPL's strategy should have the following key elements:

1. Keep close and cordial contact (with as productive a business relationship as possible) with all potential claimants. This must be done by the chosen executive and by the PMOs and state managers who have the personal contacts. . . . efforts in this regard in Adelaide have demonstrated just how effective this can be in keeping the lid on PPL's exposure. It is very important that the state managers in Brisbane and Perth be directed to spend all necessary time in keeping up these contacts and business relationships and to do so as a matter of priority;
2. Avoid litigation at any reasonable cost;
3. Bring borrowers onshore as quickly as possible;
4. Any concessions given to borrowers should only to be given in exchange for a complete release;

5. When particularly dangerous potential claimants come onshore, try and arrange this on the basis of a concession and a consequent release. My concern is that if these claimants come onshore without a concession, they may become bellicose once their reduced capital and higher interest rates start to bite.
6. Take all practical steps to avoid PPL's weaknesses being known outside PPL/Westpac boards and senior management.
Please don't hesitate to contact me if there is anything I can amplify.

Dear Warwick,
DOES PPL HAVE ANY CRIMINAL LIABILITY?
WESTPAC'S CONDUCT OF MANAGED OCLS
I refer to my conference with you and others on 26th November.
You asked me to write to you about some matters raised in that conference.
These matters come into two categories:
1. Two matters relating to PPL's position:
. whether PPL or its employees have been guilty of criminal conduct; and
. whether it would be prudent for PPL to attempt to make recompense to managed borrowers to reflect deal switching and point taking.
I deal with these questions in Section A.
2. Four matters relating to Westpac's current forex trading activities, and in particular, their handling of managed accounts.
I deal with these in Section B.
SECTION A-DOES PPL HAVE ANY CRIMINAL LIABILITY?
A.1 POINT TAKING
There are two features of the relationship between Westpac and the managed borrowers which, in my view, preclude criminal liability.
A.1.1 PPL sold currency to managed borrowers as principal
It was the very essence of the contractual relationship between PPL and its managed borrowers that PPL owned the overseas currency that managed borrowers would acquire from it.
The essence of all criminal offences involving dishonesty is the acquisition by A of B's property.
It is difficult, in the sale situation described, to categorise the sale of property from A to B as criminal merely because:
. that sale takes place at a profit to A;
. the better legal view is that there is no contractual justification for taking that profit.
A.1.2 PPL's broad discretion
Under Clause 1 of the Powers of Attorney, PPL was given total discretion in its right to sell currency to managed borrowers.
The width of PPL's contractual discretion is such as to create profound difficulties in categorising a sale made pursuant to the exercise of that discretion as criminal.
POINT TAKING SUMMARY
I adhere to the views expressed in my earlier letter as to the civil law problems created by PPL's point taking and deal switching.
These problems are civil. For the reasons given above, I see no question of criminal liability.
A.2 DEAL SWITCHING

A thorough review of all the relevant documents and the interviews described in my earlier letter failed to provide any basis upon which one could hope to convince a jury beyond reasonable doubt that deal switching had occurred.
As a matter of judgment, I believe that it probably did, but there is no basis upon which I, or a jury, could be satisfied beyond reasonable doubt.
A fortiori, there is no basis whatsoever for asserting deal switching with respect to any particular transaction or transactions, and this of course, is a sine qua non of any criminal liability.
It follows that the legal status of deal switching does not arise.
If the legal status of deal switching did arise, there are two factors which cause me to be confident that no criminal liability is involved.
A.2.1 PPL's broad discretion
I deal with this in A.1.2 above.
A.2.2 Difficulties in establishing allocation of currency to managed borrowers prior to suspense account entry
It is virtually impossible, when a suspense account is involved, to establish allocation prior to entry into the suspense account.
If this is not established, there is no prospect of criminal liability.
A.3 SHOULD PPL TRY TO RECOMPENSE FOR POINT TAKING AND DEAL SWITCHING?
A.3.1 Point Taking
My clear recommendation is `no'.
I say this for the following reasons:
i. There is no basis upon which we can establish what point taking took place with respect to what managed borrowers.
ii. Even if i. was not correct, any approach to managed borrowers would disclose a breach of contract which vitiates the exclusion clause in the Power of Attorney.
I strongly recommend that PPL reflect its proper concern about this in the relative generosity with which it approaches settlement discussions.
A.3.2 Deal Switching
As I indicated in A.2, there is no basis for making any assessment of any loss suffered by anyone as a result of deal switching.
There is thus no basis upon which recompense could be approached, and disclosure of this to managed borrowers would be even more serious than disclosure of point taking.
SECTION B-MATTERS RELATING TO CURRENT WESTPAC FOREX OPERATIONS
B.1 POINT TAKING
I confirm my advice that I doubt that Westpac could establish a contractual right to sell currency to managed borrowers at prices any higher than that available in a free market.
Given this, I think it unwise for any points to be taken unless there is a clear written agreement with the client which covers this.
It would obviously be unwise to approach the former PPL clients to seek this agreement, and it therefore follows that no points should be taken from former PPL clients.
B.2 ESTABLISHING THE MARKET PRICE BY SEEKING QUOTES

This is a related issue. Unless there is an agreement to the contrary, managed borrowers are entitled to buy at market price. This market price must be established by seeking quotes in the market and dealing with those offering the most favourable quote.
If that quote happens to be from Westpac, well and good, but Westpac must be able to establish that Westpac sought, and accepted, the most favourable quote.
A.3 ``PARKING''

PPL sometimes ``parked'' transactions in the suspense account in order to circumvent Reserve Bank limits. I have no reason to believe that Westpac is ``parking'' transactions for the same purpose. I stress that it is very important that it not do so.
B.4 CONSERVATIVE HEDGING POLICY
I am most concerned about recent losses suffered by the three former PPL managed borrowers during the recent slide of the $AUS against the CHF.
These borrowers were largely unhedged.
I think it important that the former PPL managed borrowers be kept fully hedged, unless and until there is a clear strategic appreciation of the $AUS against the relevant currency.
A fully hedged client may not like the interest rates, but he is suffering no losses and he can't sue.
A policy of ruthless conservatism is called for.
With best wishes,
Yours sincerely,
B. P. JONES

In reply to your memo of the 5th June 1987 on the above subject and further to our discussions I will formally answer the questions you raised, although as you are aware most of your questions, if not all, have been answered verbally.

. You stated you did not receive any reports on the above clients' positions between 7th May 1987 and 21st May 1987. Julie Cleary on the other hand has assured me they were sent and has cited South Australia as an example of an office which did receive most of their reports. I understand that subsequent enquiries found that some of the reports turned up in Western Australia and some have never surfaced.

. You stated that you repeatedly requested by telephone a copy of the report. In your memo you do not state who you asked although you implied that you asked me. At no stage did we discuss missing reports nor did anyone else contact me about the reports. The first time I became aware you were not receiving reports was at the time of receipt of your memo on the 5th June. Julie Cleary also did not receive a complaint about the lack of reports being provided to your office.
. ``Thomas Nominees received a [Tandem] report dated 27th May 1987 showing a debt/security rate of 81.68%.''

. While there certainly was a deterioration in the client's position the reason for the high security/debt ratio on that particular report compared with previous PC reports was that domestic loans to the client were also shown on the report and included in the ratio. Previously the PC reports had only shown offshore borrowings but in response to a number of requests from various PMO's, domestic loans were also included in the security/debt ratio on the new Tandem system.
. I understand from discussions with Elizabeth Wyse that the security mentioned in the report is not held against the domestic loan.

. You stated the situation was serious and that the position was out of your control as you were unable to monitor the daily position. I can only restate that if you had actually discussed the lack of reports with me I would have made sure you received the reports daily.
Answers to the specific questions raised in your memo are as follows:

1. The loans were not managed strictly on a pool basis (the agreement did not provide for a pool arrangement). While deals were approximately pro-rated in practice this entailed some rounding up or down depending on the situation. With the exception of Thomas Nominees No 1 the other security/debt ratios did not differ significantly from one loan to another during the period you mentioned. The reason for the change by 3.11% of the account ratio of Thomas Nominees No 1 appears to be due to an oversight whereby a decision was made to leave the loan unhedged at rollover with the intention of unhedging the other borrowers on the same day. Apparently the latter decision was deferred and the unhedged loan was forgotten. This resulted in a loss of USD57,423.02 (AUD79,291.66 at 0.7242) for the client. In view of the fact that we appear to have made an error it is appropriate that the client be reimbursed for the loss. This will be the subject of a separate paper to the Managing Director recommending the writing off of the loss by PPL.

Another reason for differences in the change of the security/debt ratio is that each client is dealt forward to their next rollover date. The rollover dates of loans rarely coincide, consequently when a decision if made to unhedge the borrowers a swap is done to the next rollover date. Consequently losses can not only be made through changes in the spot price but also through changes in the forward swap points. As clients' positions were individually hedged to their next rollover and these can differ from one client to the next by many months this can result in changes in the clients' relative positions.
You asked if the reports were checked the answer is yes although the client's ratio is not checked as it was always considered to be the roll of the PMO to review the ratio.

2a. At no stage was Westpac managing the clients' positions. All dealings were carried out between the client and PPL. From the time Haniff Abu Bakar left PPL, on the 24th March 1987, arrangements were made for Agnes Wong to advise Andy Fedas or myself of market trends and for her to inform us of strategies she was adopting for the Bank's clients. With the exception of a few occasions her advice, when offered, was always taken.

Arrangements were put in place when Andy Fedas resigned to second Agnes Wong and Neville Miles to PPL effective 18th May 1987. From that time Agnes and Neville managed the portfolio as employees of PPL. This was still the position up until the time of termination of the contracts by PPL on the 29th June 1987.
``The clients have not signed a new Power of Attorney''

This was due to the fact that the Bank's new pooled Power of Attorney was not ready immediately the decision was made to transfer the management from PPL to the Bank. In addition there was computer system constraints which had to be resolved and for a period of time personnel shortages.
``When will they receive one''
As soon as possible was the answer. This eventuated on about the 19th June 1987 and the 22nd June 1987.
``Will they be told PPL is not managing the facility anymore''
No, as the statement was not true up until the time of termination on the 29th June 1987.
``You assured me 6 weeks ago new Powers of Attorney would be in place shortly. Why aren't they?''

At that time the view was that a new Power of Attorney would be drawn up between the client and PPL permitting PPL to deal on the clients' behalf with the Bank. Subsequently the decision was made for PPL to step out of the roll of manager and for the Bank to offer clients an alternative service. This all took time plus the delays mentioned in 2b.
Comparison of John MacDonald with your clients' positions.

It is impossible to compare the results of the John MacDonald group with any other client as this group of clients were not always managed by PPL. The client took an active involvement in the management of the exposure sometimes to the client's benefit and sometimes with the opposite effect.
``Why wasn't I shown how it worked before it [the report] was sent to the client?''
You were sent a copy and explanation. Unfortunately this must have gone astray.
``Why didn't I get a copy to enable me to monitor the position?''
See 4a.
``How was Ms A Wong selected to manage PPL client loans? What are her qualifications and track record as an FX dealer? Is she going to meet the clients?''

Firstly she only assumed responsibility for the management of the loans on the 18th May when she was seconded to PPL. Secondly she performs this role for the Bank and has done so for the last year. She is well qualified for the position and has been involved in the foreign exchange market since 1983.
It is not intended for her to meet the clients although if clients do wish to discuss their position with her they can do so quarterly by appointment.
``If the losses are as significant as I have been advised, what steps have been taken to improve the level of professional service given to managed clients. Are we to continue the service?''

There was little we could do to improve the service in terms of improving the clients' positions. It is an extremely difficult product to manage particularly with the thin volume of trading which takes place in CHF in our time zone. In addition the US dollar traded against the thirds in a particular unpredictable way during the period as did the AUD.

My view has been that we should discontinue the service, Andy Fedas also had the same view as did Brian Eggert. This view was formally put to Bruce Fraser, Tony Snape and Ron Regan at a meeting in February this year. A similar recommendation was made by Brian Eggert late last year. Our recommendation was to terminate PPL's management agreements as soon as possible. Bruce Fraser and Tony Snape refused to accept this recommendation as they believe that PPL had an ongoing obligation to manage the clients' FX exposure.
``Is the Bank's position on daily trading as bad as the managed clients?''

One can not make a comparison for a number of factors such as; the client always has a short Swiss Franc position and it can only be left open or hedged. As such the client overall can not go long Swiss Franc, any short (unhedged) position will not accumulate cash profits, only a paper result, whereas a hedge position can create negative cash flows on which the client has to pay interest.
The Bank can deal in any currency not just the CHF/AUD cross, secondly it can be short, long or square.
``What steps are you taking to:
- ``provide PMO's with regular reports''
- The report can be accessed by the PMO off the Tandem computer.
- ``provide professional information to clients on a regular basis''
Monthly reports will be sent to clients in the new format of which you will now be aware.
- ``provide professional dealers to ensure losses, if any, are minimised''
In my view as well as others, Agnes Wong is a very professional dealer.
- ``provide PPL staff with necessary information when requested''

A new unit employing Julie Cleary and Jenny Chandler, reporting to Bruce Glover, has been set up to handle the administration work involved with the managed borrowers. They will continue to be the first point of reference for information on clients' positions etc.

You will be aware by now that responsibility for the product has now shifted to Agnes Wong and Neville Miles. Responsibility for the administration work has been taken up by Bruce Glover with Julie Cleary handling the day to day work.
Garth Carter
