TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Mr President, and other senators. I acknowledge the point being made by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Hill, that they are in fact lengthy documents and it is an unusual request that they be incorporated. I do not wish in any way to set a precedent, but I agree with him that they are of such public significance that under these circumstances their incorporation is justified.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is now acknowledged that here we are looking at a battle of mammoth proportions. It is a battle between ordinary Australians, in the circumstances in which they innocently find themselves, and a great corporate financial giant-in fact, Australia's largest private bank. The documents have been referred to, and are referred to within the documents themselves, as devastating. That is what has caused them to be a matter of such conjecture prior to this morning, when I think commonsense prevailed in the public interest.

The other evening on the adjournment I spoke at some length to the second set of documents, which are now referred to as the French letters or the Paris documents. In the process of doing so I made an incorrect statement which I would now like to correct for the benefit of the public record. Mr Stuart Fowler, the Managing Director of Westpac, quite rightly corrected me in his public statements this morning.

In discussing the significance of discovery as a part of the legal process, I cited two cases-Quade and Rhame. I said that they were cases of litigants in dispute with Westpac. I was wrong; they are cases of litigants in dispute with the Commonwealth Bank. However, the point I was actually making on the significance of documents and the discovery of documents in the process of litigation is still valid. They are in fact cases relating to Commonwealth Bank documents. Having corrected that for the public record, I offer apology to Westpac for that mistake. Presumably, the Commonwealth Bank is now embarrassed by the points I made on that occasion.

I want to refer briefly to comments passed by Mr Steve Martin, the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. This morning on the radio he made reference, I think probably unfortunately, to people coming out of the woodwork as a result of these Westpac documents having surfaced and getting on the band wagon of litigation.

As one who has been involved for 2 1/2 years in the process of revealing the circumstances of these people, and who has related to the borrowers association for the whole of that time, I think what is happening is that people are not so much coming out of the woodwork and getting on a band wagon, but rather are being encouraged. Their morale is up; they now see a possibility of success and the recovery of massive losses. I would like to put a different complexion on what is happening as a result of these documents coming into the public forum.

I would like to turn briefly to the first letters-the Belgian letters. The documents have been referred to in general terms as the Westpac letters but, of course, there will be more. So we are now having to differentiate between those that first arrived from Belgium and those that subsequently arrived from France. It has been claimed, by me and others, that these documents are potentially the most potent that have been before the Parliament for many years. They are confidential-absolutely private and confidential-correspondence between the law firm Allen Allen and Hemsley, the lawyers of Westpac, and Mr Warwick Kent, the Chief General Manager, Corporate and International Desk, Westpac.

There are two letters: one of 26 November, which in many respects is possibly the most significant; and one of 11 December. The document of 26 November is a disclosure to Westpac of the magnitude of its mismanagement and its undoubtedly-as will be subsequently proven-illegal and fraudulent actions in its handling of foreign currency loans. In the documents that I have tabled the names of individuals have been removed. That is not the issue at stake, even though the documents do apportion blame and actually attempt to sheet the blame home to three individuals. It has been suggested to me that there may be more than an element of scapegoating in that process. So the names of individuals have been removed.

The significant thing about the first three pages is that they emphasise how thorough Allen Allen and Hemsley has been. It has compiled 50,000 documents. Details of over 7,000 documents are in its computers, and the most significant 1,500 are readily available for reference. It has interviewed all of those involved in the field management of the process. It emphasises the fact that it has had absolute cooperation from those interviewed. In other words, the first three pages emphasise, `We have been thorough, and you had better believe what we are telling you, because it reflects the reality of what is out there'.

The documents then go on to summarise the performance in managed loans. That summary is very significant, and is now available for public perusal. It is worth noting that they really say that the whole process of offering these foreign loans, in the final analysis and with the benefit of hindsight, was a disaster. They say, for instance, that there can be no doubt that by early July 1986 all senior management of PPL, which is the subsidiary of Westpac, were only too well aware of the gravity of the situation of mismanagement. They use terms such as `non-management', `management vacuums' and `management by memos'. They say that, in short, management foreign exchange loans were a bad idea, introduced at the worst possible time and badly managed. They make reference to the fact that the first quarter of 1987 was a period of `nonmanagement'. These are the expressions used within the documents about the way in which this flawed product was not managed. Yet it is referred to officially as `managed foreign currency loans'. There is more than a touch of irony there.

They come to a series of conclusions, and those conclusions admit the fact that the bank breached fiduciary obligations-the fundamental obligation under law between banker and client. They admit to the fact that the relationship was breached. They admit that it failed to comply with the management parameters which it communicated to the public. In other words, it had created an image of certain things occurring, and it admits that that was not what happened internally. The documents attempt to identify those that were largely responsible for this disaster, and they actually name them. Whether or not that is a just allotment of blame, others will have to decide. And they attempt to identify the magnitude of the disaster.

In many respects the interesting aspect of this is that the documents go on to talk about damage control techniques. They go on to devise a strategy for minimising the impact of litigation. I have contended elsewhere, and I will contend yet again, that those strategies are in fact tantamount to aiding and abetting. They are tantamount to conspiracy to thwart the course of justice. In fact, the significance of the second of the letters is that it says, `Assuming that we are guilty, juries will never be able to find us so because the significant documents are missing'. The documents go on to say that it is highly unlikely that these litigants, or many of them, will be able to persevere long enough in the courts to be successful, because most of them are broken, not only financially but emotionally and in almost every other respect.
I will read what I consider to be the most damaging sentence in these documents. This is by Mr Jones, the principal legal adviser to the senior manager:
I wrote to you on 22 October-
1987, that is-
and attached to that letter a collection of documents.
Many more documents have been examined and a number of them are very damaging.

I see little point in adding further documents to the bundle, however, because the documents attached to my letter of 22 October illustrate the extraordinary extent to which PPL's own documents support the conclusions I have reached-
in other words, disaster, abandonment of fiduciary relations, et cetera-
The bundle is attachment 2 to this letter.
All of those reading this letter should read these documents-they are devastating.

I am quoting from the assessment that is made by Allen Allen and Hemsley about this massive evidence that the firm is referring to. It says that it is devastating. It is interesting to relate those comments to what I have said on the adjournment debate-that instructions have gone out to destroy and shred and conceal many of these devastating documents. Those two points have got to be related. I would like to turn, just briefly, to the last section of the first letter, under the heading `Strategy'. It says:
PPL's strategy should have the following key elements . . .

This is a strategy, I would suggest, to reduce and minimise the just outcomes of litigation. It is stated that PPL's strategy should be to keep a `close and cordial' relationship with those that might be litigants-butter them up. The letter continues:
Avoid litigation at any reasonable cost . . .
In other words, do not get into the courts if you can avoid it. Further it states:
Bring borrowers onshore as quickly as possible . . .
Any concessions given to borrowers should only be given in exchange for a complete release . . .

That is complete release from subsequent legal action. The strategy is to offer concessions-in other words, I would suggest, bribe borrowers by concessions, then get legal release in exchange for those concessions. The letter continues:
When particularly dangerous potential claimants come on shore, try and arrange this on the basis of a concession and a consequent release.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public interest I wish to raise does not have the glamour or excitement of the matter raised by Senator McLean. It should, however, be a matter that is of very great concern to this Parliament because it deals with actions of governments, and of this Government in particular, and it is something that this Parliament could do something about. Unlike the matter mentioned by Senator McLean, where legal remedies are available and law rights and courts are available to institute proceedings and recover moneys if the courts of our land find that wrongdoing has occurred, in this instance people cannot recover moneys because legally they have little in the way of rights.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite that it is a matter of some concern to me and to the people of north Queensland. It relates again to the town of Ravenshoe, which I have mentioned a number of times since I have been in the Senate and which colleagues of mine in the Senate from Queensland have also mentioned. It relates to matters that the Government has been very negligent in attending to.

There are three aspects that I want to raise today in the continuing saga of Ravenshoe. The first relates to just what happened to the $7m of taxpayers' money that was given by the Government to a mill in Ravenshoe for certain purposes. Secondly, I want to raise the matter of what is happening to the mill there. Thirdly, I want to raise the matter of money that is owing to business people in Ravenshoe.

All of these things are directly related to Government actions. All of these things have occurred initially through the World Heritage listing of the rainforests in the Ravenshoe area. There was never any argument that the rainforest should be protected. There was a lot of argument about where the boundaries should be and whether the drawing of those boundaries would ruin livelihoods, jobs and whole townships.

I have been attempting to find information about what has happened to the $7m of public moneys that have been alleged to have disappeared. It is very difficult to obtain information either from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) or from the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) or from their respective offices about what has happened to those moneys. I was, however, advised yesterday that a couple of weeks ago the matter of where those moneys were spent has been in fact referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions and to the Australian Federal Police for further investigation and, I understand, action.

It was announced back in October 1990 by the Minister, Mrs Kelly, that she was referring this matter to the Attorney-General for investigation and it has taken almost five months to get to the point where the matter is being referred to the police and to the Director of Public Prosecutions. It is of some real concern that it has taken so long. These investigations, I would hope, would show what happened to it-whether criminal activity was involved. If criminal activity was involved with taxpayers' moneys, then prosecutions, hopefully, will be brought at an early stage.

The whole incidence of the giving of this money and what happened to it has been a scandal as far as the Government has been concerned. It shows the absolute negligence and flimsiness with which the Government pursued or oversaw that money. I have been told by Ministers in statements and answers to questions that the Government did keep a supervisory role in seeing that that money was spent. In fact, one answer from the Minister said:

Like any good business manager the Commonwealth did not let its loan go unwatched. Officers of the Department regularly telephoned the manager of the mill to seek information on progress with the retooling. The mill was visited by representatives on several occasions. The Department's financial advisers on this issue also monitored operations of the mill.

That is what the Minister said. My information is that the supervision was very patchy in that the Commonwealth, contrary to its statement, did let its loan go unwatched. It was more than a loan; it was taxpayers' moneys given in a grant and some in a loan. Basically they were unwatched, they were not supervised at all, and the money has disappeared.

The retooling of the Ravenshoe mill cost in the order of $3.58m, and a grant was given by the Commonwealth to do that. But I have figures-they have been tabled in the Senate before-that show that the mill paid for that retooling out of its own resources. That begs the question of what happened to the government money that was given for that particular purpose. There are suggestions of impropriety in what did happen to that money. The Government certainly did not oversee it. My investigations have revealed that the Government did not then bother to ask the people who would most know what happened to the money, what moneys came in and what went out. It did not then and it has not since, after all of the times this has been raised. The more one investigates this, the more one becomes suspicious of just what did happen to the money, and the more one becomes convinced that the Government, in spite of its protestations to the contrary, has played no proper role at all in supervising this large payment of taxpayers' money.

Ravenshoe is only a very small town. The timber mill there has, as a result of World Heritage listing, been wound down. It has been propped up by the Government. The Government has, to its credit, attempted to do something with continuing grants; but the mill has reached a stage now where it has fallen further and further behind. The receiver has been in there for almost a year now and has been unable to run the mill profitably. The situation has now been reached where, unless the mill can be sold to an operator to keep it going, it will be sold piecemeal at a fire sale and will disappear from that town.

The town of Ravenshoe is only a small place. It achieves no recognition. There are no votes there. Ministers went there in its heyday, but since then they have kept well away. Minister Kelly did go through for a very brief trip, but there has been no real significance given to it. It has been brushed aside. I want to say to the Government that for as long as I am here I am going to keep raising this matter. It will not be able to brush it aside until some resolution is reached and some justice done there.

There have been a couple of applications to buy the mill, one by an Aboriginal community and one by a private sawmilling concern which involves business people in Ravenshoe. In both instances, though, substantial government moneys will be needed to assist the bid to buy the mill out. I know that these are before the Minister at the moment, and I can only urge upon the Minister that she make a decision at the very earliest time. The mill is running down. Each week another group of people is dismissed, and I understand that in a couple of weeks there will be only a couple of caretakers left there. The mill will cease operations and it will be very difficult, in those circumstances, to restart it. If the decision on the sale is left for more than a week then it may be impossible to restart it, even if the goodwill is there to do so.

I urge Mrs Kelly to make an immediate decision on that. I urge her to think wisely about it. There is a need for further government money, and whilst this does not always receive great support in these tough economic times I might point out that the assistance being sought is still much less than is left in the structural adjustment package which was specifically set aside for trying to do something about Ravenshoe. Even if it supports these applications, the Government will get out of this with much less expenditure than would have been the case if the original proposals for assistance had not proceeded. Although there will be a cost to the taxpayer, the cost is not going to be exorbitant. It is going to be less than was originally envisaged. But it must be decided soon, and I urge the Minister to think very carefully.

I think it is in not only in the Government's interest but in the interest in the town of Ravenshoe that the successful bidder for the mill be in a position to carry it on in a profitable way. It is essential that the successful operator have the expertise and the wherewithal to do this. I understand both applicants are in that situation. It is essential, though, that the purchaser have the marketing network and the ongoing financial resources to keep the mill operating, so that we do not have to keep revisiting Ravenshoe as the years go on. It is important that a decision be made, it is important that it be made wisely, and it is important that it be made soon.

The third aspect concerning the town of Ravenshoe relates to the money lost by a number of business people and contractors in Ravenshoe because the mill went into liquidation. As I mentioned earlier, one would say that if they have a claim for money owing to them they should take proceedings. They cannot in this instance because, as the company owing the money has gone into liquidation, the laws of the land do not permit such action. But why I always say the Government should step in-and I can justify saying it-is that that situation arose and those people in Ravenshoe advanced credit to the mill on the understanding that the Government was proceeding to support the mill for a 10-year period. The Government had announced that and it had given money on a regular basis. The Government had indicated that it was supervising its money, that it was keeping an eye on things.

The business people of Ravenshoe, quite rightly, expected that with that sort of government supervision and that commitment to further government support they would have no risk at all in a commercial sense in extending credit on a short term basis-on normal 30-day or 60-day credit terms-to the mill. Because they trusted the Government, because they believed what the Government had said, they gave that credit and have now suffered tremendously.

I have mentioned individual cases without naming them. But I again want to draw to the Senate's attention a couple of instances that were brought to my notice when I revisited Ravenshoe during the recess last week. One relates to an electrician, a good citizen of Ravenshoe, who extended credit to the mill on the strength of the Government's support. He has lost his whole business, his whole livelihood, his home there. He has lost the lot. He has lost his house and the family has had to move town, taking the kids out of school. I understand it is a very traumatic and sad experience for that family and it is an experience that is well known in Ravenshoe.

I visited another gentleman who had applied for assistance from the structural adjustment package but had been knocked back because it was said he had too many assets. Some other people in the same category did get some assistance but it is not adequate. This gentleman has some large earthmoving equipment-huge tractors worth $200,000 to $300,000 in their heyday-that would go in and get the logs out. They are now sitting idle. There is no market for them; they cannot be sold. This gentleman is a couple of weeks from bankruptcy as well.

I have asked the Minister to allow the applications for structural adjustment relief to be reopened and for people affected to be able to reapply. It is within the Government's power to do that, and I think it would be a good way to do it. But so far this request has fallen on deaf ears. When it comes to wharfies who are sacked there is no problem in finding government money to give them $100,000 or $200,000 redundancy payments. When these little business people, through no fault of their own but through government incompetence, are put in this position, there is a way that they could be helped through the system, but the Government ignores them. Obviously if they had been union members or wharfies or something they would have got the money thrown at them, but because they are small businessmen, really down to their last cent, the Government is not interested. I do now urge, and will continue to urge, the Government to do something about them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 February last the Senate resolved that there be laid on the table of the Senate on or before 5 March answers by three Ministers to questions which had been on notice for considerable periods in excess of the 30-day limit, together with an explanation for the delay in responding. Those answers were tabled by the respective Ministers on Tuesday last. I now wish to take the opportunity to comment briefly on the adequacy of the explanations given for the delay, because I do think it is time that we started to take the processes of the Senate more seriously than we have in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of answers were provided. I would like to deal with the answers tabled by Senator Bolkus in relation to two questions, the first of which was 97 days overdue and the second of which was 40 days overdue. Senator Bolkus-and I think in mitigation it can be said that Senator Bolkus was a captive of the Department of Mr Dawkins-says in his explanation:

I am assured by my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training that Questions on Notice are dealt with as expeditiously as possible within his Department, having regard, of course, to the need to provide comprehensive answers to honourable Senators' questions.

I do not regard that as anything more than saying that we have an obligation to answer questions. He really has not addressed himself to the issue of why there was such an inordinate delay in respect of these two. He goes on to say:

I note that, with regard to these Questions, each was asked towards the end of the last Sittings or early this year. Inevitably, there have been some administrative delays arising from the disruption to the Department's normal operations during December and January.

That is also pretty lame stuff. I trust that we are not going to be told that somehow the army of public servants advising the Minister are at their desks but not being paid or, alternatively, not at their desks and being paid. The fact of the matter is that there are staff available to attend to these matters at all times. One would have thought that the holiday period was relatively slack and would provide the perfect opportunity to have come up with the requisite answers, so I am not particularly impressed by that part of the explanation. Finally, the answer says:
The Minister has further assured me that he and his Department will continue to accord the highest priority to the requirements of the Parliament.

If we are going to have a continuation of the same, it is not good enough. I trust that what the Minister is saying is that in future his Department will accord the highest priority. I simply let the case rest in respect of those two answers and hope that the Minister will in fact be able to do better next time.

The next answer was tabled by Senator Cook on his own behalf. I must say that, in terms of relative culpability, Senator Cook was the least blameworthy and the most apologetic. His answer was a mere 40 days overdue. He said, in very humble terms:

At the outset I should state that I take my responsibility for answering questions on notice very seriously indeed. Processes are in place within my Department and my office to meet the deadline for answering questions set by the Senate, and in virtually all cases these work well.

Regrettably in this instance these processes failed, because of difficulty in assembling and clearing relevant data over the holiday period. My answer was provided to the Table Office on 22 February 1991.

That is no justification at all, because the resolution of the Senate was the day before. All that is really doing is admitting that once the balloon went up Senator Cook's office was able to deliver the goods within 24 hours. It clearly shows that if sufficient priority had been given to the matter it could have been provided a lot earlier. I say in general terms that Senator Cook does show a commendable acknowledgment of the importance of answering questions on time, and in effect pledges to do better in the future. On that basis, I am grateful for his response.

The final answers were provided by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) in respect of two questions, one of which was 47 days overdue and the second 35 days overdue. His explanations were as follows:

The preparation of the answer has taken longer than the 30 days set by the Senate because considerable time was required by the Department to establish the extent to which a detailed response could be provided.
Again, that is pure gobbledegook, saying that it took a long time because it took a long time. His second explanation was:
The provision of this answer took longer than 30 days because of the complex nature of the information.

Again, I would have thought that absolutely no valid explanation was put forward in either of those two comments to justify the delay that was taken. Indeed, any competent government could already have asked itself last year the very questions to which answers were being sought. The Minister refers to:
the complex nature of the information required; particularly, the tabulated material in answer to question 4 relating to the results of the 1989/90 review of overseas-born pensioners.

If there is any point in doing the survey in the first place, it is in order to obtain the very material that I was asking for. I hope the Minister is not saying that the taxpayer has been put to all this expense to collate information, but nothing is done about it until other senators decide that they want to know the answers to certain questions. I do not regard those explanations as adequate, and I hope that the fact that Senator Richardson has chosen to give only a very cursory explanation does not indicate that he will not be pledging to do it a lot better in the future.

I also wish to make brief mention of two other matters, one of which concerns Senator Richardson and the other Senator Button. During the August Estimates Committee hearings I submitted a question on notice to Committee C requesting all reports from consultants to the Department of Social Security. The request was not satisfied; the written response said simply that some reports provided by consultants are confidential. In the Committee of the Whole debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) on 13 November 1990, I again asked Senator Richardson for all the reports to the Department from consultants. The Minister replied:
. . . there is no reason why something that is not confidential cannot be made available, and it will be. I undertake to do so.

So far nothing has been forthcoming despite a number of requests from my office, most recently a letter of 5 March 1991. Again I say to the Senate that if we are to be able to conduct the business of this chamber in a proper manner it is necessary for Ministers to honour the obligations that they have, particularly where a gratuitous undertaking is given as it was by Senator Richardson on 13 November. So I again ask that that material be provided as expeditiously as possible.

Senator Button displayed a little more native cunning than others whose offices were contacted without satisfaction, because we have had a number of phone calls from Senator Button's office regarding two questions, Nos 318 and 363, explaining that answers were just around the corner and that if we could just be patient all would be well. Indeed, I had the pleasure of getting a letter from Senator Button to that effect.

Regrettably, those two questions, answers to which are 77 and 63 days overdue respectively, have still not been answered despite repeated requests to the Minister's office. I again take this public opportunity to say-and I hope that in government we will measure up to the standards we are now setting-that it really is not good enough to promise to comply but then ultimately not comply. It is probably worse in many respects because it wastes a lot of time on phone calls and raises a lot of expectations. So, having said that, I trust that from now on we will see a much higher standard of response and a higher degree of promptness. I am sure that Senator McMullan will have much joy in conveying those sentiments to the respective Ministers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, before I seek leave to move the motion that we suspend the sitting until 2 p.m., could I make one procedural point about the remarks Senator Alston has just made. It may be a matter that you and the President might want to consider, without lifting it to too high a plane of significance. Senator Alston has given notice of a motion about the matter which he just discussed. There was nothing untoward about what he said and I took no objection to it, but I wonder whether it is procedurally appropriate for the continuing use of the debate on matters of public interest for discussion of matters on the Notice Paper. I do not want to lift it to any higher plane than that, but I would appreciate some consideration of that. Having said that, I seek leave to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the sitting of the Senate be suspended until 2 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was alive to the matter that has been raised by Senator McMullan. I did in fact discuss it with others. It was thought that this was the more appropriate forum and I publicly indicate that I will not be seeking to pursue the motion which is on the Notice Paper. It seems to me that this is probably a more appropriate way of handling the matter anyway because otherwise it is dead time. So I think we are in heated agreement and I will leave it there.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. What action did the Government or the Minister instigate to prevent the closure of Australia's largest tin mine, located at Zeehan in Tasmania, because of the refusal of the Australian Workers Union, the Electrical Trades Union and the Australian Metal Workers Union to put the interests of the workers ahead of the interests of the union bosses? If the Government took no action, how does the Minister justify the Government's position to the 350 Tasmanians who have now lost their jobs? If the Government took action but failed, how does the Minister explain this further failure of the Government's disastrous industrial relations policy? What measures does the Government plan to take to provide alternative employment opportunities on the west coast of Tasmania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just heard, prior to coming in for Question Time, about the lay-offs that are projected for Renison Ltd on the west coast of Tasmania. It is in that context that I note the question and observe that, to my knowledge, Renison has not contacted the Government directly to ask for our involvement. That being the case, some of the assumptions in the question about our having a responsibility in these circumstances cannot be supported. Indeed, if what Senator Calvert said in his question were true, I would expect in the normal course, and quite reasonably, that Renison would have contacted us.

ANSWER.PARA: I might also say that if matters of industrial action are involved and if this is the reason-and I do not concede in this answer that it necessarily is-remedies for resolving industrial matters are available to the parties. In the case of Renison, that is either, depending upon whether it is a State or a Federal award, through the auspices of the Tasmanian Industrial Relations Commission or the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister in his answer indicated that he had not had any contact from the employers. Since this matter has been going on for quite a few weeks, why has not the Minister been contacted by the union bosses or been advised by his advisers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The terms of the supplementary question are quite mystifying. To the best of my knowledge, no union official has contacted me about these issues either, and that is not surprising. The Opposition has an interventionist mentality in industrial relations. It believes that every time there is a dispute the Government should stick its big frame in and mess up the possibilities of the parties being able to resolve the matter between themselves. In the event of an industrial dispute, if the parties cannot settle it between themselves, and the onus is on them in the first instance to do that, there is resort to an umpire. That umpire is the industrial relations system. It works well in this country and should be used in the event of the parties not being able to agree.

ANSWER.PARA: The element of the supplementary question which, frankly, I find mystifying is the intrinsic allegation that somehow or other my Department is advising union officials of what they should do in the conduct of a dispute. I think that is an extraordinary allegation to make and there is no foundation for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Is the Minister aware that Tasmanian dairy exporters have complained of cost increases of 25 per cent for the carriage of cheese to North America? How can the Government assist Tasmanian exporters to remain competitive in the North American markets?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answering this question, I would like to acknowledge the representations that I have received on this very serious problem from both Senator Sherry and Senator Archer. In fact, I had arranged meetings this afternoon with Senator Archer and, indeed, with Senator Sherry. I have some good news for them, so they can make up their minds whether they still want those meetings to go ahead.

ANSWER.PARA: A serious problem arose just recently with the withdrawal of cargo centralisation arrangements which resulted in an increase of $1,000 per container for people in Tasmania. In addition, freight rates have been increased by approximately $800 per container against a base freight rate of approximately $7,200-that is, an increase of about 25 per cent-which caused a very serious problem for the dairy producers.

Following representations from both Senator Sherry and Senator Archer, I raised this matter with the Australian Peak Shippers Association against the background of the part X provisions of the Trade Practices Act. Part X deals with liner shipping services and, in particular, empowers the Australian Peak Shippers Association, which is the designated peak shipper body, to require the shipping conferences to negotiate such cost increases and to justify them.

In response to the approach by the Australian Peak Shippers Association, the conferences concerned offered to reduce the freight rate by $1,000 per container during 1991 and waive the charge for the withdrawal of centralisation arrangements where the exporters use conference vessels when they call at Tasmanian ports. If Tasmanian dairy exporters can coordinate their shipments to take advantage of conference vessel calls, they will actually be paying $200 a container less than they paid in 1990. This should enhance the Tasmanian exporters' position in the North American market.

I am advised that the major Tasmanian dairy exporters, not surprisingly, have accepted the revised offer by the shipping conferences. I would urge all Australian liner exporters and their associations to consider joining the Australian Peak Shippers Association and thereby take advantage of the safeguards which the Government has provided in part X of the Trade Practices Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the recent Heinz company tomato fiasco. Is the Minister aware that this is the third year running that the union has created a dispute at the peak of the harvest? Is the Minister aware that this fiasco continued despite a recommendation by his umpire, the arbitration commission, for a return to work? How many working hours were lost? What was the total cost of this dispute? Does the Minister endorse the guerilla tactics adopted by the union against the producers and processors of yet another perishable product? If not, what support will the Government give to the tomato growers and Heinz to recover damages?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am, of course, aware of the regrettably long running dispute with Heinz in Victoria.
—Don't say `of course'. It is a surprise that you are aware of it.

—I am cut to the quick, Mr President-I have really been destroyed in full flight now! If that is the best Senator Vanstone can do, she should crank up her act. It may be of information to Senator Crane to know that this is a dispute which, I understand, is over awards covered by the State jurisdiction in Victoria, the Victorian commission, rather than by the Federal commission and is thus more appropriately a dispute commented upon by the Victorian Minister, not by me.

ANSWER.PARA: I am asked how much money has been lost. I assume that that question relates to the loss of operational earnings by Heinz, those affected as suppliers of Heinz and the workers involved in the dispute. I do not have that figure to hand. I will see whether there is a figure available.

I am asked whether I endorse the tactics of the union. In the case of this dispute, the position is the same as in the case of every other dispute. I believe that the unions and employers, if there be lockouts involved, should not avail themselves of action of this nature but should go to the commission and have the matter resolved there. That is the appropriate place. Opposition senators know that I am consistent in asserting that, and I would hope that they recognise that as the Government's position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. My question is: what action does the Government intend to take in terms of the continual abuse of the umpire in terms of recommendations that are made in these types of disputes, particularly when it applies to perishable products?

—I have already said that this is a matter in the jurisdiction of Victoria, not in the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth. Senator Crane is inviting me to comment on the proposition in his first question about whether or not action for recovery of damages should be taken. On that subject, if any of the parties feel aggrieved by this dispute, there are provisions within the legislation-and this is true of Victorian legislation as it is true of our own-for those parties to deal with the problem in order to bring about a settlement of the dispute and remove the issue in contention, and the parties should do that.
—What about damages?
—I know that Senator Alston is hooked on--
—Order!
—Senator Alston keeps interjecting.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The Minister is not answering the question. The supplementary question I asked was: what action does the Government intend to take to stop the continuing abuse of the recommendations that are being made by the umpire?
—Senator Cook, you should answer the question.
—I am answering the question, Mr President, and I am answering it directly.
—Don't argue with the umpire.
—Order! Senator Alston, you are not asking the question.

—This is the second shot at a supplementary question, and it seems we are getting supplementaries on supplementaries. The answer I was making before I was rudely interrupted by a vexatious point of order is that there are--

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Cook, in making that statement, has indeed reflected on your ruling and on you in saying that your ruling was in answer to a vexatious point of order, which you clearly did not consider it to be. I ask that Senator Cook be made to withdraw his inference.
—On the point of order: there is in no way any reflection on your ruling, Mr President. My understanding of your ruling was that there was not a point of order.
—My point of order was not that Senator Cook reflected upon the point of order but that he reflected upon you, Mr President, and your ruling.
—In reply to the point of order, I asked Senator Cook to answer the question. I believe that he was about to do that and I ask him to finish his answer.

—There are too many interjections. The Government does not see a need to take any special action in this case. The appropriate government to consider action, if there was any, such as bringing the parties together outside the jurisdiction of the Commission to see whether there were grounds for reconciliation that had not succeeded within the jurisdiction of the Commission, is the Victorian Government, not ours. Senator Crane's question was leading to a question of the exercise of tort or laws of that nature. In the case of that type of approach, it is not my view that that approach in fact brings about a speedy resolution to the dispute. In fact, it is my view that that type of action extends and compounds the dispute, involves other parties that are not involved and puts matters of complex industrial concern beyond easy resolution.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Government taken any recent initiatives in support of workers with children in the public service, particularly the Australian Public Service? Can the Minister please inform the Senate of any recent developments in the provision of work related child-care in the public sector in accordance with our responsibilities, having ratified International Labour Organisation Convention 156?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government has on many occasions demonstrated its commitment to assisting workers with family responsibilities to balance those responsibilities of their family and their working lives. One of the areas of particular concern to this Government has been to ensure the provision of accessible and good child-care. Last year the Government agreed to the introduction of work related childcare by public sector employees. These arrangements are part of the Government's goal to create 28,000 additional commercial and employer provided child-care places over the next five years, half of which are expected to be in the public sector.

ANSWER.PARA: The guidelines for child-care in the public sector have recently been clarified to ensure their full effectiveness. Under our policy, individual departments and agencies are responsible for determining what child-care arrangements will best suit their individual circumstances. As far as possible, agencies have been placed on the same footing as private sector employers by being allowed to subsidise child-care, if they choose to, from within their own budget, but without budget supplementation. A number of agencies are now investigating the possibility of sponsoring child-care for their employees.

A good example of where agencies are moving ahead with child-care is in the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). It has appointed a full time officer to handle its child-care implementation. The Australian Taxation Office has been investigating child-care since 1989 and has agreed informally with unions to five centre priorities in New South Wales and Victoria. The ATO has been operating a holiday care program in the Dandenong office since 1989 and is investigating other options such as joint ventures.

In addition to all of that, there are investigations being carried out by departments and a number of statutory authorities and government business enterprises to actively develop work related child-care programs for themselves. For example, the new Australian Broadcasting Corporation buildings at Ultimo and Melbourne are expected to have provision for child-care. OTC is part of a joint facility in inner Sydney. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is establishing facilities at Black Mountain and North Ryde.

In conclusion, the issue of work related child-care in the Australian Public Service will undoubtedly be discussed at tomorrow's International Women's Day conference on women in the Australian Public Service. I look forward to hearing the views that arise from that conference, because I do think that they will be an important contribution to this subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer the Minister to his response to my question on 12 December last year in which he said that he would not be providing any additional support for voluntary welfare organisations despite the unprecedented increase in the number of people seeking help from such organisations. I also refer the Minister to an article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 5 March entitled `More need than cash in South Australia', in which South Australian welfare agencies reported that they were turning away more people than they were assisting because the incredible demand for financial help exceeded their resources. I ask: does the Minister acknowledge that the evidence from agencies such as those quoted in the Advertiser indicates that there are increasing numbers of Australians falling through the so-called welfare net for longer periods? Secondly, does the Minister acknowledge that the significant rise in unemployment is causing a great increase in demand for welfare agency services? Thirdly, where does the Minister suggest these people obtain help and assistance if such last resort agencies are not able to provide it? Finally, in view of the great demand on welfare agency services and the fact that they are unable to meet such demand, I ask the Minister again: if welfare agencies request assistance from the Government, is the Government willing to change its mind and provide additional financial support to them to enable them to cope with the human consequences of this recession?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a long question, and I think that I have got down some parts of it. I understand that in the first part of the question I am asked: does the fact that voluntary agencies in South Australia have reported increasing numbers visiting their premises mean that more people are falling through the social security net? I think the phrase that Senator Lees used was something similar to that.

ANSWER.PARA: Firstly, there is no question that unemployment has been increasing. I have been asked that question in this place quite a number of times and have said so. I do not believe, however, that that means an increasing number of people fall through the net. It is a pretty comprehensive social security net as it stands. It is available for those who are unemployed and, quite obviously, looking at the increased numbers of those on unemployment benefits, it is a net that people are increasingly using. Of course, that does not mean that those who are given the benefits of that social security net are necessarily living on a bed of roses. Clearly, many of them-particularly those thrown out of work in recent times-are in debt and are having--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell those people living on their capital.

—That is a different question; I am trying to answer Senator Lees. Those people, particularly those who find themselves in debt and the unemployed, who are receiving a significant cut in their income will find life very difficult. Many of them have turned to welfare agencies. That is the role which welfare agencies have always fulfilled. In every developed country in the world those welfare agencies are there for that very purpose. If one were to go to the United Kingdom or the United States at the moment, one would find them in much greater use than they are here. With the significant rise in unemployment and people being turned away from these welfare agencies, where will they go? Those who are finding themselves unemployed, those Australians without work, are able to avail themselves of the social security net. I hope that they will continue to do so.
—How big are the holes in the net?

—There would not be a hole big enough for Senator Walters to fall through. I hope that we can arrive at a position pretty soon where those numbers will not continue to rise so the call on the system will not get any greater.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot pretend to Senator Lees that people who are becoming unemployed will not be going through hardship. Quite obviously many of them will, and that is something that no-one in this country can be happy about.

Will I do anything about a request from welfare agencies if I were to receive one? I certainly think if the welfare agencies come to me and quantify what they consider a need to be, I would be more than happy to talk with the Prime Minister and the Treasurer about the possibility of meeting that need. Quite obviously we would not simply turn our backs on them, not give them a hearing, and then not consider what they put to us. But, as yet-I cannot speak for my colleagues Mr Howe and Mr Staples-I am not certain whether welfare agencies have made requests of them. So far I have not had any requests for increases in welfare assistance along the lines that Senator Lees has suggested.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support advise the Senate of progress made in proceedings this morning in the Industrial Relations Commission in the Conaust enterprise agreement case?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to advise the Senate that following proceedings in the Industrial Relations Commission today the parties to the Container Terminals Australia Ltd (CTAL) agreement in Sydney-that is, Conaust and the Waterside Workers Federation (WWF)-have reached agreement in principle for the agreement at CTAL in Sydney. The parties, again by agreement, have established a working group and have given a commitment that they will tie up outstanding details of the agreement, the final drafting of the agreement, by the end of this month and will transmit that to the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority which has to approve the final agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: The significance of the proceedings in the Industrial Relations Commission this morning is that the resolution of this agreement in Sydney paves the way for resolution of the outstanding issues in a large number of Conaust enterprise agreements in ports around Australia, including Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Fremantle, Adelaide and my home port of Darwin. This will significantly increase the momentum of waterfront reform.

For the advice of the Senate, on Sunday 374 workers will leave the National Terminals company, a further 64 workers will leave the company at the end of this month, and 13 workers have already left employment in the port of Cairns.

This process was done by agreement. I stress that it was done not by the arbitration proceedings in the Commission but by the conciliation processes of the Commission in two meetings, and was reached by agreement of the parties. That is important in terms of the extraordinarily negative and damaging non-stop attacks that are continuing to be made by the Opposition on the union, the Waterside Workers Federation, in this process.

I would just like to correct the record because it is important to do so. The shadow Minister for shipping and waterfront reform, John Sharp, has concluded what is so far an unbroken record in issuing public statements that contain factual nonsense in his latest effort. It is important to correct the record.
Mr Sharp issued a press release last night once again attacking the WWF, predicting that the proceedings in the Commission today would be a disaster because the WWF would not agree. He said:
Conaust had to go outside the Government's waterfront reform process in order to get results . . .
In the final paragraph, he stated:
The AIRC direction is a significant step-
that is the only accurate thing he said-
taken quite outside the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority ambit.

It is entirely within the process. This is the document, the in principle agreement, that lays out the detail of the process. Mr Sharp really has no excuse for his ignorance because the provisions for the involvement of the Commission are found on page one of the agreement.

In conclusion, the Commonwealth intervened in these proceedings before the Commission to assist the parties in reaching this resolution. We urge them again-I know them; they will-to achieve a speedy end to the final drafting processes that they have agreed on in the Commission today. Captain Richard Setchell has applauded the agreement as being a very significant step towards reform of the waterfront. The reason I say that is that when this process is successfully concluded it will not be due to any of the efforts of John Sharp or indeed me; it will be due entirely to the commitment of the parties to deliver the commitments they gave to the reform process at the beginning of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and follows the rather surprising answer he gave to Senator Calvert about the tragic industrial relations situation in Tasmania and in particular his apparent conversion of a non-interventionist approach to industrial relations. I ask the Minister: did he not support intervention by an outside party in the SPC dispute; namely, Trades Hall? For the benefit of Australian industry, will he now clarify and give some guidelines as to whether he will support intervention and whether he will not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question is based on absolute fiction. I never supported any intervention in the SPC dispute by an outside party.

ANSWER.PARA: Members of the Opposition seem to be labouring under an illusion about what operates in industrial relations, which is not at all surprising because of their abysmal ignorance of what industrial relations law and practice is all about. The case of SPC has been resolved through the Industrial Relations Commission with the participation of the unions without a reduction or an alteration in any award prescribed rate or condition, save one, which the parties have agreed on; that is, to end the practice of paying wages in the pay packet and agree to a practice of paying them by electronic funds transfer. That is the only alteration to the award that has occurred and it is a standard alteration in award restructuring.

TALK.START.PARA: —Trades Hall. You said it had to be involved.

—The interjection, abysmally put in terms of knowledge, is that the Victorian Trades Hall Council had a role in this. SPC is an employer which employs workers covered by more than one union. Where that is the case, the Trades Hall or the regional Trades and Labour Council is the place at which the collective view of all of those unions is sorted out and dealt with when one employer is seeking one answer from the lot and the same answer from all of them. That is a quite legitimate role. SPC was pleased to be able to have a one stop shop in which it could discuss all of its issues with the unions concerned. So there is no illegitimate role in that case.

ANSWER.PARA: What is being tried on here is a view that the union movement has no right in dealing with these matters. That is a fiction that is believed in the Opposition, propagated by a few right wing journalists in this country, but it is not the practice anywhere and is not believed by the wider community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that there is a right of intervention if there is more than one union on the shop floor, otherwise he is advocating that he is opposed to intervention?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not saying that at all, and I wish that Senator Hill, as a lawyer who claims to be knowledgeable about the law, would learn a bit about industrial relations law. What I am saying is that, where an employer wants an answer from a collective group of unions, those unions are convened, in order to find their collective view, by the central council-in this case, the Trades and Labour Council. If it is a national case, it is the Australian Council of Trade Unions. That is what happened on this occasion, and it suits the convenience of the unions and the employers that that occur.

ANSWER.PARA: That is not intervention. That is not outside participation in the dispute. That is consistent with how the industrial relations model works. In this case, I underline yet again, because clearly the message is not understood, the SPC case was settled by agreement between all the parties after it was conciliated on by Commissioner Donaldson of the Industrial Relations Commission over the Christmas period, and the workers at SPC voted for that package and strongly supported it. That is a package which settles the issues in that plant, and I am pleased to see that that plant since then has been enjoying better levels of productivity than it otherwise might have done.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Would the Minister advise what the Government is doing to achieve more national consistency in Australian schools and what level of support the community is offering for this initiative?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Aulich's question is in two parts. The first part goes very much to what the Government is doing on the issue and the second part goes to the level of community support for it.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has recognised the importance of this particular issue and is acting in a cooperative manner with the States and the community in order to address the important issue at hand. It is a national effort to strengthen Australian schools which is what we are all about. The effort that we are involved with builds on a foundation set in April 1989-very much the Government's initiative which led to the issuing of the historic Hobart declaration on schooling.

As part of our record in achieving national cooperation in this area we have made some landmark achievements towards it. In fact, in respect to the problem we have been able to commission and obtain the first ever annual national report on schools. We have also recognised the importance of curriculum development in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —We cannot hear a word you are saying. Is it worth hearing?
—Senator Bishop makes the point that she cannot hear a word I am saying. If she was not being harassed by the noise from those around her, she would not have a problem and nor would anyone else.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point is the recognition of the importance of curriculum development. To that extent we have made achievements in five areas: mathematics, English literature, science and technology, society, and the environment.

I just digress for a moment from the answer I was going to give. I think it is an important issue that we are talking about today, and the fact that the Opposition seems to be babbling on while I am giving this answer is a very clear indication of the disrespect it has not only for this Parliament but also for the issue at hand. Mr President, the Government also--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. The remarks from this side of the House were entirely meant to be helpful. The Minister does indeed have a tendency to be the Minister for mumbling. We have heard one or two others take lessons from him. It was meant in good faith. It would be helpful if we could readjust his microphone, if he is unable to speak into it more directly.
—There is no point of order. If people are having difficulty hearing the Minister--
—I could hear him. Who wants to swap?
—I point out to Senator Crichton-Browne that all interjections are disorderly and they should cease. I call the Minister.
—Thank you, Mr President. I do make the point that the last person Senator Bishop was helpful to was Senator Puplick, and we have not seen him for a while.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me go on. The Government, also within the spirit of national cooperation and achievement with the States, has recognised the importance of moving towards flexibility in recognition of handwriting styles as well. However, the focal point that we have achieved is the establishment of the national curriculum collaboration in Australia. We have also recognised and launched the national project on the quality of teaching and learning. As I say, that is the record so far. There is also currently in operation involvement and commitment by the Government in this area, particularly in the post-compulsory education and training area, where we have, with the States, looked at new targets for national participation rates and how to go about achieving them.

I did mention at the start, and I think Senator Aulich also in his question asked for, an indication of the sort of community support that the Government has achieved for this important initiative. We recognised, when we took the initiative some three years ago, when the policy statement on strengthening Australian schools was released, that we did so in the knowledge that there was widespread dissatisfaction with the focus and content of Australian schooling. We are continuing to operate and I think we now have been able to achieve greater cooperation and support from not only parents, teachers and community leaders but also the business community.
I would on this particular point like to quote comments from a speech on 20 February to the National Press Club by Mr Brian Loton, President of the Business Council of Australia. He said:
If we truly believe that Australia's future depends on becoming competitive, one of the first things which must surely be set right is the education system.
In looking at how to create the right approach, I think Mr Loton shared--

TALK.START.PARA: —This is becoming a very long answer, Senator Bolkus.

—It may very well be, but the second part of Senator Aulich's question went very much to the level of support in the community for our initiative. What I am doing, adequately, is to go to that. As I said, Mr Brian Loton made those comments. In his speech he mentioned a number of clear goals that need to be set in terms of the education system-all goals which are being addressed by the Government. Also in his speech he recognised the vital role of reforming education in rebuilding Australia's competitiveness. The Government has been committed to achieving national goals in this area. We have delivered on our commitment and we continue to do so.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer--

QUESTION.PARA: Government senators-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that you are excited that it is on Burke. Yes, it is on Mr Burke, yet again. I am pleased you are all excited.
—Order! Ask the question, Senator Knowles.

—I refer to the acknowledgment by Brian Burke since his return that the Australian Labor Party in Western Australia employed the now convicted phone tapper, Robert Smith, to collect information on Liberal Party politicians. As the Minister should be concerned with the question of whether Brian Burke is a fit and proper person to hold the high office of ambassador, has he clarified with Ambassador Burke what instructions Mr Burke gave Robert Smith? Is he satisfied that the work done by Smith for then Premier Burke was not illegal or improper?
—These are all questions that will be addressed and presumably resolved by the royal commission, and I certainly do not want to pre-empt the deliberations of that body.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I ask the question again because surely the Foreign Minister should be responsible for ambassadors that he has appointed to ambassadorial posts. Is the Minister saying that he does not care whether a person is a fit and proper person to hold that post, and is he going to establish whether or not Brian Burke did give instructions to Robert Smith and whether those instructions were for something illegal or improper?
—I do care about that question, but that is a matter on which my judgment will now appropriately be guided by the deliberations and outcome of the royal commission.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Claims have been made by a United States energy expert that Australia has made an empty promise to cut down emissions of greenhouse gases. Can the Minister comment on this claim and advise what action the Federal Government has taken to achieve the aim of a cut in carbon dioxide emissions by 20 per cent by the year 2010?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw those claims from the United States expert. They were apparently made after he had spoken to a number of State power authorities and was looking at some of the plans that they had for the next 20 years. Of course, not all of those plans represent anything definite and are subject to the discussions that will be held between the Commonwealth and the States, so the promise will not be an empty promise but can be given full meaning to.

ANSWER.PARA: In October of last year the Government adopted an interim planning target to stabilise by the year 2000 emissions of greenhouse gases not controlled by the Montreal protocol on ozone depleting substances, based on 1988 levels, and reduce these emissions by 20 per cent by the year 2005, the most progressive policy, I might say, of any nation in combating the threat of greenhouse climate change.

An important element of the Government's decision on the target is the initiation of a national greenhouse response strategy. The Government's commitment to tackling the greenhouse threat is clearly demonstrated in its announcement of an initial package to reduce emissions under this national greenhouse response strategy within a fortnight of the decision to adopt the interim planning target. This package includes the development of an energy conservation information kit, which will be distributed to every household in Australia. Energy efficiency in residential and commercial buildings will be promoted through demonstration programs and the development of building codes. The Commonwealth itself will lead by way of example in upgrading energy management in its own operations. This program is estimated to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 14.2 million tonnes each year. The ecologically sustainable development working groups are in the process of examining options for achieving the target to reduce emissions cost effectively.

In addition to energy efficiency and conservation measures, the working groups are looking at the use of solar, wind and other renewable sources of energy so that we can reduce our dependence on fossil fuels. I did agree with the expert's statement that we could do much more by using our incredible resource, namely the sun, which Australia seems to get more of than many other nations. In addition, the Government has directed the Industry Commission to perform an inquiry to examine ways in which industry can achieve greenhouse gas emission reductions consistent with the target. The Government is also supporting a number of research projects on energy production and usage technology as well as the potential of sinks to reduce net emissions. The Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology has carried out an extensive inquiry. Its report, released in January, has made a number of helpful recommendations on ways that we might reduce emissions. All that would lead us to believe that, far from being an empty promise, it is one which the Government takes seriously and is well on the way to implementing.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a former distinguished senator, Sir Robert Cotton, who is here with a group of young political leaders in an exchange program from the Soviet Union. On behalf of all honourable senators I welcome him and the delegation to the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and relates to the Burkegate cover-up. Has the Minister noted the views of the Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives, Ron Edwards, as expressed on both the 7.30 Report last Thursday and in the 2 March issue of the West Australian, wherein he compared the use of a private detective by former Premier Brian Burke to gather information on his political opponents with the Watergate scandal? Does the Minister agree with his colleague, Mr Edwards, when Mr Edwards says that the Minister should examine the appropriateness of Mr Burke's appointment as Ambassador to Ireland.
—I have noted the views of Mr Edwards in this respect. They have not altered my views, which are those I have just conveyed to Senator Knowles in response to the previous question.

—I address a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Is it a fact that, contrary to the outburst by the honourable senator in the chamber yesterday, there is no continuity in payment for Austudy but rather payments are backdated and that in 1991 the minimum period for students to survive without any income support was 9 days, and that was for people with access to bank accounts on a Saturday? Is the Minister aware that some students who applied for Austudy in November and December 1990 are still awaiting payment and that in 1990 students who were eligible for Austudy were without any income support for up to four months between consecutive years of study? Is the Minister also aware that, according to an internal document of the Department of Social Security dated 19 February 1991, that Department has identified many students who face acute financial crisis until payment of Austudy in the new academic year? Is the Minister concerned that the Department of Social Security has turned away students, refusing them any income support on the basis that they are eligible for Austudy, and then referred those students to welfare relief agencies? What will the Minister do to provide continuing and intending students with financial support before the start of the academic year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the basis of the information supplied to me and provided to the Senate yesterday, the answer to the first part of the question is no. In respect of those students who applied in November and in December last year and are waiting, I made mention of the fact yesterday that the Government has set, through the centres involved, goals for achieving turnarounds for applications for Austudy. Those goals have been surpassed by a pretty impressive percentage amount. Those goals provide for a turnaround within 21 days.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know, and nor would I be expected to know, of the internal document of the Department of Social Security. However, I said yesterday-and I repeat today-that if there are students with financial difficulties and for whom there is financial urgency, then there is the capacity for payment through counter cheques at the access centres. I recommend that process, which is obviously there to ensure that the sorts of people whom Senator Bell is concerned about have their needs met. If there is a specific case, Senator Bell should put that to me, preferably by correspondence. I am sure he has a supplementary question. I hope I will be able to answer that as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I can certainly satisfy the Minister; I have a supplementary question. I think that the Minister said that there were goals which had been met by the Department. I heard him describe the goals yesterday as being a response within a certain number of days. My question is: does that response include payment or is it merely an acknowledgment of the application? What use is the goal if it is only to respond but not make a payment?

—The usefulness of the goal is to ensure that about 80 per cent of applicants receive initial response to an application within 21 days. In terms of the payment, the important part of my response yesterday was that there is capacity for those in financial urgency to have that need met in a very quick and direct way with the over-the-counter cheque facility. When we are talking about an 80 per cent or a 90 per cent achievement of a 21 days response to applications, some people do not have those applications responded to within that period. There are obviously reasons for that which go to aspects such as valuation, processing and a checking out. However, I go back to the point I mentioned earlier: for those in dire financial need there is a very quick and direct facility.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health give an assurance that the new Medicare card to be introduced this May will not have to be presented at a pharmacy now or at any time in the future in order to qualify for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme? Can the Minister also advise why an issue number will now be printed on the Medicare card in addition to an ordinary Medicare number and expiry date and what information will be incorporated on that new number?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall that Senator Boswell asked some questions along these lines before Christmas. It has to be recognised that the Government decided that the Medicare card should play a role in relation to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme as a result largely of indications from the Auditor-General's reports that that particular scheme was subject to fraudulent activity and that there needed to be a method of ensuring that those who took the benefits of the scheme were entitled to the very considerable subsidies offered to other Australians through the tax system to enable them to have access to drugs which are prescribed for them at a reasonable cost.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the question of the presentation of a Medicare card, I think I also emphasised before Christmas that in a sense this is more for the protection of the pharmacist, the dispensing chemist, than for the person presenting the prescription for it to be filled. In other words, the pharmacist has to make a judgment as to whether the person is well enough known to him or her to enable the pharmacist to take the risk in relation to dispensing the medicine at a particular rate of benefit; in other words, at a particular rate of subsidy. The pharmacist then seeks to be reimbursed. It is the dispensing pharmacist who needs to satisfy himself or herself that the person claiming the concession is eligible for it. That is to ensure that the pharmacist is reimbursed under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

As I think I also pointed out before Christmas, most local pharmacists have a very good working knowledge of the range of pensioners or other persons entitled to a benefit who come regularly to their pharmacies. There will be no need for a special check in that particular instance. The reissued Medicare card will be a convenient way for pharmacists to establish their customers' eligibility for concessional pharmaceuticals if they are in any doubt. It will not be compulsory to use a Medicare card if people can satisfy their pharmacist of their identify or eligibility in some other way.

Senator Boswell asked about the issue number and made it appear that that was a new requirement of the reissued Medicare cards. Just before coming into the Senate for Question Time, I looked at the Medicare card of a member of my staff. The current Medicare cards have the issue number on them. There are three blocks of numbers on the current Medicare card. The final single numeral on the card-in this case, in the name of the member of my staff-indicates whether this is the fourth time on which the Medicare card has been issued, as opposed to the third time. The reason for that is that if it is alleged that the card has been stolen or lost, that fact is punched into the computer alongside the issue number of the card. If that card is presented and the issue number comes up-for example No. 3, lost or stolen-it would be clear that a person without an entitlement to present that card has been making or attempting to make use of it. So, the issue number is already on the Medicare card. It is a very important protection and will simply be maintained with the reissued card.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his detailed answer to my question. I have just spoken to my learned medical colleague, Dr Herron, and he tells me that at the moment the Medicare card has only one number on it. My supplementary question relates to the fact that the Medicare card that will now be issued will have two numbers-the Medicare number and another number.
