What information will be recorded or incorporated in that other number? Does this mean that a black box in every pharmacy in Australia now becomes a fact of life?

—I do not know what might be in the black box. But certainly there will be nothing which would be a cause of concern to the Privacy Commissioner, Kevin O'Connor, who has endorsed this new arrangements and, in fact, whose advice was taken in relation to this reissue of the Medicare card. He has endorsed the changes to the card and, I believe, in his endorsement lies the security of those who are concerned in these matters. I believe that that should lay to rest any misgivings that they may have.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I draw the Minister's attention to two issues regarding AIDS, both recently highlighted in the media. The first issue involves a proposal from Western Australia for compulsory testing for HIV AIDS of all blood samples taken in that State. Secondly, I raise the results of a recent survey which claimed that there was an increase in support for the quarantining of people with HIV AIDS in Australia. Could the Minister advise the Senate whether it is intended to compulsorily quarantine people with HIV AIDS and whether the Government intends to fund compulsory testing for AIDS.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Foreman for his question which arises out of a proposal, I believe, of the Opposition spokesman on health in Western Australia, Mr Kevin Minson, who suggested that all blood samples should be tested for HIV indications. That would be a wasteful, irresponsible and an unnecessary response to the question of HIV and AIDS in the community and reveals a depth of ignorance about the disease and its transmission.

ANSWER.PARA: It has been estimated that the cost of implementing Mr Minson's proposal would run into many tens of millions of dollars, as hundreds of thousands of blood samples collected would have to be subjected to the particular tests in laboratories that he suggests. In Western Australia only 109 cases of AIDS and 581 cases of the HIV infection have been reported-about 0.3 per cent of the population. So honourable senators can see that the proposal is out of all proportion to the problem evidenced in Western Australia.

Senator Foreman also asked about quarantining those who are carriers of HIV or who are suffering the AIDS disease. The fact is that there is some community concern about isolating or quarantining those who suffer from this disease. This is unfortunate as I believe that it reveals that many in the community are still very ignorant about the way in which this disease is transmitted.

In June 1990 a survey commissioned by the Government found that over a six-month period in 1990 approximately one in four Australians supported the idea of isolating people with AIDS. I believe that that is a reflection of the fact that so many Australians are still not aware that HIV is not highly infectious and is only transmitted in very specific ways.

I believe that education efforts are paying off. But much more needs to be done. Only this week an article in the British medical journal, Lancet, commended Australia for its strategy on AIDS. The way in which that education program can allay prejudice and discrimination against people with HIV is to be commended but obviously it needs to be reinforced.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which I address to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, concerns Cambodia. I refer to the Minister's answer to Senator Schacht at Question Time on 13 February and to the Minister's past determination to keep on asserting that his comprehensive settlement is the only hope for peace in Cambodia which, on 13 February, the Minister said is `inching forward'. I ask: how can he possibly consider such a settlement to be `still well in sight' when he admitted on 13 February that three significant issues-the demobilisation provisions, the weapons custody arrangements and the acknowledgment of past genocide-are still unresolved? Is the Minister prepared to consider moves by the Hun Sen Administration to hold elections in Cambodia so long as they are genuinely on a fair and open multiparty basis? Now that Australia has normalised relations with China, what new initiative is the Australian Government taking in discussion with China to advance a solution for the Cambodian people? Finally, will the Minister explain how, under his policy, he can continue to expect that the Khmer Rouge, including leaders directly involved in Khmer genocide, will not regain positions of power in any future Cambodian government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is the case that there are only three significant issues dividing all the various parties to these long and complicated negotiations, that is a very substantial improvement on the situation that has existed previously when there have been many issues of controversy and difficulty. My own judgment is that there are only three such issues and only one of them is in fact substantive-and that is the question of the demobilisation or disarmament arrangements under the United Nations peace plan. Moreover, I believe that it is capable of negotiation, particularly in a round table context where all the parties are gathered together and able to talk and exchange positions.
—Genocide?

—Yes, including genocide because there is a particular formula on the table which involves a forward looking reference rather than a backward looking reference. It is our judgment that, on the basis of conversations we continue to have with all the relevant parties, at the end of the day-although not before a round table conference is finally convened-we believe that that issue will be capable of resolution. That is a judgment not just based on instinct-it is a judgment based on a lot of knowledge and a lot of discussion.

ANSWER.PARA: We do propose to keep pressing forward for the comprehensive settlement solution even though it is, as I have recently described it in a letter to the press, an achingly, frustratingly slow business. We take this view simply because of our continued very strong belief that it is the only way to bring to an end the protracted and tragic civil war in Cambodia; because, I will repeat, in our judgment and that, indeed, of all the other players, including the United Nations key countries, that is the only way that China will be persuaded to withdraw its support, including in particular its support of arms materiel for the Khmer Rouge. It will only be persuaded to do so in the context of the comprehensive settlement where the neutrality of Cambodia is internationally guaranteed and there is no prospect of the country coming again under the hegemonic influence, as people like to describe it, of Vietnam. That is China's traditional strategic concern for the region. That is why China has taken the course that it has, not out of any particular love or affection for the Khmer Rouge, and it is that that can only be addressed by the kind of comprehensive settlement we are talking about.

Any one-sided solution which seeks to recognise and arm and equip the Government of Phnom Penh to deal with the Khmer Rouge threat simply misunderstands the significance of that external support for the Khmer Rouge and misunderstands the necessity to break the nexus of that external support which can only be done under a comprehensive settlement.

We are continuing to plug away. Mr Costello, as has been indicated in some press reports, is presently in the region and talking again, as I have been talking regularly, to the co-chairman of the Paris conference, Ali Alatas. He is hoping to go to Hanoi and Phnom Penh within the next few days to engage further in discussions on this. Certainly, we are still talking very directly to China. I have taken the opportunity with several recent high level visitors to express certain views on how the matter might be resolved. We genuinely believe it is capable of resolution.

There are no new particular initiatives that we are presently contemplating. It is just a matter of trying to keep the attention of the major players engaged-it has obviously been distracted by the Gulf war-and to move the process forward in the way that I have indicated.

As to the final point of the honourable senator's question of course we cannot guarantee that the Khmer Rouge will not play some kind of role in a post-settlement Cambodia if it is successful in a free and fair election conducted on a level playing field by a United Nations supervised administration. If the people of Cambodia, under those circumstances, are prepared to entrust the Khmer Rouge with some share of power in a democracy so constituted, then I do not honestly believe that it is for us or for anyone else to second guess that.

What the whole present United Nations plan is about, however, is avoiding a situation which was a flaw in the original peace proposals circulating a year or more ago. We want to avoid the situation where the Khmer Rouge is given a share of executive power as part of some transitional arrangement without earning it at the ballot box in a properly supervised election. So that is the basis on which, despite all the systematic disinformation which continues to be peddled by Mr Pilger and others who are impressed by him, we continue to press for the United Nations peace plan.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his long and careful answer. There was just one part that he did not explicitly refer to and therefore I ask it again. Is the Minister or his officers or his Department giving any active consideration to the proposal that the Hun Sen Administration conduct an election so long as it is seen to be and actually is genuinely fair and open and on a multi-party basis?

—We of course have no objection in principle to the Hun Sen Administration conducting an election and thereby conferring some additional degree of legitimacy presumably on the government so elected-a legitimacy which is presently lacking because of its character as a government installed by the occupying Vietnamese. However, it does not follow from that that that is a credible alternative solution to the whole problem of Cambodia or something that in itself will necessarily advance or assist the process of bringing to an end the civil war, for all the reasons I have just indicated; because the Khmer Rouge will continue to be supplied externally-in particular by the Chinese, for the reasons I have indicated-and the Khmer Rouge simply will not be prepared, I believe, to foreswear the military option simply because the Phnom Penh Government conducts some kind of internal election. It is an attractive option. It does move the process forward in some ways, in terms of conferring additional legitimacy, but it does not address the basic nub of the tragic problem of Cambodia. Only the United Nations peace plan does that.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 February Senator Macdonald asked me a question relating to the spaceport and I undertook to obtain an answer for him. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Following the Government's decision in December 1989 on the need for a spaceport Environmental Impact Assessment, guidelines for the assessment were developed jointly by the Commonwealth and Queensland Governments. These were issued to the proponent, Cape York Space Agency Pty Ltd, on 11 October 1990.

Very shortly after that, the owners of CYSA announced their intention to sell the company. The present situation therefore is that the spaceport project now needs restructuring and until this is done there is no proponent with funds to commence the EIS.

Whilst the Government is taking steps to encourage restructuring and recommencement of activities as quickly as possible, the EIS involves a complex study and assessment process which will take approximately two years to complete. It is expected that a plan acceptable to the local Aboriginal community will also be settled within that time frame.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me a question in respect of Queensland's share of higher education places. The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided me with further information on the issue and I seek leave to incorporate that answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
QUEENSLAND'S SHARE OF HIGHER EDUCATION GROWTH

In allocating growth among the States and Territories, the Commonwealth takes account of a range of factors, including current levels of participation and unmet demand, and projected further demand associated with population growth and increasing Year 12 enrolments.
Having considered these factors, the Commonwealth has recognised Queensland's case for a share of growth above its population share. This is also the case for some other States.

The growth allocations provided to Queensland by the Commonwealth are such that Queensland will receive 25% of all additional intakes in 1991 and 23% over 1991-93, well above its population share of 17%.
In 1990 the higher education participation rate was slightly below the national rate: 39 per thousand 17-64 year olds compared with 40 per thousand nationally.

There are other States, notably NSW, which have the same or lower participation rates than Queensland: NSW's rate was 37 per thousand, Tasmania's 34 per thousand, South Australia's and the Northern Territory's both 39 per thousand.

It is estimated that, on 1990 figures, an additional 13,200 students would have been required to bring NSW, Queensland, South Australia, and the Northern Territory to the 1990 national rate. In particular, NSW would have needed 9,800-students, compared with 1,300 in Queensland.

The level of unmet demand in Queensland was estimated by the AVCC at 3,300-4,800, well down on the 1989 figure (4,000-5,900). The AVCC's estimates of 1990 unmet demand for NSW and Victoria were 3,700-5,400 and 4,200-6,300 respectively, both higher than in Queensland.

The proportion of Queensland secondary school students proceeding directly to higher education in 1990 was 25.1%, above the National figure of 23.1%, and higher than any other State or Territory, except the ACT. In NSW the transition rate was 21.6%, below both the Queensland and the national figure.

The Commonwealth considered in detail the case for growth in each State and Territory in coming to its decisions on the allocation of 1993 growth (reported in its recently released Higher Education Funding for the 1991-1993 Triennium).

The Commonwealth consulted closely with the States as part of this process, through the Joint Planning Committees which exist for each State and Territory, and it would be quite inappropriate for the Commonwealth to be dealing separately with Queensland, outside the normal process.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Question Time today I was asked a question by Senator Calvert about the Renison mine closure. I would wish to supplement the answer.

ANSWER.PARA: In the case of Renison Ltd, I can say that I am disappointed that Renison has decided to close its tin mine in Tasmania and regret the severe economic consequences of the decision. Renison's decision follows a long term deterioration in the tin market and continuing losses incurred by tin producers. Renison's mine is the world's largest underground tin mine, and the company produces 90 per cent of Australia's output of tin concentrates. Falling tin prices led the company to put forward a restructuring package involving a lower operating level, a reduction in the size of the work force and an erosion of working conditions at the mine. This plan was rejected by the work force. Renison has had difficulties in the past in gaining access to high grade tin deposits in Tasmania because of what it cites as environmental considerations. This may have been a contributing factor to the financial difficulties of the mine. Renison has advised that the mine will be placed on a care and maintenance basis and it will review costs and the market situation if this justifies a decision to reopen the mine.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — At Question Time today I was asked a question by Senator Winston Crane about the dispute at the Heinz company plant in Victoria. I can supplement my answer by saying two strikes stopped production from 22 February to 4 March at the Heinz food canning plant at Dandenong, Victoria. The first dispute involved 400 members of the Food Preservers Union who stopped work over the dismissal of two employees. The matters went before Commissioner Donaldson of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The Government believes that the Commission was the appropriate forum to deal with the issues in dispute. The striking members met on 4 March and voted to accept a proposal negotiated between the parties last weekend.

ANSWER.PARA: The second strike involved 80 members of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union (AMWU) over the matter of a long running demarcation issue with the Electrical Trades Union (ETU). The matter came before Commissioner Peterson of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission on 6 March and was adjourned into private conference. The AMWU and the ETU have agreed to hold further discussions on the matter which has been relisted for further hearing on 18 March. All striking workers returned to work on 5 March.

The other element of that question was a question of costs. I have no estimate that I can vouch for. I can say, though, that Heinz has estimated that it has lost $9m in sales, and growers and transport operators have lost $1m, and that striking workers have forfeited half a million dollars in lost wages.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to table the statements that he had prepared for him for Question Time.
—Will the Minister table those answers?
—I do not propose to table the documents, Mr President. I have read the salient features of those documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answering my question last Tuesday about whether Department of Social Security regional offices were giving correct information to clients about the relevance of the deeming rules to beneficiaries other than pensioners, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) claimed that my office's survey which found that 15 of 31 Social Security regional offices were giving inaccurate information about this matter was not a fair survey of Social Security. Yesterday this was reported in the national media.

SPEECH.PARA: This cast doubt on the accuracy of the staff of my office, the survey in particular, and me. The Minister, in doing so, failed to recognise that a similar survey by the welfare rights unit, conducted in New South Wales earlier this week, also found that more than 50 per cent of the 22 regional offices contacted were unaware that the deeming rules applied to sickness benefits. Nine of the 22 offices incorrectly claimed that the deeming rules did not apply to sickness benefits, whilst three offices were unsure whether they did or not. This second survey, in conjunction with my own survey, conclusively showed that the client contact officers in social security regional offices are not aware of the applicability of the deeming provisions to beneficiaries. I ask that the Minister put his own house in order before he casts aspersions on mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that notice of motion No. 76, standing in my name, be withdrawn.

SPEECH.PARA: Notice of motion withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In January I gave notice of a motion No. 76 which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that Senator Vallentine disrupted debate yesterday in the House of Representatives by shouting abuse from the Senator's gallery; and
(b) calls on Senator Vallentine to:

(i) apologise to the Speaker of the House of Representatives for her improper and unparliamentary behaviour in disrupting a most serious debate in that chamber on a matter of vital concern to all Australians-
We remember that it was the Gulf war debate-
(ii) apologise to the Senate for behaviour bringing the Senate into disrepute, and

(iii) undertake as a Senator to abide by the principles of bicameral parliamentary democracy in which the elected representatives of the people are entitled to participate in debate without harassment or intimidation from the public galleries.
Today, almost two months after that event, Senator Vallentine submitted a letter to the Speaker of the House of Representatives which has just been tabled in that House. The letter reads:
Dear Leo,
I write concerning an incident in the House of Representatives on Mon. 21st Jan. 1990 whilst the Prime Minister was delivering a statement on the Gulf War.

My interjection, from the Senators' bench in the gallery, was not a planned action; it was straight from the heart, as I strongly oppose Australia's involvement in the war with every fibre of my being.
However, that does not excuse my interjection from that place of privilege-
with which I think all senators would agree-

and I apologise for any difficulty you or the gallery attendants experienced then or later, caused by my action. It was not my intention to embarrass you as Speaker, and I'm sorry about that aspect of the incident.
With best wishes,
Yours sincerely,
Jo Vallentine.

In the light of that apology, I am withdrawing my notice of motion. However, I must say this about the apology; it is belated and clearly grudging and, to my mind, does not really meet the requirements of good taste and discretion and the responsibilities of a senator. Nonetheless, it is a recognition that her interjection from a place of privilege could not be excused by her strong feelings on this matter, but I do express concern that, in effect, the apology is really to Mr Speaker and to the gallery attendants rather than the House of Representatives. But if that suits the House of Representatives, that is its business.

I am also disappointed that Senator Vallentine chose to do this simply by writing a letter to the Speaker without referring the matter in any way to this chamber to which, by the way, I believe she owes an apology, and did not have the courtesy to take this chamber into her confidence or to deal with us in a proper way despite the existence on the Notice Paper of this notice of motion dealing with her improper behaviour.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Newman proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The impact of the economic mismanagement of the Hawke Labor Government on Australian women.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The impact of the economic mismanagement of the Hawke Labor Government on Australian women is surely a matter of national importance because that impact has been both massive and appalling. Tomorrow, this Government has the hide to plan to celebrate International Women's Day. Some celebration! One might ask: what do the women of Australia have to celebrate tomorrow? When one looks at the importance this Government places on women, one has only got to start looking at the importance it places on this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: There is not one Minister going to take part in this debate. Although we have got the Minister responsible for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) and we even have the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), all of whom have portfolio responsibilities in which women are extremely interested. But not one of those honourable senators has seen fit to place importance on this debate.

It says something, I think, for the importance which they place on women, and I think it also says something for the shame they have for their mismanagement of the economy and, thereby, its disastrous impact on Australian women and, as well, of course, on Australian men. It is the sisterhood which is taking part in this debate, the troika of sisters in this chamber from the Left who march in on every debate every time there is anything to do with women. But we cannot see the Government, which is responsible for the mess, being prepared to take part in the debate.
Today, I have my colleagues Senator Brownhill and Senator Reid supporting me on this important matter. Senator Brownhill will discuss a matter--

TALK.START.PARA: —An excellent team.
—An excellent team. I thank Senator Short.
—A powerful team.

—Of course it is. Senator Brownhill will discuss the problems being faced by women in the bush. There is a disastrous situation in the bush now for men and women directly caused by this Government's mismanagement of the economy, directly as a result of its policies, and women in the bush are worried, and worried sick. They are lacking supportive services that they need as a matter of urgency. It is a disaster in the bush. If there were a national disaster anywhere else the Government would be looking to see what measures it could put in place. But is it interested in putting support services in for these families, for these women in the bush? No. Senator Brownhill will be discussing that matter in detail.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Reid will be looking at the problems being faced by older women in our community; the very serious problems of the women who are ageing and in poverty. She will be looking also at those mothers who are trying to support children on their own. It is a disastrous situation for those women in poverty traps in our society, because it is women who are bearing the brunt of the social fallout caused by the Federal Government's economic mismanagement. As the job market declines, as it tightens and the economic climate declines, women are being affected not only financially but they are also being affected in their health, their emotional needs, and ultimately those things take their toll on the family, even to the extent of the awesome and horrible announcement today by the Preterm Foundation in Surry Hills in New South Wales of the massive increase in abortions for married women. The executive officer of that foundation was saying how they have seen a 31 per cent increase in abortions by women because, as she said:
They can't afford to lose their income.
She also said:
They can't afford to keep a roof over their head if they lose their jobs.

For women now jobs are not an idle distraction. If they ever were, they certainly are not now. They are a vital necessity in keeping their family's mortgage going; in keeping the food bills paid; in getting shoes for their children; and it is absolutely critical to these women that they maintain their employment. Pregnancy messes up all their plans and it causes them to totally face disaster. So these women-married women-who are wanting to have their own children, who are sad to have to queue up for an abortion, are going down to ask for an abortion. What more terrible condemnation can we have of this Government's mismanagement of the economy that married women in Australia are being forced to this situation?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is shameless.

—It is shameless. The Government is shameless and shameful. The pressures from fear of unemployment, welfare dependency, high housing costs and inflation and increases in suicide all result from the economic mismanagement of the Federal Government. Let us talk about unemployment. Since 1983, the number of unemployed women has risen by 11.6 per cent. That is over the life of this Government. Young girls are really copping it from this Government.
—Oh, charming.

—Senator Crowley might well laugh. We on this side of the chamber do not find it amusing. In January 1990, 20 per cent of girls aged between 15 and 19 were unemployed. That was a disgraceful figure. What has it gone to now? It is 26.8 per cent. All those young girls cannot get a job. So much for the lucky country. What do those girls have to celebrate?

SPEECH.PARA: I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that at about the time the Labor Government came into office Bob Hawke told us that no government that allowed that rate of unemployment should ever be forgiven. Let this Government never ever be forgiven. Let nobody ever forget that Bob Hawke is presiding over unemployment for youngsters at 26.8 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator could refer to the Prime Minister by his appropriate title.

—The Hon. Prime Minister, Mr Robert Hawke. I accept your rebuke, Mr Acting Deputy President. We will give him all the deference to which his office is due. He is singing a different song now when he is the one who is presiding over these awful figures. In January this year also there were 305,000 Australian women who wanted a job and could not get either a full or a part time one. That is up from 239,300 at the same time last year. I ask: what do those women have to celebrate on International Women's Day?

SPEECH.PARA: From 1983 to 1990, the number of women receiving sole parent pension rose by 9.8 per cent. Is that something to crow about? I suppose the sisterhood will probably crow that it is marvellous that there is a pension there for them to get. I would say it is terrible that they should need it. They would much rather be in work and that is what we should be trying to provide. But this Government has failed to provide it entirely.

Let it not be forgotten that the President of the Australian Council of Social Service, Mrs Merle Mitchell, has told us that by the middle of the year more than one million Australians, including nearly a quarter of a million children, will be dependent on unemployment benefit-something to crow about there, I imagine, from the sisterhood. I will leave Senator Reid to talk about the poverty traps, the sole parents and the number of women who are being assisted, if at all, through the jobs, education and training program for sole parents (JET) interviews. Only 5.3 per cent of the sole parent pensioner population actually received JET interviews last year. Yet we continue to hear about the JET scheme from the Government.

Let us look at housing affordability. In 1988, people living in Melbourne used 25.7 per cent of their average family income to pay off their home. In 1989, it had gone up to 34.2 per cent. The Government tries to claim that interest rates have come down and that things are a lot better. It should ask people who were paying 32.6 per cent of their income in 1990 whether they are feeling much difference. I would say they are still feeling the pain. In Sydney the figure has gone from 31.7 per cent of the average family income in 1988 to 41.1 per cent in 1989. It has gone up to 42.2 per cent this last year, in the September quarter. So much for interest rates coming down. People are still, in fact, desperately strapped for cash when it comes to keeping a roof over their head.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I think you will be interested to find that only this week the Tasmanian Minister for Community Services, Mrs Judy Jackson, acknowledged that some women in our State are paying up to 75 per cent of their income in rent. Is that something to celebrate? It is no wonder women cannot afford to have babies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook said that they had put off having babies because of the economic climate a year ago.

—Senator Cook knows all about it. It is a wonder he did not come in and debate the issue. I thank Senator Patterson for her interjection; she is quite right. When it comes to inflation, let me give the Australian Labor Party a few more clues because obviously its Ministry is out of touch. Inflation has been running at 8 per cent in 1989-90 and it will be well over the 6.5 per cent that the Government predicated for this year. The cost of living is putting ever more pressure on women who are juggling the family budget. All those women outside know that every word I say is true. I want to give some more figures. I hope honourable senators will bear with me because they are pretty appalling sorts of figures. I have the figures for some food items for 1983 and this year.
—Not the food items again.

—Senator Crowley is probably as much out of touch as her Ministers. In 1983 a litre of milk cost 74c; it now costs 97c-that is, it has gone up 31 per cent. Cornflakes have gone up from $1.15 to $3.40. That is an increase of 196 per cent.
—Shock! Horror!
—I would expect Senator Crowley to be and I hope she would be, if she had any heart at all. Baked beans have gone up from 60c to 91c-an increase of 52 per cent.
—This speech sounds like you have been eating baked beans.

—Senator Evans may not be aware that many Australian families are living on baked beans. It is their only hope of getting cheap protein in this country-short of cat food, I suppose. Strawberry jam has gone up 78 per cent. Laundry detergent has gone from $2.49 to $5.09 for a kilo-that is, 104 per cent. Are they going to be the great unwashed poor in Australia, or just the poor? The price of a loaf of white bread has gone from 83c to $1.41-that is, an increase of 70 per cent-and a litre of petrol has gone from 48.1c to 69.7c. In all this time the average weekly wage has grown by 75.6 per cent-that is, from the time this Government came into office until now. That is what those battling Australian families are trying to cope with. This Government, the sisterhood and the absent Ministers cackle and think it is all so very funny. But I tell them they are out of touch and the Australian people know exactly how hard it is to make ends meet, even if they do not.

SPEECH.PARA: This is causing stress-related problems. Doctors are saying that they are seeing increasing numbers of stress-related illnesses, they are seeing marital breakdowns, they are being called in with child abuse and domestic violence and they are being involved in alcoholism. Surely to goodness honourable senators know that is true. A counselling agency in my home State only this week reported that it expects a 100 per cent increase in suicide calls this year. Mr Peter O'Sullivan from Lifelink in Launceston said that those calls are from people contemplating, threatening or actually in the process of suicide. It normally takes them about three or four hours to counsel people on those calls. Mr O'Sullivan said:

We've had 59 of those already this financial year and if they continue to come in at this rate we'll see a 100 per cent increase this year on last. What we deal with at Lifelink is only the tip of the iceberg.

Those on the Government benches may laugh, but it is a terribly serious matter. We know that small businesses around this country are going to the wall. Bankruptcies, to the September quarter, were reporting an increase on the same quarter of the previous year. They have been up 32.7 per cent and 56 per cent in the last quarters of the year. Almost one-third of all small businesses are owned and run by women in Australia because, as we know only too well, that is the one place where they can get some flexibility in hours and conditions of employment. It is probable that some hundreds of small businesswomen will go to the wall this year in Australia.

Why are they going to the wall? They are going to the wall because of high overdraft interest rates particularly, because their customers do not have the money to spend any more-they are either unemployed or they are worried they will become unemployed and they dare not spend the money. That is the reality of Australia today, all around the suburbs and the country towns. That is what is happening to small businesses and their customers. The overdraft rates that they were paying may have come down from the 23, 24 and 25 per cent that they were paying a year or so ago; they may be only 20 per cent. I say `only' with heavy irony because those who are trying to keep a business going with an overdraft of 20 per cent today are destined for disaster.

Mandrake Keating does not seem to have any magic wand left. The magic dust is certainly not clouding the eyes of Australians any longer, certainly not those of women, who are essentially practical. The magic has worn off and there are no rabbits for him to pull out of the hat any more. He thinks he is a wizard, but unfortunately we all know the worst.

The Government should also be condemned for the way it has managed its own work force. I have time only to give a couple of examples. The second annual report of the Australian Women's Employment Strategy finds that the relative proportion of women in male dominated occupations remained largely unchanged between 1986 and 1990, with women only about 20 per cent as likely as men to be employed in male dominated occupations. Within the Australian Public Service, the percentage of women in decision making positions remains low. Women greatly outnumber men at the lower end of the salary scale. Last month the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade-and I am glad we have Senator Evans here, to make sure he remembers this-was publicly criticised as one of the worst performers in the Public Service in terms of equal opportunities, with a disproportionate representation of women at lower levels of responsibility and salary and no increase in the percentage of women in the Senior Executive Service in his Department since at least 1987. What does the Minister do or care about that? I am glad he is at least here to listen.

Senator Bolkus might be here to listen, too. It is a pity he is not. Nine Comcar drivers were appointed in his home State of South Australia to replace those Comcar drivers who were made redundant at great cost--

TALK.START.PARA: —There is only one man over there.

—Yes, only one man from the Labor Party is listening. Senator Bolkus is responsible for Comcar; he made those men redundant and paid them big fat amounts to get out of the service, and now in Adelaide he has just put nine more people on. Guess how many were women? One! Big deal for equal opportunity for women in federal employment! I have been told of an experienced taxi fleet computer operator, female, who was recently passed over for appointment by Comcar in favour of a two-finger typist, male. Why? One can wonder.
—Tell us.

—She was needed; that job was to fill a computer operator's position, and we get a two-finger male typist. One wonders why. Turning now to superannuation, one finds that only 36 per cent of women are in superannuation funds compared to 61 per cent of all male workers. Fat lot of incentives the Government has given them.
—You are on shaky ground. You never did anything for women under superannuation.

—If Senator Crowley wants the figures, that 36 per cent of women in superannuation funds includes those who are only on the Government's measly 3 per cent awards which it imposed on small business-not genuine superannuation schemes, but those pretend schemes designed to give the Government's union mates economic power. When the Government tries to copy our proposals to give women the opportunity to opt out of work and save their superannuation entitlements while they are having babies, what does it do? It restricts their opportunity to keep their superannuation funds going for two years, so as soon as one has a terrible two-year-old-a toddler-one is meant to go back to employment and leave him to somebody else, regardless of one's own wishes, because one is supposed to get back into work and save one's superannuation. How uncaring and impractical is that?

SPEECH.PARA: I could spend a lot of time talking about what the Government has not done or has done inadequately in the area of health, and it is appropriate really because of the problems caused to women's health by economic pressures. I do not have time to spend on this now, but one wonders why the Government is failing to speed up the availability of hormonal replacement therapy for women. It is frustrating for those working in the field and it is unfair. So much for the squawking on the other side. I am sure that Senator Crowley will love saying something about this, but the fact remains that these women are waiting for this care and cannot get it. A senior Health Department official is challenging the legality of providing funding for the National Women's Health Strategy on the grounds that it is discriminatory. Who is in control of this Government? Perhaps it is not the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe); perhaps it is the bureaucracy. One way or another the Government must wear the responsibility.

Now the Government even has Medicare turning women doctors into second-class citizens because of the lower level of rebates that many women are now being forced to accept with the new arrangements with the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners. That is all part of the Government's mismanagement of the economy. I could go into many other matters, had I the time. My colleagues will cover many more of the areas.

This country could be great; it should be great; people in Australia want it to be great. And yet what has happened? We have people worried sick about their futures. We need a government that will turn this country around and will invest pride in its people-like the SPC workers, who are proud of the productivity they have increased. Yet the Government fought that deal. This is a government for special interest groups, not for the women of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must express my thanks to Senator Newman for allowing us today to discuss the issue of this Government's achievements in relation to women. I do not, of course, agree with the first of many faulty assumptions that she made when she introduced this matter of public importance. I hope that I will be able to give her some idea of where she has erred.

SPEECH.PARA: Early in her speech Senator Newman asked what Australian women had to celebrate. Had I two or three weeks, I think I might be able to tell her, with some assistance from my colleagues the members of the sisterhood, which Senator Newman seems to believe is a derogatory term. I assure Senator Newman that we all take great pride in being members of the so-called sisterhood; we take great pride in being members of the Labor Government; and we take considerable satisfaction in having been involved in policy development and now in policy implementation.

The selective citing of statistics, the faulty assumptions and the irrelevancies we have had from Senator Newman really do not do her justice. We could have had a debate at a much more useful level had Senator Newman managed to avoid some of the traps that are there for the unwary: for example, her assumption that there are vast numbers of women in small business going into bankruptcy. I would like to see some evidence to that effect. Our information-and it is not just Australian; it is also international-is that women are much less likely to go into bankruptcy. They tend to be better managers; they know their limitations; and they are not so likely to be speculative.

Of course, the Australian Labor Party has realised that the main and most crucial issue in relation to the welfare of women is to establish their economic independence. I would like to remind honourable senators of a few things that have happened over the past eight years. For example, the retention rate in schools has been raised to over 60 per cent. Of that 60 per cent, far more than half are girls. This is an enormous change. In 1982, only 36 per cent of young people stayed at school until they reached matriculation or the equivalent standard. Enrolments in universities are now showing us an excess of female enrolments over male enrolments; even in the technical and further education system, which tended to lag, we see a great deal of improvement in the participation of women. The participation rate of women in the work force is at its highest level ever and is still rising, despite increasing unemployment. It is very unwise, Senator Newman, to look simply at the raw figures and to ignore the percentage rates. At the moment we have a female participation rate of 52 per cent- as I say, the highest ever-despite the fact that there certainly is increasing unemployment.

It is also faulty to assume that women are worse hit by a period of downturn such as we have at the moment, in view of the fact that the highest rates of increasing employment are in the service sector, where women are represented most highly. Over the last eight years 59 per cent of the additional 1.6 million jobs created have gone to women. A lot of those certainly have gone into part time employment, but for many women this is the preferred type of employment during certain periods of their lives; certainly in returning to the work force, in coping with their families and in developing or maintaining their skills in order to return to the work force at a later time.

We note that Senator Newman has heard of some of the job creation and training programs. The only one she mentioned was the jobs, education and training program-JET. Between its inception in March 1989 and May 1990, nearly 11,000 sole parents participated in labour market programs, compared with only a little over 3,000 in the previous 12 months-an increase of nearly 300 per cent.

That program has been extended and enhanced in the 1990-91 Budget. Clearly it is a very successful program and, as I am sure the Senate is aware, includes a component to provide for children's services in order that women can return to education, training and employment. There has been a 28 per cent reduction in long term unemployed, incidentally, in the 12 months to November 1990 since the introduction of the Newstart program, which Senator Newman will recall, is designed to help those people who have been out of the work force for long periods of time. Some 12,000 women from the Newstart group have returned to the work force in that period.

The Women's Employment, Education and Training Advisory Group, which was established by this Government about three years ago, is providing an excellent source of information and advice to the Government and has recently established a steering committee on a national plan of action for women in technical and further education. I anticipate that that will be an extremely useful approach to that type of tertiary education, which is becoming more and more acknowledged as part of the tertiary education field.

Another very important aspect of improving women's employment possibilities and their long term employment possibilities has been the introduction of maternity leave which occurred more than 10 years ago. But just recently honourable senators may have noticed that this Government supported the successful Australian Council of Trade Unions case for parental leave, which now allows fathers to share the 52 weeks of unpaid leave which are available in the majority of private enterprise employment.

I turn to matters such as income support, which Senator Newman managed completely to ignore as if it did not matter. I draw to her attention the fact that across the community generally real household disposable incomes per capita grew by 12.4 per cent between March 1983 and September 1990. This is a genuine figure, in percentage terms about the whole of the community and all household incomes. It compares with a growth of only 5.4 per cent between December 1975 and March 1983-a very real improvement on what occurred during the seven years prior to this Government's being elected.

The family package which was introduced by this Government has helped to increase the real income levels of the bottom 10 per cent of two parent and sole parent families with children by 12 per cent and 15 per cent respectively. That is an important increase in the disposable incomes of those families on low incomes or of those who depend on social security. At present more than 500,000 families, including 1.2 million children, are being helped with family allowance supplement payments or their equivalent in extra pensions and benefits. Including family allowances, this involves over $2 billion of Commonwealth funding for children and low income families. The average payment now to a family with two children will be $50 tax-free per week.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have to under your Government.

—They received considerably less under your Government, Senator Walters. I remind Senator Walters of what I just said, because perhaps she was not listening. Between 1975 and 1983 real household disposable incomes rose by only 5.4 per cent. In the following eight years they have risen by 12.4 per cent-a 150 per cent increase on the previous seven years. If women are to be able to take their place in the work force to maintain or develop their economic independence, we have to make certain that our children's services are adequate to meet their needs.

SPEECH.PARA: I have great pleasure in reminding Senator Newman of figures that I am sure she has heard before but perhaps which she would like to hear again. Since 1983, 77,500 new community child-care places have been created. The program that we have embarked on will substantially increase that number within the next two or three years. Since eligibility for fee relief was extended to commercial child-care centres in 1990, 890 centres have already been approved for fee relief, representing about 36,000 places. Some 50,000 new places will be created in the community sector, and it is expected that commercial and employer provided child-care will grow by 28,000 places.

I am sure Senator Newman heard Senator Cook's answer to my question today about guidelines for children's services in the public sector, and his reference to the fact that there is now a set of standards which Commonwealth departments are expected to examine in the hope that many will follow the good example already set by the Australian Taxation Office, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, with the support of the Australian Government.

The other ways in which the standard of living, the quality of life, the opportunities generally for women of all ages have been enhanced would make a very long and interesting catalogue. I would like to have the opportunity to embark upon it; it is difficult to stress too strongly that this Government has been very conscious of the fact that the way to assist families out of poverty is to ensure that the members of those families are able to take part in the work force and able to develop their economic independence.

There is another sector of the community which has been greatly assisted by the initiative of this Government in establishing the child support scheme. Prior to the start of the scheme in June 1988 only 30 per cent of court ordered maintenance was paid to parents with custody of children, and frequently this was paid at irregular intervals. The Child Support Agency now collects 71 per cent of all liabilities registered with it and the Department of Social Security distributes $10m each month to 138,000 children from broken families. There has been a rise in the average amount of maintenance paid per child from $27 to $49 a week under the formula assessment. There has also been an increase, as you, Mr Acting Deputy President, will be well aware, in the amount of child support ruled by court orders from $27 to $39 a week.

I recall working with Senator Aulich on this scheme two or three years ago and our mutual concern about the low level of court orders generally at that time. Work carried out by this Government, with a great deal of assistance from a number of professional people, and particularly Mr Justice Fogarty, has established a level at which we believe children should be supported by the non-custodial parent, given certain qualifications. That scheme is now in place. As a result of introducing this scheme there has been a rise from 26 per cent to 37 per cent in the proportion of sole parent pensioners receiving maintenance payments-that is an increase of 42 per cent.

In a relatively short period of time it is a matter of considerable satisfaction to us and a matter on which the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Social Security should be strongly commended. This has its side effects, too, and a particularly good one is that because of this increased level of maintenance payments by non-custodial parents the amounts of pensions being paid to sole parents have been able to be reduced, and therefore have reduced the call on the welfare budget.

As I said earlier, Senator Newman made a lot of very wild assumptions. She referred to a matter which was the subject of some recent publicity-the number of terminations that are being sought by women in Sydney. Although she did not actually quote from that article--

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did. The Executive Officer.

—I beg the honourable senator's pardon. She said that some women are saying that they cannot have babies because they have to keep their jobs. Perhaps we should be looking very carefully at encouraging women to use contraceptives rather than resorting to terminations. If there is this genuine concern amongst women in the community about their fertility, there are-on the whole but not always-certainly other ways of dealing with this than having to depend upon terminations. I expect that, if the matter were investigated more closely, it might be seen that the story could have been a little more complete.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman also made some statements-and I have no reason to doubt them at all-about the numbers of people suffering from stress, particularly women who are threatening suicide. Indeed, this is an extremely tragic state of affairs and it certainly needs some more investigation.

What was it that the coalition recommended as one of its very few firm policies in relation to fiscal matters? I seem to recall some reference to a consumption tax. I wonder how that is meant to enhance the well-being of families; how that is meant to really increase the standard of living and the quality of life of women and their children, particularly as women always bear the brunt of increasing prices and inflation rates.

I think Senator Newman's reference to the current inflation rate probably was a little uninformed. I suggest that she have a closer look at some of the answers to questions that have been asked over the last two or three days and not leap to the sorts of conclusions that she has been tending to draw today.

As inflation falls and interest rates are cut, we will find-as we are already finding-that housing will become more affordable and much of that stress will be relieved. But at the same time, we in the Government very much appreciate that stress is being place on families and on women in particular. We appreciate that this can affect relationships within their families. We know the effect that this has on children.

I will go back to what I was saying originally. As much as we regret the downturn in the economy, Australian women in 1991 are in a far better position to cope with that state of affairs than they would have been, and certainly were, in 1982. I can recall being in this Parliament at that time and taking part in a debate not unlike this one. There are now far more women in a position to earn their own living or to contribute to their own economic independence. There are far more young women with much better opportunities as far as education and work force potential are concerned. Those are amongst the many things that Australian women have to celebrate on 8 March, International Women's Day 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are astonished that the Opposition chose to propose this matter of public importance when Australian families and women, about whom they profess to be so concerned, are suffering hardship because of policies which, in large measure, the Liberal and National parties have actually supported in this chamber. For example, I remind the Opposition that it supported the Government's move to take widows off the class B widow's pension when they get to 45 years of age and put them on the unemployment benefit; something that has been the cause of great hardship and increased impoverishment for many of the women affected ever since.

SPEECH.PARA: Also, the Opposition was keen on cutting Austudy to 15-year-olds in their last two years of school. This has been particularly hard on women in South Australia and Western Australia who are single parents and who have 15-year-olds in Year 11. They are experiencing difficulties because of the school systems in those two States especially. We have had calls and letters from these women who have been forced to take their children out of school, causing them and their children enormous distress and damaging the future life prospects of their children. Presumably, these particular groups of women and others are not the ones that the Opposition is concerned about today?

Women make up the majority of those living below the poverty line in this country. Women, as a group, spend more time in that position below the poverty line than men do. Yet every time the Opposition actually manages to come out with an economic or taxation policy, it is essentially directed away from the most disadvantaged members of our community-most of whom are women, as I have said-and towards the more well-off.

Senator Giles has just referred to the concept of a broad-based consumption tax. Marian Sawer, a woman of note, writing in Australian Society in 1989, pointed out that such a tax would result in a redistribution from `the purse to the wallet'. She said:

Beneficiaries (of the tax) will be those on or above average weekly earnings-overwhelmingly male-while the costs will be borne by low income earners, pensioners, beneficiaries and those responsible for household purchasing, the majority of whom are women. Proposals to compensate households through the social security system for the regressive effects of the tax will increase the economic dependence of women.

Of course, proposals to compensate through the social security system will also create poverty traps at the margins, as we have seen already with the targeting of the social security policy by the Hawke Labor Government. All that the Opposition proposes to do is to increase the poverty traps, increase the economic dependence of women and increase the tax burden for those who can least afford to meet that burden.

Marian Sawer mentioned average weekly earnings. In spite of nominal equal pay in this country, we still find that the latest figures show that there is an over $140 per week discrepancy between the average weekly earnings of males and females. Clearly, women are least able to cope with those sorts of policies.

If we are going to be critical of the effect of the Government's economic policies on women, I think we are also entitled to ask: where is the benefit for Australian women in the Opposition's economic policies? I point out that earlier today in this chamber one of the women on the Opposition side moved an amendment which, in essence, opposed support for Australian industry. This would have the potential to create even higher unemployment in the future than this Government has already meted out. I find considerable irony in the fact that a little later in the day another female colleague should propose the matter of public importance that we are now debating.

Let us be clear: Australian women are bearing the brunt of this recession. There has been a very real feminisation of poverty in this country. I refer here especially to the desperate situation of many sole parents, the vast majority of whom are women. At least 50 per cent of sole parent families headed by women live in poverty. Amongst the major reasons for this fact is the lack of financial support from former partners.

The Government, as Senator Giles has said, has taken steps, strongly supported by the Democrats, to do something about this through the child support scheme. Progress is taking place. Nevertheless, for many of those sole parent families it remains the case that lack of support from the former partner drives them into, and keeps them in, poverty. I think until we have a maintenance guarantee for all children, which we still do not have under the child support scheme, that will continue to be the case.

Enormous difficulty is being experienced by women trying to re-enter the paid work force after years at home or, in the case of many women, particularly those in the older age groups but still of work force age, attempting to gain, perhaps for the first time for many of them, some form of relevant and employable qualifications. This is in spite of the Government's scheme which looks good on paper but access to which is very difficult for many women, particularly those who are geographically isolated or those who are socially isolated by their lack of experience, by their lack of self-esteem, by their lack of English language and often, too, by their lack of financial support to engage in those exercises. The social security review, headed by Bettina Cass, found that women are twice as likely as men to depend on social security for their major source of income.

Just this morning my colleague Senator Lees spoke about the fact that the social security system in this country used to be driven by the attitude that we would and should help those who, through no fault of their own, were in financial need. Senator Lees went on to observe that under the Hawke Labor Government we have taken significant steps away from that concept and embraced the notion of targeting. Indeed this Government bruits on the international scene its pride in the very highly targeted social security system which we have. Targeting attacks that very basic concept of helping those who, through no fault of their own, are in financial need. Part of that concept really was, and has to be, that such support would apply universally to those Australians who lack sufficient funds to maintain themselves or their families.

The impact of this shift in philosophy has been particularly hard on women. It is a philosophy strongly supported by the Opposition, which has brought on this matter of public importance today. It is well documented that women suffer most as public expenditure diminishes because they are disproportionately dependent on the public sector for services and income support as well as employment. For example, through the cuts in funding by this Federal Government to the State governments have been the consequent cuts in the home and community care scheme. The particular groups of women affected by that are the elderly and women raising disabled children for whom that sort of support is less available.

Women are the carers in our community and they have lost out as cuts in that area alone have come through from the Federal Government to the State governments. There are, of course, particular problems faced by rural women. Government moves to impose an assets test on the family allowance galvanised rural women into action. They mobilised behind the campaign to remove the assets test from the family allowance which was proposed in the last Budget and to at least exempt the family farm from that test on the family allowance supplement. For many rural and farming women these supplements constitute their sole source of cash income from which they feed and clothe their children at this time of extraordinary rural downturn. To these women the family allowance is a matter of being able to put bread on the table; it is a matter of their family's survival.

That mobilisation did lead to a breakthrough. The Government and the Opposition continue to be intransigent on the issue of exempting family farms from the assets test for the family allowance supplement, Austudy and the assistance to isolated children scheme despite the obvious benefits that would flow to rural women and children. These benefits are only what we can call justice in a situation where assets do not mean liquidity.

I acknowledge that there are over 77,000 increased community child-care places. Senator Giles spoke on this matter a little while ago. Because this Government was starting from such a lean base after the years of the coalition Government, there is still a great shortage of affordable child-care places. Demand continues to grow, and that is a natural consequence of the increased involvement of women in the paid work force.

A paper put out by the Australian Institute of Family Studies tells us that in 1989, 56 per cent of families with dependent children had both parents in the work force; that is, families where there are two parents. We spoke recently with community based child-care providers who were primarily concerned about the affordability of child-care during the current recession. They spoke of women who simply could not afford full time child-care and had to make impossible choices between earning a decent living or contributing to maintaining their family's standard of living and giving up work to care for their child.

I express the Australian Democrats' concern of a report I heard on this morning's AM program about the deep distress that is being caused to married women seeking pregnancy terminations on economic grounds. I will refer to the comments made by Sue King, the Executive Officer of the PreTerm Foundation in Sydney on AM this morning. She said that these people are having to cope with huge financial dilemmas. She states:

It's their whole life experience at the moment; it's not just having to terminate a pregnancy at this time, it's their whole life experience that they're going through. They haven't got any money, they don't know where the next penny is coming from. They're worried that they're either going to lose their business, they're worried that they might be losing their home. A lot of these people have a lot of difficulty in either scraping together the money to buy their existing children shoes, or pay for a school excursion or whatever it is. The most basic things which we all take for granted become huge problems for a lot of these people.

I think that speaks volumes for the distress that is caused to women at this time. I also refer to the concerns that have been expressed about the increasing unemployment and the effect that has on women. Virginia Dowd, the Managing Director of a national financial group, Women's Investment Network, expressed a number of those concerns in an article in the Canberra Times on 2 January. She states:

The group, which manages the financial affairs of about 20,000 Australian women, had found its services were being increasingly sought by women, many of whom had been retrenched or feared losing their jobs as the recession deepened.
This has occurred since January. In this article, Virginia Dowd tells us something that we all know. She states:

Women tend to be concentrated in support-staff roles and in a downturn, these are the first jobs to go. What's more women make up over 77 per cent of part-time workers-and, again, part-timers are vulnerable in a cut back.

Nowadays most women are providers and, for them, this economic downturn is removing financial independence but, perhaps even worse, removing their ability to support their families in the way they need to.

The Opposition has nothing better to offer women on this issue. That is why I think we find it somewhat extraordinary to be faced with this matter of public importance today. It does not require a recession, however, for women to have financial difficulties. I raise here, just briefly, the Democrats' concerns about the difficulties being faced by Robin Greenburg, the majority owner of the Perth-based finance advisory group, Western Women Management. For the past 11 months she has been trying to change the financial status quo. She has struck enormous problems-problems which we are attempting to get to the bottom of. There is an enormous amount of what appears to be obstruction and, indeed, a great deal of media vendetta in her home State of Western Australia. It is obvious that statutory authorities must do their jobs thoroughly; nevertheless, there is a nasty flavour of discrimination about this issue and the Democrats will certainly follow this issue up.

I think there are many areas where women still face difficulties. Those difficulties are obviously exacerbated in a recession. Nevertheless, nothing is offered by the Opposition that is of any great benefit to women; indeed, particularly with its tax and economic policies, women face an even more difficult future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy-Mr Acting Deputy President. It is not a good way to start a debate on something that is so important to the people of Australia. In debating this matter of public importance-the impact of the economic mismanagement of the Hawke Labor Government on Australian women-not surprisingly, I wish to direct my remarks specifically to women in rural Australia, and obviously that is why I addressed you in the way I did.

SPEECH.PARA: I am disappointed that no male person on the other side of the chamber will be speaking in this debate, because I believe the plight of women in our society at the moment is something that all of us should be thinking about. There is no indication of the representation in this place of the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women in the other place. I know that Senator Newman definitely represents the status of women in this chamber on behalf of the Opposition.

In the last few weeks we have heard quite frequently-especially from me-about the plight of the rural communities and the rural crisis that is crippling our country, most of it induced by the Hawke-Keating Labor Government. No matter how many times I raise the matter, what does not seem to get through to the government of the day is the cruelty that it is inflicting on the people of Australia. In fact, in November of last year the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Kerin, said:
The rural sector is vital to our national economy, and the rural community is vital to our national identity. This has always been the case in Australia, and it is not about to change.

That was over three months ago. Since then, we have seen wool prices collapsing and something like 4,000 small businesses going to the wall around Australia, many of them in rural Australia. Since that bold statement in November the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has published its annual projections of farm incomes and they have shown a drop across the board. In fact, the average farm net income will drop this year anywhere from 42 per cent for beef farms to 93 per cent for cereal grain operations. On average, across all farms it means a fall of some 67.1 per cent.

The wool industry faces a debt of $2.9 billion and the dilemma for woolgrowers at the moment is whether they accept the prevailing prices or not. Of course, they have to sell because they need the money to keep going. For some there is no choice; they have to sell their wool.

The wheat industry, as we know, is in no better shape. Figures provided by the Grains Council of Australia show that despite a 10.8 per cent decrease in farm production costs in 1991, and a 2 per cent annual productivity increase over the last 20 years, grain growers this year face a drop in income of 79.5 per cent for wheat and 93.8 per cent for non-wheat grain.

For those who are on a pay as you earn salary, that is probably hard to grasp. It is hard for a person to imagine what it would be like to have his income for the year cut to 10 per cent of what it was last year while still doing the same work or, as is the case on farms, more work. One cannot hope to understand what that does to families and particularly farm women caught in this bind with their families. It is, therefore, absolutely appropriate that on the eve of International Women's Day this chamber should focus on women in Australia, and most especially rural women. I am glad that Senator Newman brought this on for debate because it is so important for the very fabric of our society.

There is an adage in the bush that the definition of a successful farmer is one who marries a nurse or a schoolteacher because each can provide off farm income. That adage has been updated in the 1980s and 1990s. Today, it is not merely frequent, but almost mandatory, that the farm wife work full time off the farm as well as do all the other jobs that are assumed to be part and parcel of living in the bush. It is not always possible. It is not always easy to do that because of distance or the fact that they cannot always get jobs anyway. Just think of the cost of fuel, and that impost being foisted on people in rural Australia by this Government.

I cannot hope to explain to those who have no appreciation or understanding of it, just what constitutes running a farm. There is a special desire in people to undertake that sort of life. Until I came to this place I knew no other. But for women on properties it is not something that all of them were born to expect. The lifestyle is not an easy one to adjust to even in good times and even on the most affluent of properties.

Even on the closely settled properties there is isolation. The corner store is not next door and neighbours are either too far away or too busy for socialising. Husbands are often preoccupied. Even in good times the average day's work on a farm starts at 6 to 7 o'clock, which means that the wife, or the person helping in the house-the daughter, or whoever it is-has to get up much earlier than that to get the breakfast. The outside work usually finishes at dusk unless there is a crop to be stripped, and then it goes on for 24 hours a day. Meanwhile the wife, the daughter or the woman in the house is on call the whole time getting meals and looking after and supporting a husband or the people who are working on the farm.

At night, after that, there is the book work and the telephone calls to agents and contractors to be made, sometimes by the farmer himself but a lot of times by the wife. I know that my wife at home works late at night. I can ring her from here at 11 o'clock some nights and she will be still working in the office. It is a pretty lonely lifestyle for women on a farm to be working all that time and on their own. That is how it is in the good times. In the tough economic times foisted on us by this Government, the situation is far worse.

In preparing my notes for this debate today it was disturbing to find that very little has been written on the subject. A University of New England study done three or four years ago concluded that the prevailing ideology in the country is that men are the real farmers and that women not only accept this but also encourage the stereotype of themselves as homemakers; and they are. Even for those lucky enough not to have to go off the farm to work, there is more to the average day for the country women than for her city sister.

A National Farmer survey some years ago said that nine out of 10 women living on farms in New South Wales worked on the farm as well as in the home. In fact, almost 70 per cent of farm wives are the farm's business managers. On 5,400 farms women are the sole owners and managers. I would like to see a similar survey done today because that figure would probably be higher and, in addition, would show that significant numbers of women are also working off farm in additional roles.

A national survey of women in rural Australia undertaken by the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet called, appropriately enough, Life Has Never Been Easy, surveyed 14,000 women across Australia with the assistance of the Country Womens Association. The dominant theme in that survey was the loneliness, isolation and lack of basic services available to them-services, at the moment, that are badly needed and are being curtailed or taken away. Again, an updated survey done today would, I am sure, reinforce those concerns that have been magnified so much more because of the economic circumstances facing them.

I was talking to a doctor the other day and one in 10 patients today who are taking tranquillisers are people in the bush-mainly women-or they are handling alcohol not as well as they should be. They are having poor sleep patterns, there are more break-ups and young people, especially, are being hit by this dilemma in the country at the moment. Even for those who do not regard themselves as the farm manager, the tasks are varied and frequent. The farm wife becomes the gofer-the spare hand at harvest, the message taker and the person who does all those other jobs-and all this is on top of housework and the crisis that they are suffering at the moment.

Some of those people are the lucky ones. The Rural Development Centre in the University of New England did a survey on the role of women in alleviating occupational stress on the family farm and detailed the increase in the informal voluntary telephone network of farm women. It said:

One of the implications of the rural recession has been to force family members to take on extra workloads to replace hired labour which is no longer affordable under the financial constraints placed on family farms.
Of course, for many women this has:

. . . involved extra responsibilities in areas in which they have limited experience and skills and for which they receive little or no outside assistance or support. These women are finding themselves in a pivotal position--
They are filling it very well, but they are under stress and they have to do it because this Government has put this economic crisis onto Australian women.

The report also suggests that communication breakdown is another factor contributing to the stress experienced by farm women. Their husbands generally refuse to acknowledge the serious financial position of the farm and the women bear the brunt of the whole situation. I commend the report for reading to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson). Rural women need to educate the Minister on what life outside Canberra and Killara is all about. I bring the matter up because the Minister, when he visited Lismore recently, was quoted in a Lismore paper as saying:

I've seen things here I've never seen before . . . It's hard to believe that in this day and age there are people living without electricity, having to rely on kerosene. And we are not talking about the middle of nowhere-I'm talking about 30 kilometres from Lismore . . .
