If Senator Richardson were to go 30 kilometres from Canberra, he would find people without electricity. Many farmers have generators for their power needs because this Government thinks it is too difficult or too expensive to have the mains power connections and there is no incentive for them to have it done. If the Minister's appallingly limited lack of knowledge in areas outside Sydney is indicative of the rest of the Labor Cabinet, I am horribly concerned. The Government is not taking enough notice of women in the community. Only recently a television documentary was done on the farm crisis and the problems associated with women in this crisis.

Rural women are also suffering from the Government's recent attempts to reduce the availability of family allowances by the use of the assets test. This was fought by the Opposition. The Government has done this at a time when farmers have little or no income-they are asset rich but dirt poor. The Government has been cold and heartless to the Australian people, especially to the women who work on the farms in those areas.

Austudy is one glaring example of the inequality that rural families suffer under this Labor Government. It is appalling that country families are being asked to repay Austudy grants because the Federal Government's valuation office has revalued properties, some of them as much as 70 per cent above valuations applied by the councils. In some cases the valuations were determined two years after Austudy payments were made. How out of touch is this Government that it can be playing with rural families in this way? How can it value virtually any rural property at present higher than previous evaluations?

The other day I heard of an instance of a person being burnt out by a bushfire. He had lost 20,000-odd acres of country, but he cannot even get Austudy so that his child can receive a better education. And the Government says that we have to have a better education for our communities! The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that by 1990 no child shall live in poverty. And we now have whole families living in poverty. Women are bearing the brunt of that.

I support this matter of public importance, on behalf of the males in the Senate, because no male Government senator has got up to support the women of Australia. I do it with honour. I am content in the knowledge that we on this side of the Parliament have someone fighting for the women of Australia, especially the women of rural Australia-and that is Senator Newman. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the chamber for not being present for this very important debate. However, I was absolutely amazed that Senator Brownhill had so little to say that he finished so early.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I ask that Senator Reynolds retract that statement, as Senator Brownhill used all his allocated time.
—There is no point of order, Senator Tambling.
—She should still apologise to Senator Brownhill.
—Order! I have ruled on the point of order.

—I certainly was not trying to be abusive to Senator Brownhill. I got that piece of information from a member of the Opposition who, as I ran along the corridor, said, `Oh yes, he was very short. I only had time for two phone calls'. Perhaps that is a reflection on the length of the phone calls.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I spoke for the length of time that I am allowed to speak according to the light that comes on the clock. Senator Reynolds thinks she is so smart by saying that I did not speak for the right amount of time. She should have been in this chamber listening to the debate if she had any interest in women, and she would have then seen that the clock had the light on it.
—There is no point of order. Senator Brownhill, if you want to claim that you have been misrepresented, you may do so at the end of Senator Reynolds's speech.

—I have no desire to argue with Senator Brownhill. If he used his full allocation of time-congratulations, that is really good to know. Let me explain why I was out of the chamber instead of listening avidly to the comments being made by Senator Brownhill and other senators on this matter of public importance this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman seems to have a habit of only being interested in raising issues of concern to women at about the time of International Women's Day. That is very commendable. She seems to remember that 8 March is International Women's Day and says, `Perhaps I had better do something about it'. That is highly commendable. However, I thought that it might be advisable for--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Reynolds is claiming that I do not do anything about women for the rest of the year. Should I invite her to come to my speeches around Australia as I speak on the concerns of Australian women?
—There is no point of order.

—I do not think I have time to follow Senator Newman. I come to the reason for my being late into the chamber-as I say, I apologise to all honourable senators. One of the reasons I was late is that I was chasing--
—Reading up on the subject.

—No, I certainly was not reading up on the subject; I was reading up on one particular issue that I thought was very important in this debate this afternoon. We are on the eve of International Women's Day. As Senator Newman said in her opening remarks, it is true that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) regards women and the status of women as so important that he is making a major statement in Brisbane tomorrow. Senator Newman and members of the Opposition do not seem to like this and I can understand why. They are a little sensitive. I know that Senator Newman does not have very much success with many of her colleagues in getting status of women issues on the agenda. I will come to that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I wondered what John Hewson was doing tomorrow for International Women's Day. My secretary rang his office, identified herself and said, `What is the Leader of the Opposition doing tomorrow? It is International Women's Day. Is he addressing women's organisations? Is he doing something special for International Women's Day?'. No, he is not. He is in Melbourne all day. I am happy for Senator Newman to correct me if there is something on his program that his secretary is unaware of, but Dr Hewson's secretary advised that he has nothing planned. While the Prime Minister will be in Brisbane delivering a statement and giving commitment to the women of Australia, John Hewson probably did not even know it was International Women's Day until we reminded him. Even if he did know, he is not prepared to do anything about it.

Senator Newman in her opening remarks went on about some of the issues of concern to her. I will not stand here and deny there are problems in the community, that there are problems that women face, that men face, that people face, that older women, younger women and disabled women face. Of course we are in a difficult economic climate and it is difficult for people around Australia and, as Senator Brownhill said, particularly in rural Australia. However, I do question some of the double standards that are presented in this chamber when members of the Opposition say, `The Government is not doing anything about it' and they fail dismally to tell us what they would do. We hear very little about what the Opposition would do about any matter, if it ever gets into office.
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It would probably be in the interests of all senators if they directed their remarks through the Chair and if there were no interjections from either my left or my right.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, you are right. I would like to trace the history of the philosophy of the Liberal-National Party coalition in relation to status of women's issues and the needs of Australian families. To do this, I have to go back to John Howard and his Future Directions. To find out about his economic plans for women and whether his economic policies would have advantaged Australian women, we look first at the index and find that that document contained 109 pages of which only 1 1/2 pages were devoted to status of women's issues or women's policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, even though there were 1 1/2 pages we were none the wiser when we got to the end of them because there was nothing specific in terms of policy dollars. We do not know how much money John Howard would have been prepared to give to programs to assist women manage in a difficult economic climate. We do know that John Howard said that he was committed to smaller government and less interference. He was prepared to say that the Labor Government had elbowed out voluntary workers and the Opposition looked at introducing programs that penalised independence, self-reliance and self-help.

Clearly that does not spell dollars or assistance for programs for elderly women, for example. John Howard also said that the Australian Labor Party directed resources to public rented housing. Tut, tut! We would not want to see sole parents having access to public rented housing, according to John Howard. We all know what happened to Future Directions and to John Howard. But let us continue and just see what happened when Future Directions went down the gurgler. We then got the coalition's Economic Action Plan.

TALK.START.PARA: —We know what is happening now. Women are spending $70 on housing.
—Why don't you let us get on with it?
—Why don't you talk about what the Hawke Labor Government is doing?
—Order! Could I have fewer interjections, please?

—I will indeed come to that, just give me a few more minutes. In this splendid Economic Action Plan, the tax package, of October 1989, let us see what was detailed for women. How many pages did it contain? How many comments were there about women? There were 56 pages of policies and programs and no doubt promises, but nothing specifically earmarked for women. Women are not even mentioned in this document.
—There was a whole separate document. What happened to you?

—I remember very well the whole separate document. Unfortunately I do not have it with me. I remember that it was a flimsy little piece of paper. Women's issues were not part of the economic plan, if indeed they were part of a separate--
—No, because women are citizens who suffer like everybody else.
—They were not part of your economic policy. Thank you, Senator Newman.
—What's the Hawke Labor Government doing?
—Order! Honourable senators will cease interjecting.

—Before detailing some of the comparisons between the Hawke Labor Government and the coalition, I would really like to take up Senator Newman's point: because of the economic difficulties, the recession, in Australia today, many women are rushing off to have abortions, and how sad this is. I do not mind Senator Newman trying to score political points-that is her job and I would expect her to do it efficiently-but I do think that this is emotional claptrap of the highest order.

SPEECH.PARA: I have the statistics to prove it. In fact, there has been a major increase in the birth rate during the past few years, especially for women over 30. I will detail this. In the age group 30-34 years, there has been an increase from 83 births per thousand to 96 per thousand; in the age group 35-39 years, it has risen from 25.6 births per thousand to 32.5 per thousand. Similarly, there has been a small increase in the birth rate for women over 40 years having children. Far from us being able to say that all these poor Australian women cannot afford to have children, there is an increase in the birth rate. I think that is something that Senator Newman should read up on.

In conclusion, I would just like to compare two documents which I think summarise the differences of approach between the Hawke Labor Government's commitment to where women fit into its economic strategy and where they fit into the coalition's strategy, if indeed they fit at all. These are not my quotes. The first quote is from the Australian Family Income Transfer Project, entitled Families and the Tax Package and the second quote is from The Coalition Parties' Family Tax Package. They contrast quite clearly the strategies that are adopted by the Labor Party and by the coalition parties. I urge all honourable senators to have a look at The Coalition Parties' Family Tax Package. The concluding remarks are as follows:
* neither the Child Tax Rebate nor the Child Care Rebate would be available to families who do not pay enough tax to fully benefit;
* distribution of the benefits would go disproportionately to high income groups, with only 1.7 per cent of the package going to the 18 per cent of families receiving $14,000 pa;

* the long term objective to drop the top rate of tax even further would only benefit high income earners, half of whom have no children, giving gains to the most wealthy 100 times those of low income families;

So much for the Opposition's commitment to women and its commitment to women with children. Contrast that with the concluding remarks in Families and the Tax Package-I am sorry I can only use the concluding remarks-in relation to the Government's tax package:
Overall, the Government's tax package redresses substantially all of the deficiencies in the tax-transfer system affecting families and single individuals, as identified in Families and Tax in 1989.

The changes in the tax scale benefit most those families receiving incomes around $20 000 per annum and have restored a significant proportion of income lost over recent years. The changes were certainly more beneficial than the indexing of the tax scale of 1983-84 would have been.

In the area of family payments, a major boost to Family Allowances has restored much of the value lost since 1983-84. As a result the family tax concession has been greatly improved from its current level.
The benchmarks for assistance to low income families were met, so underpinning the incomes of all families with children.

I regret that I have not longer to go into details about the rural initiatives except to say that in the coalition's Economic Action Plan all those programs of assistance for rural Australia were going to be abolished.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think perhaps we should refocus on the topic of the matter of public importance that we are discussing today; namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The impact of the economic mismanagement of the Hawke Labor Government on Australian women.

I can scarcely believe that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will be making a major statement on women tomorrow. He is always making major statements on something, but we very rarely get anything that flows from it that is of benefit to the people he is talking about.

We had a major statement once about child poverty. Honourable senators will recall that child poverty was to end by 1990. But we know what the value of that statement was. Of course he will be making a major statement on women tomorrow; that is what he does on 8 March every year. It is designed to impress people, to bluff them into thinking that he is serious about women and serious about their welfare. If he were serious about the welfare of women he would be getting the economy right. He would be sacking his Treasurer (Mr Keating) and putting somebody in place who would get the economy on track so that women on low and fixed incomes would not be suffering as they are at present. Tomorrow will be more of the same from the Prime Minister.

We have a leader who is committed to getting an economy in place which will benefit all Australians and which will particularly benefit women, and they will be better off as a consequence. We do not have handouts, promises or bags and bags of policies. We actually want something to be done.

I am sorry that none of the Ministers has seen fit to take part in this debate. I would have thought it was a matter of such importance that a Minister would have taken part and referred to what the Government was going to do to make the economy strong. I noticed an interesting thing while sitting here listening to this riveting debate: there does not appear to be a Minister in the Senate who has ministerial representation responsibilities for the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I do not know, but that is certainly the literature that has been supplied to us in the Senate.

Tomorrow is International Women's Day. It is a day that I certainly remember each year. I have two daughters-they are not twins-whose birthdays are on 8 March, so it is not hard for me to remember the day. It would be worth looking historically at the day: it dates back to 1910 internationally and in Australia from 1928. At various times it has been used to assert women's political and social rights; it has been used to review the progress that women have made; and, on occasions, it has been used as a day for celebration. The United States socialist Lena Lewis said in 1910-in fact, she declared it somewhat prophetically-that `International Women's Day was not a time for celebrating anything, but rather a day for anticipating all the struggles to come'. So it will be this year.

There will not be many women in Australia who will be celebrating International Women's day on 8 March 1991. Women who are living with the economic and social consequences of the Hawke Labor Government's policies cannot celebrate. I am thinking of the women who are now unemployed or those who are coping with the financial and social consequences of their partners being out of work, as is happening to so many. I am thinking of those struggling with high interest rates on their home mortgages and on their businesses. I am thinking, of course, of the rural women that Senator Brownhill has already referred to who are suffering economic disaster and devastation in country areas, not just those on the land, but those running small businesses in the rural towns who are suffering so greatly because there is no money to change hands in those areas. I am thinking of the older women of our community, vainly attempting to live out their lives with dignity and financial security in the face of years of high inflation, high taxation, economic uncertainty and now, of course, a lack of understanding of the new deeming provisions which have been wished upon them. I am thinking of the women whose children cannot get work at a time of growing unemployment and, of course, of the young women amongst them who are not able to get on with their careers and to get a start in life. I am thinking of the women who make up the 90 per cent of one parent families which are headed by women. They have nothing to celebrate.

I recognise, of course, that no-one in Australia can escape the economic hardship that has been caused by this Government's deliberate policies of high taxation, high interest rates, high indebtedness and the high inflation that has flown from it as well. Women on lower incomes and fixed incomes have suffered particularly, those least able to buffer against the economic consequences of the Government's policies-policies that it has boasted about for eight years.

It is true, and one has to admit, that on the propaganda front the Government has done fairly well. It has propagated the myth that it is concerned with the status of women and women's issues. There have been many committees, inquiries and policies-there will be another one tomorrow, of course-but the gains are often illusory. Much effort and time has been put in by women into submission writing and information gathering, but not much has been done that has helped women, especially those who are on pensions and the single income benefits.

I want to refer to a small portion of a report of a Congress committee, the Committee on Economic Well-being. I think this answers some of the issues that the Australian Democrats put forward. The Committee said a number of things, among them:
The Committee recognized that a strong economy is essential to the maintenance and improvement in any of these tiers.
The tiers were the various levels of social security and pensions that exist. It went on to say:
The Committee therefore urged that the Administration and the Congress take steps to control unemployment, interest rates, and especially inflation, which significantly affect the elderly.

One would say that `the Administration' is a reference to the Federal Government. Oh, if only the Treasurer were listening and had the capacity to understand the effect that his economy has on those on pensions and on fixed incomes.

But rather than have a strong economy, what in fact have we got? There is not time today to go into all the details, but a little bit of information tells the story. We have a massive net foreign debt of $131 billion. Let us look at a bit of history. In 1969-70, the foreign debt was $2 billion. A decade later, 1979-80, $6.8 billion. That was perceived to be fairly high. It is now, as a gross figure, $165 billion, and as a net figure, $131 billion.

We can look at the situation in many different ways. Of course, we need more than the wool clip each year just to pay the interest on the foreign debt. I worked out yesterday that it would take 30 years of the wool clip to actually pay off the foreign debt, and that is without paying the interest each year as we go along in the meantime. That is the economic mismanagement that is making life so difficult and so hard for so many women; that is why it is necessary and relevant to discuss the matter as a topic today.

Senator Newman referred to the article about the increasing number of married women having abortions which appeared in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald. Senator Reynolds seemed to think that that did not matter because the birth rate was increasing. I do not think those two things are related. I think it is a tragedy if women are having abortions because they feel they cannot look after a child. Ms Sue King, the executive officer of the Preterm Foundation, which is Sydney's biggest provider of abortions, was quoted as saying:
We have a very strong perception that more married women are presenting for terminations because they cannot afford to lose their income.
They cannot afford to withdraw from the workforce and if they did withdraw it would probably mean losing the roof over their heads.
So even if the birth rate is increasing in some areas, there are women suffering in this fashion.

Many women find the question of child-care a very difficult one. Without going in great detail into the matter of child-care, the fundamental difference in the attitude of the Labor Party to child-care to that of my Party is that Labor regards child-care as a welfare issue and not as an economic issue. I think until it changes its attitude to that and sees child-care as an economic issue, continuing problems will exist for those who need quality child-care to enable them to participate in the work force.

This morning, in another debate, Senator Hill referred to the number of bankruptcies which had occurred, and the figures are worth noting. In the June quarter of 1990 there was a 10 per cent increase in bankruptcies over the same June quarter of 1989. In September 1990, there was a 32 per cent increase over September 1989. In December 1990 there was a 56 per cent increase over December 1989. I think we all recognise that that figure is growing.

It is all very well to talk about statistics in that fashion but every time there is a bankruptcy a family is totally disrupted in terms of its lifestyle. Its social life is disrupted; it probably has to move house or to a totally different area. The children have to change schools. The effect on a family is absolutely devastating. I think it is not good enough to just brush off these statistics for bankruptcies without having any regard at all for the social consequences to the people involved.

I want to refer also to sole parents. Ninety per cent of sole parents are women. We hear from time to time the myth that sole parents are mainly young girls who want to have a baby and get a pension. That is nonsense. About 3 per cent of women are in this category. Most sole parents are women attempting to get on with their lives.

The problem with the sole parent pension is that it locks women into being pensioners and does not do anything to encourage them to be in the work force or to try other options. As a family law solicitor, I have heard and know that a woman sole parent is frequently better off being on a pension than being in the work force. I think that is a tragedy. For every dollar she earns she loses money; she has to pay tax; she has to catch up with the Medicare levy; and she needs money to spend on child-care, transport and clothes. We make absolutely no effort to try to give such a woman a chance to escape from being on a pension, to escape from the isolation she is in at present.

I want to refer particularly to elderly people on fixed pensions who have great difficulty managing at the present time. Many have been caught with provisional tax. They are now facing the question of deeming. Deeming is a means of getting people to invest their money and earn income. The rate was set at 10 per cent at a time when the interest obtainable was 4 per cent higher than it is today. I want to refer to the interview the other morning of Mr John Barber on radio 2CN and what he said about the suggestion by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) that there are plenty of places where one can get 10 per cent. The Minister said that there were 29 accounts offering that rate or better. What nonsense, Minister. Mr Barber said:
We prepared our assessment on a basis of research that we've done with older people.

People need to be able to withdraw their money. However, there is an enormous number of restrictions on their doing so. Of the 29 banks that the Minister for Social Security spoke about, only two were able to offer accounts that actually met the criteria that pensioners needed. Pensioners frequently are not able to walk to 29 banks around the town to find out. To put people in this position at that age of their life is cruel and unconscionable. At the very least, those people over 80 years of age should have been excluded from the operation and not had to face the deeming provisions. Many of them are women.

So many utterly confused people have contacted my office. The provisions do not apply to some of them but they do not fully understand that. It is absolutely wicked of the Government to have introduced these deeming provisions. Certainly there would be people over 80 who could cope but a lot cannot.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a letter from Senator Newman proposing that the following matter be a subject for discussion:

SPEECH.PARA: The impact of the economic mismanagement of the Hawke Labor Government on Australian women.

One presumes from that that the Opposition wants to suggest that the impact on Australian women is negative and nasty. The Opposition spends a lot of time getting its facts wrong and confusing us with a range of statements that are so irrelevant as to be absolutely stunning in their irrelevancy. They have nothing to do with anything. Senator Newman, who led for the Opposition in this debate, is its spokesperson for women. And as Senator Margaret Reynolds said, it is women's day, so Senator Newman had to make a speech about it. For the rest of the time we are apparently included as citizens, which would be true because it would save Senator Newman telling us about the dramatic increase of women in the defence forces and other areas of interest of hers. They are actually categorised separately, Senator Newman. Does Senator Newman read them as citizens or women?

While I was out of the chamber, Senator Newman described the speakers for the Government as a `troika of Left women'. It depends what she means by Left, but by some definitions I am not strictly a Left woman-I am a Centre Left woman. I would suggest that was the first example of her being almost right, which would be the best I could say about her contribution.

Senator Newman did not tell us about her great quote about her commitment to women. I have reminded her of it before and she always springs up and says that she has been misrepresented. At the risk of that happening again, I will say that Senator Newman has said on the record that in times of economic difficulties women in sport should not be getting funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said you had your priorities wrong.

—She did not. I remember quoting her directly at the time. Those words bore in my brain because I have an interest in women's sport. I was fascinated that apparently she is not committed to funding in sport being equitable. She could have made a much better case if she had talked about not funding sport at a time of economic hardship, but she wanted to take out women's funding. That is a fine definition of her attitudes to women. The best I could say is that her attitudes are confused.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman tried to tell us a lot of things, including the price of items in shops. Senator Newman has Senator Walters's remarkable capacity to insist she knows what other people think, much less what they intend, and never bothers to quote what they say. To suggest across the chamber that I would not know the price of certain goods or, even worse, that I might never have gone to buy them is pretty risky stuff. I will resist asking her who does the shopping in her house. She will tell me that as she is a restaurateur, or at least engaged in that business, she has to keep an eye on the price of some of those items. I might ask her how many times she serves baked beans in her restaurant. The point is that it is a glorious irrelevancy. If she wants to make the point she can do so, but I must say that it does not go to the issue under debate. Whoever does the shopping in any household is quite irrelevant to whether or not people are suffering under the impact of this Government's programs.

It is also clear that Senator Newman did not want to run through these programs. Senator Reid wanted to say that the Government has done a whole lot of things, but they are programs; they are not really a serious commitment to women. It is this Government that has put women on the agenda. It is this Government that keeps women on the agenda and it is this Government that has made all the difference, the absolutely huge difference, to women in this country.

I will go to some of those points. Senator Giles spelt out some of them and she was absolutely right. There are more women in education; there are more girls staying on to year 12; there are more women in universities and tertiary institutions; and there is a higher participation of women in the work force than ever before. Women have the jobs, the education and the better opportunities under this Government and its specific to them programs. They have not been excluded; they have been included. Because sometimes they are not dealt with satisfactorily under the title of citizen, it is this Government that has put women on the agenda and made sure that they do have equality of opportunity and equality of training opportunities-equality of options for all sorts of things in their lives.

As Senator Giles also said, one of the most important things that we know confronts women is the issue of income security. The Opposition spokespeople that I have heard today have suggested that our pension changes have not been of any benefit to women. I do not know how they can argue that our pension system is not good enough but that women would be better on it than getting into the work force. I say to the Opposition: get your thinking clear; you are a confused lot.

The Government has finally got pensions to over 25 per cent of average weekly earnings (AWE)-a promise in Australian Labor Party policy for years. That has been achieved and the figure is now about 25.8 per cent of AWE. What is more, those pensions are now indexed. All other payments to families and women, particularly through the social security system, are now indexed. For the first time ever we have set benchmarks for the cost of children. Those benchmarks are indexed and I challenge the Opposition to stand up and say whether or not it would withdraw those benchmarks. When it gets into government-if it ever gets into government-will it withdraw benchmarks for the value of payments on behalf of the care of those children?

This Government established the Child Support Agency and introduced the tremendous child support legislation that goes with it. Senator Newman often suggests that she and the Opposition are the holders of the flame of the true family. It is this Government that has required fathers to pay for the maintenance of their children because it sees the importance of that responsibility by fathers to and on behalf of their children. I take Senator Powell's point that on some occasions the Government has been able to introduce such legislation with Opposition support. I note that the Opposition supported that legislation although, as is often the case, it put in a tedious little amendment that did not make much difference.

Going right to Senator Reid's point about poverty traps, the family allowance supplement was introduced to deal precisely with that issue. It is precisely because we recognise poverty traps that we understand the challenge for people coming off pension or benefit and going back into the work force and the costs entailed for such people. Therefore we introduced the family allowance supplement to go to working families on low income. It was introduced precisely to deal with poverty traps. The fact that we have not dealt with them all, or have not completely eliminated them, should not be used as an argument against the fact that we have done so much work and that we recognise the issue and put it on the agenda as being vitally important.

Over our time in office-I am not prepared to run through all the figures at this time-we have also introduced dramatic tax cuts. Those tax cuts have fallen most on people on low income, which is of course where we will find women in the work force in large part. Sitting in this chamber this afternoon is Senator Cook, the Minister for Industrial Relations. If anyone doubts what we have done in the work force I can outline some of the measures that have been introduced by Minister Cook.

TALK.START.PARA: —He reminds us every day in Question Time.

—If he does so every day in Question Time, it means that Senator Kernot has not yet grasped it. This Government has ratified International Labour Organisation Convention 156 to make a genuine commitment to the needs of workers with family responsibilities. As an employer, the Government has given the lead in employment conditions for workers with family responsibilities. It has done a number of things: it introduced permanent part time work in employment in 1983; it has provided 12 weeks paid maternity leave, plus additional unpaid leave for up to a total of 52 weeks, and, as Senator Giles said, that has now been extended to cover paternity leave. Senator Newman wanted to dismiss what she so disparagingly called the so-called sisters, but it is women who have sought equity in terms of changing a single mother's pension to a single parent's pension even though, as has been said, until recently well above 90 per cent of single parents were mothers. It is also true that we see the equity of parental leave, not confinement-if the Senate will allow a good pun-or maternity leave for women only.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has recognised the income security that comes with having jobs-employment. It is this Government that has put the bridging courses in place that Senator Reid wanted to dismiss. The Government introduced the jobs, education and training program for sole parents to get women who are on the pension into the work force through training schemes. The Government recognises the challenge for women who have been out of the work force for some time. It recognises the difficulty for people who are out of the work force and whose skills have now been passed over. It is this Government that has recognised all those factors and has put the programs, the policies and the dollar commitment in place.

The Opposition does not tell us what it would do. It simply says that life is tough. I would not have thought that any case was argued very well by the price of baked beans. But if Senator Newman wishes to stick to the price of baked beans, along with her women in sport crack, I suggest that is a fair measure of her commitment. It is not a sufficient analysis of the issue. It does not do justice to this Government's commitment to women. I would like to hear her say whether she would continue this Government's initiatives for women or whether she would withdraw them. If one understands what Senator Reynolds had to say about the Opposition's policy, the Opposition does not know what policies it wants for women; it would be inclined to withdraw them.

Senator Giles made the very potent point that the Opposition will introduce a consumption tax. What will such a tax do to people on fixed incomes? What will it do to people who have restricted or limited savings? What will it do to inflation, to the price of goods and services and to the general economic situation of this country? I do not know that the Opposition is clear about it and I do not know how serious its commitment is. It comes in here and tells us that we have no policies for women-we have; the record is there-and that the economic situation is very difficult for women. We have the policies and the backup to assist women.

The best the Opposition could offer in that interesting document was 1 1/2 inches on child-care. I am still not clear what the Opposition wants to do with child-care nor where it sees the place of women in the scheme of things at all. Senator Reid suggested that the difference between the Government and the Opposition in child-care policies is that the Opposition sees it as an economic issue whereas, she claims, the Labor Government sees it as a welfare issue. Senator Reid did not write the draft child-care policy of this Government.

I have to say that I was one of its authors along with Wendy Fatin, and our arguments from the very beginning were that child-care is an economic issue and that that is the only way it properly can be seen. It is about income security for women and it is about justice in terms of opportunities and assistance for women who are at home and for women in the work force. That is how it has been argued. If Senator Reid does not want to see it that way, that is a measure of her blinkered view. It is not a welfare matter; it is a matter of justice and economic support for women who choose to be in the work force or to look for occasional care when they are in the voluntary work force or doing any of the other things women choose to do.

One of the problems the Opposition has is that this Government actually believes in those words `choice for women'. The Government actually believes that women should have the opportunity to exercise choice. The Opposition believes women have one role, that is, the role in the family and there they shall be confined by the Opposition and the Opposition's preferred policies. If the Opposition seriously believes in choice, it must support the Government's initiatives for women. Those initiatives are comprehensive and they go to a whole range of issues of concern for women and areas of women's life.

During the debate, I heard Senator Newman somehow getting onto hormonal replacement therapy. I sincerely hope that was not a plea for need or something. I do not know what it had to do with anything. It certainly was not argued in terms of costs nor in terms of who was missing out or what. I have to say that, if the Opposition's health policy goes to hormonal replacement, that is a limited view. I would much rather ask the Opposition to tell us whether it is serious about introducing the voucher system, which would increase the cost of health for the majority of Australians, ensure that many people are not covered under private insurance and push up public expenditure.

This is the Opposition that says it will lower public expenditure. Dr Hewson wants smaller government. But at least an extra $1 billion worth of costs will be incurred under the Opposition's proposed changes to Medicare. I think that that is a more significant issue to tackle in the health area than hormonal replacement. If there is an issue of concern about hormonal replacement, as with breast cancer screening and a lot of other things, this Government will look at it and will implement the necessary and proper changes.

TALK.START.PARA: — `We will do a study'. That is about your measure. That's all you do all the time.

—Very likely, because we actually prefer to work on facts than on preferred fiction. We always prefer to have our facts to hand. On the eve of International Women's Day the women of Australia do, as my colleagues on this side of the chamber said, have much to celebrate. Fortunately those things are in place to assist them through these tough times and to help them when we come out of these tough times to continue to exercise their options as full and participating citizens in this country. Their talents and skills will not go to waste.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —So often in debates of public importance speakers lose sight of the impact of the matter under debate, which in this case is the impact of the economic mismanagement of the Hawke Labor Government on Australian women.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to draw the attention of the Senate to the plight of those women who have to cope with husbands who have lost their jobs and all the associated trauma within that household on the family, on the woman, and also on the man as a result of this economic mismanagement. Tens of thousands of people have been thrown out of work.

As time is limited tonight, I would like to draw attention to all those women who work part time in various occupations right across this country, whose retrenchments are not shown up in the statistics. These women are often forced to go to work for economic reasons, for social reasons and for their own economic well-being. They are forced to go out to work to supplement the family budget and to enable them to finance a decent education for their children. As a result of this economic mismanagement these women now find themselves in dire economic straits because they lose contact with the community and they lose income. What will happen to their children and their standard of living? They are in strife.

TALK.START.PARA: —And their mortgage?

—As my colleague mentioned, how will they cope with meeting the cost of their mortgages? How will they meet the cost of rising prices and their grocery bills? Their standard of living is appalling and that is due to the economic mismanagement of the Hawke Labor Government and the impact it is having, particularly on women. I therefore congratulate my colleague who has taken a very strong stance in enhancing the role of Australian women. I congratulate her.
—Order! The time allotted for consideration of the matter of public importance has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the second annual report of the Australian Institute of Health. If anyone wishes to get an overview of health care in Australia today, the document produced by the Australian Institute of Health is an outstanding one. I have written to Professor Peter Karmel, who is Chairman of that body, congratulating him on it.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I think it is important to note that the board of the Australian Institute of Health is totally unrepresentative of health bodies in this country. It is composed of three nominees of the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council, the Australian Statistician and his nominee, the Secretary to the Department of Community Services and Health and his nominee, three nominees of the Minister for Community Services and Health, the nominee of the Public Health Association, and the nominee of the Consumers Health Forum. Having said that, it is primarily a statistical body, but honourable senators will note from the membership that nobody who delivers health care in this country is represented on that board. The Consumers Health Forum is represented on the board but there is nobody representing the Australian Nursing Federation, the Australian Medical Association, the physiotherapists association or any of the thousands of groups devoted to health care in this country. Action should be taken to include, on the board of the Australian Institute of Health, representatives of the many people who deliver health care in this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I wish to return to some issues that I addressed last time I spoke on the Privacy Commissioner's report. I was concerned that the Privacy Commissioner had raised the issue of documents or information being provided to businesses and organisations by public servants for a fee. The Privacy Commissioner has expressed concern in his report that this practice is difficult to stop and seems to be continuing. On that day I said that I would be moving a motion, which I still intend to do, to ask the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs to address that part of the Privacy Commissioner's report. I shall most probably be moving such a motion on Monday of next week.

I wish to raise another issue which has been drawn to my attention since I last spoke on this matter, and it relates to Medicare information. Mr Wilcox, the General Manager of the Health Insurance Commission, in a submission to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in September 1988, said:

The greatest threat to the security of data comes from people who have access to it and who step outside of their functions to release it. There is one example of this in the many issues included in the Committee's hearings on 11 July and that relates to the disclosure of doctors' incomes in 1985. Here the only recourse is after the event through punitive actions contained within the legislation. The problem, irrespective of whether the information is computerised or not, is identifying who released the information and securing sufficient evidence to invoke the legislative provisions.

They were the same sorts of problems that appear to have been occurring with the Department of Social Security information that has been leaked and provided. In the examples I gave when I last spoke on this report I said that Medicare information had been available to credit organisations, organisations providing information to debt collectors. I said that, for $20 a hit, a bit of information would be provided from Medicare.

It is particularly important that I raise this matter at the moment, when the Government has announced that it will improve the integrity of the Medicare system by reissuing everyone with a Medicare card. That has raised this issue in my mind, and I have also been concerned about the cost of the reissuing of Medicare cards. I wonder whether it would have been necessary if better procedures had been in place to purge Medicare card records. An example of this appeared in Column Eight of the Sydney Morning Herald on 6 March this year. It made me realise that the system needed looking at long ago and that the Government is now trying to close the door after the horse has bolted, and it will cost us a fortune. The item in Column Eight read:

No wonder there are 300,000 more people on Medicare cards than the total population of Australia. After a lecturer's purse was stolen from her office at Sydney University last week, she phoned Medicare to say her card was among the things missing. Never mind, she was told, just go into a Medicare office and get another. No effort was made to cancel the stolen card. Make it 300,001.

The Minister may say that the reason they are not bothering any more now is that the Government intends to reissue the cards and will not do anything more about it. I wonder whether that practice has been going on. The issue raised by the Privacy Commissioner is the very great issue of public servants releasing information to which they are privy and which is not appropriate to be released and where it is difficult to track down who has acted in this way and to punish them. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES LAW REVIEW COMMITTEE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the documents.

The Companies and Securities Law Review Committee, as such, no longer exists and the role of the Committee has been taken up by the new Companies and Securities Advisory Committee, which has a much more proactive law reform function than the former Committee, and the Australian Democrats welcome that. The new Committee has already produced major policy initiatives, including the vital questions of directors' remuneration, insider trading and regulation of unit trusts. There is still much to be done to repair Australia's corporate reputation. The commitment to assist the Government to remove loopholes from company law is certainly given by the Australian Democrats, and we expect some action by the Government in this area.

One very disturbing report which has recently been made to my office concerns the Adelaide office of the Australian Securities Commission. A member of the public claims to have paid his annual company fee and it was acknowledged to have been paid on 23 January. However, the cheque has still not been cashed by the Commission. He was astounded and inquired about the fact that the cheque had not been presented. He was told that it probably would not be cashed until late April because there is a huge backlog of work. Clearly this is a matter that the appropriate Minister should address. It at least indicates some administrative laxness and lack of organisation in that office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is in only one sense a timely report. In every other sense it is most untimely. The report is for the year to June 1990 and it has been delivered to the Senate only in March this year. That is not timely reporting. It would have been nice to have been able to get a feeling as to where the delay occurred, if Mr Harris, in conveying his report to the Minister, had put a date on his letter. It may have been some time ago; I notice that the auditor's report is dated 18 December. We have to find out who is delaying presentation of these reports so that we know whom to blame and whom to give a bit of curry to. When the Chairman of a body such as this does not bother putting a date on his letter, it does not do anyone any good and does not help us.

SPEECH.PARA: However, it is timely in another sense. It is timely in the sense that the Sydney bid for the Olympic Games in the year 2000 has now well and truly become Australia's bid. The Federal Government has shown its preparedness to support that bid in both a financial and a manpower sense. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is on the Sydney bid committee, as is the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), and I am his alternate on that committee. That committee met for the first time yesterday in Sydney. The outstanding calibre of that committee and the amount of work that has already been done suggest that this bid will be outstanding. I think that it has an excellent prospect of success.

This bid by Australia for the Olympics-which, of course, will be held in nine years time-will not come up for decision until 1993. One would hope that by then a lot of positive decisions would have been made so that the Australian Sports Commission-which, of course, is heavily involved in the elite sports program, which relates entirely to Olympic sports-clearly will have a significant role to play in preparing Australian athletes for what we hope to see as the Sydney Olympics of the year 2000.

However, there are many other things that have to be done in this Olympic area before we can see a successful Games in Australia. For example, it is up to the Government to determine what it is going to do about the Newington Armaments Depot which adjoins the proposed Olympic area. The presently unused part of the Newington Armaments Depot will be required for some elements of the Olympic sports centre.

I hope that the Government will proceed at a faster rate than it has in the past to do something about getting rid of the Newington Armaments Depot from its present site, which is in the centre of the western suburbs of Sydney; roughly in the geographic and demographic centre of Sydney. It is totally inappropriate for it to be there. My concern is that the presence of such an armaments depot so close to an Olympic centre would not be helpful at all to the bid. Whilst it is recognised that for some years now the Navy has wanted to move that armaments depot to Jervis Bay, the Government appears to have been putting a great deal of difficulties in the Navy's way.

However, the challenge now in front of the Australian Sports Commission is to do what it can to prepare Australia's athletes for that Olympic Games. I certainly wish it well in its endeavours. I wish the Sydney bid well in its attempts to get the Games for the year 2000. I wish all Australia's Olympic athletes the best possible good fortune in the run-up to those Games so that Australia can show the rest of the world exactly what it can do in Olympic sports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly to this annual report. I comment first by noting that the Australian Sports Drug Agency has now made the appropriate appointments. I note that Professor Peter Baume has been made the Chairman of that agency. That is a very wise and responsible choice. He is eminently suited by virtue of his scholastic qualifications, his particular interest in drugs and his interest in sport.
—His standing as a bowler.

—His standing as a bowler and also his all-round political skills. There is a lot to be said, frankly, from either side of politics, for having somebody who has had experience in these matters, in finding his way through the bureaucracy--
—What job do you want?

—I do not want a job; I have plans to stay here for at least another two years. I might say-and I will save it for another time-that I cannot say the same for the rest of the appointments. There was one particular appointment to which I will refer later. I qualify that by saying that I have no objections to ex-politicians or the wives of politicians being appointed to positions provided there is some merit and it is not just on the basis of a job for an ex-boy.
—Or girl.

—Or girl. In respect of the matter that I heard Senator Baume referring to as I came in-the Sydney bid-I hope that this bid for once gets support from all Australian Olympic federations. I remind the Senate of what is well known as the night of the long knives, where every identifiable person who voted for Melbourne against Sydney was singled out, knifed off and removed from the committee. That was retribution for voting for Melbourne and not Sydney. There was considerable heartache and pain. It was something well known to those who were ultimately voting on a choice of a city for the Games that there was less than full and unqualified support for Melbourne. I hope that on this occasion we have full support. I notice already how some of the procedures of the past have been circumvented. There was an open bid, and the various capitals of Australia did not have to put up a bid of their own in the same way as Brisbane did for the Commonwealth Games and Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane all did for the 1992 Olympic Games.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the matters that trouble me is what I see as an incestuous relationship developing in sport in Australia; particularly at the administration level. It is more concerning now than it ever has been because the funding for all elite sport really now comes through the officials of the Australian Olympic Federation who happen to be also on the board of the Australian Sports Commission and who happen to be associated-very many of them-with certain elite sports. In my view, we have that unhealthy circumstance where people are finding themselves beholden for funds for their sport to an elite group of people in sport in Australia generally. It is one of the reasons that I have always opposed the allocation of funds for elite sport being in the hands of the Olympic Federation. However, I will save that for another time.

I observe that the Australian Sports Commission now seems to be better placed to fulfil the obligations and responsibilities which it has as a result of the appointment of Mr Ferguson and having some proper direction, leadership and, not least, good management. I am certain that we will not see the imbroglio and confusion which has resulted from previous events. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 March, on motion by Senator Reid:
That the Senate take note of the document.
Debate (on motion by Senator Brownhill) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes the overwhelming votes in Latvia and Estonia on 3 March 1991 and in Lithuania on 9 February 1991 in favour of independence from the Soviet Union;
(b) calls upon the Government of the Soviet Union to respect the results of these referendums and to concede the right of independence to the Baltic States;
(c) demands that the Soviet Government unequivocally renounce the use of force in its dealings with the Baltic states and respect normal modes of dealing between states; and
(d) believes the Australian Government should join with other like-minded Governments to press the Soviet Union to give early practical effect to the three referendums.

I do not wish to speak at length on this motion today, but I do hope that it will be carried. I think it is important to encourage the people of the Baltic states of Latvia, Estonia, and Lithuania in their continual fight for freedom.

Mr Deputy President, you will probably recall that shortly after the staggering vote in Lithuania this Senate passed a motion noting that vote and calling upon the Soviet Union to facilitate the independence of Lithuania. Subsequent votes took place in Latvia and Estonia and also produced quite staggering results, particularly in Latvia which has a significant Russian population. It indicated beyond any doubt that the three Baltic states do desire a return to independence. It is the view, certainly on this side of the chamber, that they should be entitled to their wish.

The Opposition parties in this country have never accepted the de jure incorporation of the Baltic states into the Soviet Union. We have stood with them in their long fight for freedom. We have observed their courage at home in their own nations and throughout the world as they have maintained their fight, often in very difficult circumstances and, of course, they now feel that they are so much closer, but yet still so far.

We, therefore, in this motion call upon the Government of the Soviet Union to respect the results. So far the Soviet Union has been unwilling to do so, which we very much regret. So far President Gorbachev seems to be determined, at any cost, to hold the Baltic states within the Soviet Union despite the wish of the Baltic people. For someone who is a Nobel Peace Prize winner, that is something that we particularly regret.

The Baltic states were incorporated under the Molotov-Ribbentrop pact, a moment that we should continue to condemn. It is a barbaric pact in international history. It is a wrong that needs to be righted even if it has taken so long to do so.

In this motion we demand that the Soviet Government give the Baltic people their freedom. In the meantime, we demand that the Soviet Union renounce the use of force in dealing with the Baltic peoples because, as honourable senators are no doubt aware, force has been applied in recent times in each of the three Baltic states. Those who have resisted that force of Soviet troops have been killed and injured. It is a particularly depressing and regrettable event in what is supposed to be the evolvement of a new world order.

The last part of this motion is a critical part because we recognise that the Australian Government by itself can only do so much, but we do believe that if it were prepared to join with other nation states-perhaps encourage other nation states to come together to provide one voice particularly in the international fora, the United Nations, and at every opportunity to join together to press the Soviet Union-it is more likely that that united voice will have some effect. That is why in this motion, in paragraph (d), we seek that the Senate resolve that the Australian Government should join with other like-minded governments to press the Soviet Union to give early practical effect to the three referendums.

As I said at the outset, I trust that this motion will be carried because although some of us perhaps think that these motions do not count for a great deal, they actually do count in the eyes of the Baltic people. They are seen as a sign that the Australian parliamentary representatives are prepared to stand with the Baltic people in their continuing struggle for freedom and, therefore, it is particularly meaningful to them. I therefore urge that this motion be adopted by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats commend Senator Hill for moving this motion and we will be supporting it today. Along with many other Australians, we have also been deeply moved by the determined way in which the people of the three Baltic states have sought to assert their sovereignty through the overwhelming votes of independence which have been cast in the referendums held in the last two months. Anyone who has an interest in events in the Baltic states just in this century will know that their struggle for independence is not a recent one. Some 50 years ago Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia were sold off as part of some illegal deal between Hitler's Germany and Stalin's Russia. Ever since, the people of all three Baltic states have fought every inch of the way against enormous odds: against the repression that for many years typified the Soviet Union; at times against the indifference of the west; and in all probability against their own feelings of futility and hopelessness.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite everything, the outlook for the Baltic peoples is more hopeful today than it has been at any other time over the last 50 years. However, we are under no illusion that in order for the three Baltic states to achieve their goal of independence as expressed in these referendums, much more will need to be done to arrive at that outcome. It is appropriate, therefore, that the Australian Senate requests the Soviet Union in the strongest possible terms to respect the results of these referendums and to finally and totally acknowledge the independence that rightfully belongs to the Baltic states.

Unfortunately, the Soviet Union has so far shown that it is unwilling to heed the wishes of the Baltic peoples. We all recall the recent economic blockade of Lithuania. In fact, an estimated half a million Soviet troops are still stationed in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. In the past, the Soviet Union has sought to intimidate the independence movements by sealing their borders and imposing banking and diplomatic blockades on the republics.

It appears to be common these days for internal import and export contracts with the Baltics not to be honoured in Moscow. We should ask whether this is indicative of a policy aimed at non-cooperation and of destabilising the Baltic economies.

In addition to this, since the beginning of this year we have witnessed the vicious military crackdown by the Soviet Union in Lithuania where a number of people have been killed and hundreds injured, simply because they gathered in the streets of their capital to demand their freedom. That sort of behaviour on the part of the Soviet Union is totally unacceptable and deserves to be condemned. We hope that we will never again see a repetition of the Soviet military crackdown which took place in January this year.

It needs to be said, of course, that what the Baltic states are seeking to do is not so much to establish independence, but rather to restore an independent state which has been illegally suppressed by a foreign power. Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania do not seek to secede from the Soviet Union because, in fact, they have never legally joined the Soviet Union. This is the foundation of the declarations of independence which all three Baltic states made earlier last year, and which have now been endorsed by the people voting in these referendums.

As I said before, membership of the Soviet Union for the three Baltic states was forced upon them by the notorious Molotov-Ribbentrop pact of 1939. The people of the Baltics were never asked for their opinion about this union and, to their credit, they have never accepted it. Another irony in the Baltics' struggle for independence is that the Soviet Union's own Congress of People's Deputies had itself, in December 1989, recognised that the 1940 annexation of the Baltic republics was illegal and invalid.

In contrast to the 1940 annexation, the referendum votes held in Lithuania on 9 February and in Latvia and Estonia on 3 March were democratic as well as legitimate, and a true indicator of the people's wishes. These votes have been overwhelming declarations of independence. They follow the elections of last year where pro-independence candidates gained big majorities under slogans of democracy, independence and justice in all three Baltic republics.

All three referendum votes drew huge turnouts and, even though there was some doubt over which way the Russian and Polish minorities in all three Baltic states would vote, I understand that in all three a significant proportion of the Russian, Polish and German populations did, in fact, vote in favour of independence. For instance, in Lithuania, where only 80 per cent of the republic's population is Lithuanian, 90 per cent of the population voted for independence, implying that the independence movement there has significant support from the non-Lithuanian minority. This calls strongly into question allegations that most Russians in the Baltic states feel persecuted and need to be defended by Russian troops against the nationalists or separatists who are running the republics. Clearly, this is not the case.

Finally, I would like to address some of the things which the Democrats believe this Government could be doing to give better practical effect to these referendums. As the Senate is aware, the Baltic peoples, in voting the way they have and in previously making declarations of independence, are appealing to the outside world to help them restore their independence and become full members of the world community.

It is most unfortunate that President Gorbachev has denounced the referendum results, claiming that they represent an attempt to obstruct his own referendum on the preservation of the Soviet Union, set down for 17 March. The Soviet referendum is intended to be the definitive and legally binding vote that will confirm the wish of most Soviet citizens that the Soviet Union should survive in its present boundaries. It asks whether voters want to preserve the country as a union of socialist, sovereign republics. Clearly, such a statement is unacceptable to Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia and probably several other Soviet republics as well. In this context, the Democrats believe that Australia has an obligation to join with other like-minded governments to now press the Soviet Union to give practical effect to those referendum votes.

We note and welcome, for instance, a vote by the Parliament of Iceland on 11 February this year to recognise Lithuania as an independent state and to set up diplomatic ties as soon as possible in the capital of Vilnius. Indeed, the Scandinavian countries have understandably been the most responsive to the Baltic states' collective desire for independence. Nevertheless, that should not preclude more distant countries such as Australia showing the same spirit of goodwill to the Baltic peoples and assisting them to achieve their stated goal of outright independence.

The Baltic states are on the road to full and complete sovereignty, and Western countries such as Australia should recognise as well as encourage the Baltic states on that road as much as practicable. The Australian Government could, for instance, do more to facilitate a greater number of joint trading ventures direct with the Baltic republics. We could also consider the export of wool and wheat stockpiles in the context of new sales trade agreements.

The question of Baltic independence is not an internal matter for the Soviet Union. In spite of Soviet opposition and some embarrassing indifference on the part of some Western nations, we believe that one day Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania will re-establish themselves as self-governing states. Australia should declare its full support for that goal and do all it can to make sure that it is achieved. We commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I want to add my words of support for the motion moved by Senator Hill, on behalf of the Opposition, concerning the Baltic states. This is a subject about which I feel very strongly. I think it will be a very important achievement if, again, the Senate expresses its fullest support for the legitimate aspirations of the peoples of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia for their freedom and independence.

SPEECH.PARA: The Baltic nations are in a unique position. Of all the 15 republics of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, they are the three that were illegally annexed by Moscow into the Soviet Union. Lenin gave Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia their independence in 1918. At that time he said, on behalf of the Soviet Union, that the Baltic states would never again be the subject of territorial claims by Moscow. That independence was granted and for 20 years the Baltic states flourished as free and independent nations. They were members of the League of Nations. They competed in their own independent right in the Olympic Games that were held during that period. In every way they were legitimately free, independent, sovereign states just as our nation is today.

As has been said, that came to an end in August 1939 with the signing of the notorious Molotov-Ribbentrop pact-a peace treaty, a peace pact or a non-aggressive pact between the Soviet Union and Germany in an attempt by Hitler to fend off the risk of war on his eastern front at the time that he was about to go to war with Britain and Europe. One of two secret protocols attached to that non-aggressive pact annexed the Baltic nations to Moscow within the sphere of influence- sharing that was contained in the agreement. It is only in the last 12 months that Moscow has been prepared to accept even the existence of those secret protocols, despite the fact that they have been published around the world in recent years.

Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia face a totally different situation from any of the other Soviet republics. They are not legitimate members of the Soviet Union. They have never been legally incorporated into the Soviet Union and we, along with the rest of the Western world, have always stated quite firmly the illegality of the action taken in 1939 and consummated in 1940 and 1941 by the Soviets.

The motion moved by Senator Hill notes, first of all, the overwhelming votes in Latvia and Estonia in the last week or so, preceded a month earlier by a vote in Lithuania, in favour of independence from the Soviet Union. It was not surprising that the vote was so overwhelming in Lithuania because 80 per cent of the population of Lithuania is ethnic Lithuanian, only 10 per cent is ethnic Russian and the rest is essentially ethnic Polish. Of course, the expectation was that the vote in Lithuania would be very strongly for independence.

In Latvia and Estonia the situation was different. Only about one half of the population of Latvia is ethnic Latvian. Much of the remaining half is ethnic Russian. Despite that, something like 80 per cent of the turnout-and it was a very heavy turnout with in excess of 80 per cent of people participating-at the referendum last week voted for independence. There must have been a very large number of ethnic Russians who supported that vote for independence. The position was similar in Estonia on the same day where only 65 per cent, or thereabouts, of the Estonian population is ethnic Estonian, and most of the rest are Russian.

The people of the republics of the Baltic nations have voted overwhelmingly that they want to be free and independent. The first part of Senator Hill's motion calls for the noting of that overwhelming expression of view by the people of those three nations. Therefore, it also calls upon the Government of the Soviet Union to respect the results of those referendums, which of course the Soviet Government has up to date refused to do. As yet there is no indication that it will do so. But there is no shadow of a doubt that those referendums were legitimate; they were properly conducted and they reflected truly the aspirations of the peoples of the three nations.

It is despicable and reprehensible-almost unbelievable-that over recent months the Soviet Government has used brute force to quell the independence move in each of the three states-Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, which I visited only 18 months ago. About 15 people were killed by Soviet brute force. Others in Latvia and Estonia have also been killed. Senator Hill's motion therefore demands that the Soviet Government unequivocally renounce the use of force in its dealings with the Baltic states and respect the normal modes of dealing between states.

Finally, and most importantly, the motion expresses the belief that the Australian Government should join with other like-minded governments to press the Soviet Union to give early practical effect to the three referendums. Personally, I believe that there is much that the Australian Government and the Australian nation could and should be doing to put more pressure on the Soviet Union to recognise and act on the legitimate interests and aspirations of the Baltic peoples. It is not enough just to express the sentiments that have been expressed, for example, in the motion moved by Senator Gareth Evans I think yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gave notice of.

—The motion that Senator Gareth Evans gave notice of yesterday does not really call on Australia to do anything; it just calls on the Soviet Union to do things. The rights of the Baltic peoples in this matter are so unequivocally correct and legitimate that it behoves all free Western and other democratic nations that believe in the rule of international law, that believe in basic human rights and basic proper relations between free and independent people, to make a much greater effort than we have been making in terms of pressure within the councils around the world in whatever way we can to press the aspirations, the legitimate wishes, of the Baltic people for freedom and independence. Therefore I very much hope that the Government will support this motion. The only difference is in the final clause. Senator Evans's first three clauses are identical with those in Senator Hill's motion. I am glad that the Australian Democrats are supporting Senator Hill's motion. I commend Senator Hill for moving this motion. It deserves the full support of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate the Government's support for the substance of this motion and to indicate that we will not vote against it. The Government's support for the substance should have been amply evident in the kinds of public statements that we have made, particularly in the answer I gave in Question Time just a couple of days ago indicating our response to the referendums and our very strong desire that that clearly expressed aspiration of the Baltic states people be rapidly translated into recognition of their right to independence by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics authorities. I do not think it is necessary for me to add now to what has already been eloquently said by other honourable senators in the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a reservation about the form in which this motion is cast. That has been referred to by Senator Short. On balance the Government would prefer that a resolution coming out of the Senate directly address its target audience-in other words, that it call upon the Soviet Union give early practical effect to the referendums. Our preferred language in this respect was embodied in the alternative motion, which now appears at No. 131 on the Notice Paper. However, since the Australian Democrats have indicated that they are prepared to support Senator Hill's motion, it would be churlish of me to insist on the distinction at this point and, moreover, a waste of time. So I do not do that. In any event, I do not want to detract from the significance of this motion as a clear expression of the views of a House of the Australian Parliament.

However, I repeat the point that it is preferable for motions of this kind to make a direct appeal to a foreign government where in fact it is a foreign government that is the subject of the motion in question. It might surprise honourable senators to know-but it is the case-that when these motions are passed, they do have an impact. Such resolutions are translated to the governments in question through official government processes, parliamentary processes. They are seen as an important expression of national will, national opinion, by the countries in question. They do have their effect. As a result it is important that, where it is appropriate to do so, the language of the resolution be couched in terms which makes the maximum impact on that audience-in this instance, to address the basic appeal, not so much to the Soviet Union but to the Australian Government to do things, makes it more of an in-house domestic kind of resolution rather than one that stands on its own feet as an appeal from a chamber of the Australian Parliament to an important international target audience. Stylistically, presentationally, in terms of its impact, there are some advantages in putting it in those terms.

In this instance there is no real further ground for preferring to change the terms of the Opposition motion.
