Quite often the Australian Government will resist the accuracy of suggestions in notices of motion that we initiate action or do something in some certain area because the clear implication is that we have not already done something whereas, in many of these situations, we have already initiated dialogue, we have already set in train some actions, we have already made representations and we have already pursued the issue. In those circumstances, we, as a Government, regard it somewhat inappropriate that we be called upon by the Senate to do something that we are already doing. That point arises quite often in the notices of motion that are given in this place. That is one of the reasons why the Government often has difficulty in accepting them simply at face value and wants to reshape them in certain ways.

That leads me to the final point that gets me to my feet on this occasion, and that is to say something about the process of treating notices of motion in relation to foreign affairs matters. In recent times-and there has been some acceleration of the practice-a number of notices of motion have been moved in terms which are genuinely desiring to get an expression of agreed parliamentary support for some particular cause passed by the Senate.

They are not just moved as a basis for scoring a political point against the Government. They are not being moved to create the foundation for a lengthy debate maybe two or three months hence, or maybe not at all. They are being moved because the senator in question genuinely wants to get a parliamentary expression, a senatorial expression, of concern of some issue on the record. They are moved often in the hope and, indeed, the expectation that the Government will accordingly be prepared to let the motion pass through the next day, simply on the nod, treated as formal.

The Government is prepared to cooperate in that process, when appropriate. There are many occasions when it is appropriate. Indeed, a resolution about the Baltic referendums, in the substantive terms of that moved, is appropriate this week. Indeed, a resolution about Sri Lanka, in particular one linked to the tragic assassination of Mr Wijeratne, is appropriate this week. It was also appropriate this week-although we do not want to overdo it, in terms of using the impact of these motions-to say something about the coup in Thailand and the Government's response to it.

The Government does not resist the appropriateness of these sorts of resolutions going through. However, we do have difficulty-I have tried to explain this to my counterpart and to the other parties here-with constantly finding ourselves confronted with notices of motion already given which are then the subject of representations to us just to accept them and to declare them formal, when we may have reservations of one sort or another. That then gets us into a scramble situation of seeking to move amendments or to get the motion withdrawn in its present form and, by leave, put in in some substituted form.

Accordingly, we have taken the position that we are prepared to consider seriously and on their merits proposals for motions of this kind, provided there has been some prior discussion, some prior consultation, about the terms of the motion. It is not just a matter of the Government getting on its dignity and on its hind legs and worrying about nitpicking points. It is because we know the impact that these motions have overseas, because we want to maximise that impact and because we do not want to send any wrong or inappropriate signals that we do need to look at the drafting of these things very carefully. My plea to honourable senators is that if they want this practice to continue-and I agree that it is a desirable practice to have these things on the record-they get into some type of consultative mode with us before the notice of motion goes down so that, if possible, we can reach agreement on the text.

Very often, in my experience, it is very easily possible to reach such agreement. If we cannot reach agreement on the text, honourable senators have the right to move the motion in the terms they want, the right to put it on the Notice Paper and the right to pick it up in General Business time that week, if they want to give it that priority, or at some later stage. The Government is not denying that. We are perfectly happy to debate each of these motions on their merit in the terms in which they are moved.

I am simply saying that, where honourable senators are really about a non- partisan exercise in getting an agreed expression of opinion on the parliamentary record, it would be very helpful to the Government in the conduct of our international relations and in terms of getting these things right if we could go through a consultative process. I have to indicate that, unless we do have some such prior consultation, I simply will be unable to accept these motions as formal business and deal with them on the nod.

I have already communicated that position to the parties. I have made an exception for it this week in the context of Senator Hill's Thailand motion, but I do not really want to make any exceptions in the future. I hope that it will be understood from the nature of the explanation I am giving that I am not trying to score partisan points; I am just trying to describe the difficulties of having to scramble to pick up the pieces of terms of notices of motion which are basically okay but just need a little attention and reshaping to get them into a form which we will be happy to support and to see endorsed.

For another illustration of what I mean, I mention that specifically also in the context of the Sri Lankan motion, which is before us at the moment and which, I understand, Senator Hill proposes to adjourn. The Sri Lankan motion that appears on the Notice Paper is one, in Senator Hill's formulation of it, which not only expresses our deep regret at the assassination of the Defence Minister, not only recognises that the scale of human suffering is such that an immediate peaceful solution is imperative in Sri Lanka, but goes on to talk of the desirability of the Commonwealth initiating a particular peace process here.

There just is some difficulty about the Government supporting a motion of that kind, giving a formal endorsement to it, allowing the thing to go through on the nod. The difficulty-in a couple of sentences-is that we know what the Commonwealth's reaction is to such an exercise because we have already tested it. The Commonwealth has indicated an unwillingness to take this action unless and until it is stimulated by a request from the Sri Lankan Government. We have talked to the Sri Lankan Government about the possibility of it initiating such a request. For the moment that is on hold. It is a delicate issue that we want to keep in the forefront of the possible ways of resolving this conflict.

In this respect, I acknowledge the very helpful contribution that Senator Hill has made in developing the idea of an Australian initiative and indeed a Commonwealth initiative. I do not seek in any way to denigrate or undermine the point that is involved in this. I am just saying that it is difficult and, we believe, inappropriate-maybe even counterproductive-for the Commonwealth Government to be supporting that motion in its present terms and, accordingly, we would want to redraft it. I did suggest a way of redrafting it by way of a notice of motion which I have moved.

This is just another example of the difficulties we have. As a result, it has made it probably impossible, in terms of available time, for the Sri Lankan issue to be now addressed, debated and an expression of Commonwealth opinion put on the record this week. In some ways that is a pity. I have said more than enough. On those issues where we are not trying to score partisan points but to genuinely express an Australian position in the international community on matters of importance to that community, I do think it is important that we get these processes right if we possibly can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In winding up the debate, I thank honourable senators who have supported the motion, in particular, apart from my colleagues, the Australian Democrats; and I thank the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) for indicating that the Government at least supports the sentiment of the motion, even if it is not happy with all of the detail.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge the short lecture that we have had on procedures from the Minister, but I do say, with respect, that he has missed the point somewhat. Part of this issue is that we want to see the Australian Government do more than it has in the past. We want to see it join with other like-minded governments and press the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics at every practical opportunity towards the objective of the motion, towards the Baltic people regaining their freedom. I might say that the Australian Government, although it is in a better position at the moment than it has been, does not have a particularly good record in relation to the Baltic states. We will not forget, and the Baltic people will not forget, the position that the last Labor Government of this country took, which was to recognise their de jure incorporation. A coalition government had to reverse that position. Only recently in the debate on Lithuania, we had to strain-I think Senator Evans will concede-to get the Government even to accept and to use the word `independence' in the motion.

We really want the Government to be more up-front on this issue. We know that it finds some difficulty. We accept that the whole world has a worry about instability in the Soviet Union, the breakdown of law and order and the economic strife, but we do not believe that the answer is to go soft on this issue. We believe the Baltic people are entitled to their freedom and the Australian Government should have the courage to be up-front in saying so, and at every possible opportunity in international fora express that view. That is why we couched this motion in those terms, not only to call upon the Soviet Union to respect the vote of the Baltic people as expressed in these motions but also to call upon the Australian Government to be active in joining with other freedom loving nations to press the Soviet Union to respect the wishes of the Baltic people. I thank those who have participated and commend the motion to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SRI LANKA: ASSASSINATION OF MINISTER FOR DEFENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes with regret the assassination of Sri Lanka's State Minister for Defence, Mr Ranjan Wijeratne, which is part of a continuing cycle of death and devastation in the seven-year civil war which has claimed the lives of at least 14 000 people;
(b) recognises that the scale of human suffering is such that an immediate and urgent solution to the unrest in Sri Lanka is imperative; and
(c) calls on the Commonwealth, as an appropriate organisation, to initiate dialogue with the Sri Lankan Government, with a view to offering its offices to:
(i) seek to negotiate a ceasefire,
(ii) examine whether the Commonwealth could contribute by monitoring the ceasefire and thus giving confidence to the parties involved,
(iii) explore the possibility of a Commonwealth role in peace talks,
(iv) help the parties by identifying the legal, constitutional, institutional and other changes which might be necessary to ensure a lasting peace; and
(v) examine what assistance Sri Lanka would need for its economic reconstruction.

As has been mentioned, I have agreed that the debate be adjourned to some appropriate moment, in particular to allow the Australian Democrats to further consider the detail in paragraph (c) which calls upon the Commonwealth to take action to try to help Sri Lanka towards a settlement of this ongoing tragedy. I do not need to relate to the Senate in the motion that I have put down the circumstances of that tragedy in any detail.

I refer to the fact that it is estimated that this civil war, and I think it is fair to call it a civil war, has claimed the lives of at least 14,000 people, including-as the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) mentioned, and as I have put in the motion as drafted-the assassination of the Sri Lankan Defence Minister only a few days ago, which is just a further step in this ongoing tragedy.

What we have sought to do-and I thank the Minister for his acknowledgment and, in return, I am more than happy to recognise the contribution that the Federal Government has been prepared to make on this issue-is find some process that might break the deadlock that is occurring in Sri Lanka.

It occurred to the Opposition, in seeking to identify an international body that might be able to help, that the Commonwealth might be uniquely well-placed to fill that role. A basis of our reasoning for that was the fact that the nations of southern Asia are part of the Commonwealth and that it is a multi-racial body. It is, in some ways, searching for useful functions. There is a high level process taking place, which started after the Kuala Lumpur Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, to look for new roles and useful tasks for the Commonwealth. It struck me that the Commonwealth was a body with goodwill and experience in these areas that could use such faculties to perhaps assist Sri Lanka in finding a way through the communal differences that are at the basis of this ongoing tragedy.

We floated that idea with a number of Sri Lankan organisations in this country-Tamil organisations and Singhalese organisations-and it received, overall, strong support. We then put it to a number of the non-government organisations (NGOs) in Australia under the umbrella group of the Australian Council for Overseas Aid. The NGOs indicated to us that they thought it was an idea with merit. We then put it to the Secretary-General of the Commonwealth; I did so by telephone and then later personally. The Commonwealth, through him, expressed some interest in the proposal but, as Senator Evans said in the previous debate, it said it believed that the initiative should come first from the Sri Lankan Government.

We called upon the Australian Government to help us in that regard. Senator Evans, when in Sri Lanka last year, raised the issue with President Premadasa. That was followed by correspondence between the President and the Australian Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). As I said a moment ago, we appreciate the fact that the Australian Government was prepared to pick up the idea and try to push it along.

Subsequently, international aid organisations have continued to consider it a worthwhile idea. Civil war has not in any way ended; the saga of death and injury continues. International NGOs have been raising the issue and are suggesting that it is perhaps a mechanism which should be pursued further. I make particular mention of the lobbying that has taken place from the Refugee Council of the United Kingdom, Oxfam of the United Kingdom and CAFOD of the United Kingdom.

Although the Commonwealth, through the head of its secretariat, felt that the initiative must first be taken by the Sri Lankan Government, its own human rights section is particularly interested in the initiative and is encouraging it. I also place on record our appreciation for the very active support that the initiative has received from Amnesty International, which is putting in considerable effort to try to arouse international opinion towards supporting this idea.

It seemed to us that, after the Commonwealth adopted the position that it needed an initiative, or an invitation, from the Sri Lankan Government, the next best step was to encourage Commonwealth nations generally to informally urge the Sri Lankan Government to give that invitation-in much the same way as the Australian Government was prepared to do. We have been in the process, through NGO work particularly, of encouraging Commonwealth governments to support the idea. In turn, the NGOs have also been doing that.

I will not say that the idea has languished. It has not, because there has been quite a lot of international activity for its support. Nevertheless, the Sri Lankan Government has not been prepared, as yet, to issue an invitation. On the other hand, the Commonwealth has not been prepared to take the initiative. That is what I want to achieve through this motion. It will be a good idea if the debate is adjourned because that will give the Australian Government some further time to reflect on it. I think that the Commonwealth can do more in taking an initiative. I accepted, on first blush, the Secretary-General's view that it was necessary to wait for the Sri Lankan Government to call for help, but I think Commonwealth countries can join together and, through their various means, communicate with the Sri Lankan Government and therefore be more active in offering help. Perhaps if they did so the Sri Lankan Government would be more receptive to help.

It is obvious that this conflict will not be resolved through military means; the killing will simply continue for a while. The Sri Lankan Government feels that it is getting the upper hand. Its military will apply pressure for a military solution, but it will not be resolved through military means alone; it will be achieved only through a political solution. That is why we have said that the Commonwealth might be able to help the Sri Lankan Government not only in negotiating a ceasefire but also after that in looking for ways in which it might facilitate or help build bridges between the communities in Sri Lanka. It might be able to help by hosting the peace talks in some way. It can give thought to the legal, constitutional, institutional and other changes that might be necessary to ensure a lasting peace.

In other words, it can bring its international experience to bear to help in that regard. It has that experience; it has the capacity to do so. It can then address the sort of international effort that would be needed to help Sri Lanka with its economic reconstruction because a cost of this ongoing conflict has been an economic one and the enormous suffering which has resulted from the economic consequences of an ongoing civil war, apart from the other consequences.

I will leave it at that, unless honourable senators wish to contribute further. At this stage I suggest we adjourn the debate on this motion until the next day of sitting. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Brownhill, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes with concern:
(i) the recent ANOP survey which shows that farm incomes will fall 67 per cent in 1991, resulting in a drop of $5 billion for the economies of rural towns across Australia,

(ii) that the resumption of wool sales in the week beginning 4 March 1991 has seen a slump of 35 per cent in the price of wool, and that prices of corn, sorghum and other grains have fallen on commodity markets by $30 per tonne,

(iii) that while the Treasurer (Mr Keating) keeps telling us that this is the recession we had to have, the situation in rural Australia is far worse, with banks increasing their farm foreclosures and increasing numbers of farmers left with no other option than to walk away empty handed and bankrupt, and

(iv) that the National Farmers' Federation and NSW Farmers' Association have, on 5 March 1991, handed to the Federal Government 35 000 letters from financially crippled farmers throughout Australia in an effort to demonstrate the severity of this crisis, but that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer chose not to meet this delegation; and
(b) congratulates those associations for attempting to bring to the notice of the Government the plight of rural Australia on which the future of this country depends.

In supporting this motion I remind the Senate that for far too long this country has ridden on the sheep's back. The rural sector, through its wool exports, has been the saviour of this economy time and time again. Finally, as might have been predicted, too many people have jumped on the sheep's back and broken it. Australia will just have to find some other method of transport.

What is really scary about this rural sector downturn is that the bottom has not yet been reached. Already, many people are really finding the hurt tremendously painful. Where else would one find 35,000 people to be moved to write letters to the Federal Government informing it of their plight? I would guess that for every one of the 35,000 people who wrote, there are at least another 10, and perhaps as many as 100, who are yet to put pen to paper and to cry out to the Government about their dilemma.

What has this Federal Government been doing about this dilemma? I remind the Senate of comments by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) in the House of Representatives yesterday about certain Labor Ministers whom he said distort and lie about the past, manipulate the present, and are able to give false hopes about the future. That is a sad scenario.

The Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls (ANOP) survey mentioned by Senator Brownhill in his notice of motion shows that farm incomes will fall 67 per cent in 1991, resulting in a drop of $5 billion for the economies of rural towns across Australia. Since that survey, the position has deteriorated enormously. I said before that the rural sector is yet to reach the bottom of this downturn. This survey is part of that proof. It says that farm incomes will fall 67 per cent in 1991, so the most we can experience in the rural sector downturn is about 20 per cent of the total impact, if one looks where we are this calendar year.

For farmers in Tasmania, the 20 per cent experienced so far has certainly been very evident in the pea and potato crops-not so much in wool, but that is yet to come. In the case of peas and potatoes in Tasmania, too many farmers have had to plough their produce back into the paddock because of the lack of demand, because of the state of the economy, and because of some of the cash resource problems of the processors which can no longer find themselves able to afford to pay the cost of storage while waiting to sell their goods. I am talking about the canneries, particularly Edgells, which is part of the Petersville group, and which is experiencing some tragic cash flow problems.

Unfortunately this has happened to the pea farmers before. In preparation for such an event occurring they have been paying a certain percentage of their income from previous pea crops into a fund to compensate those fellow pea growers whose crops are left in the ground-a very sensible device. Mind you, the fund will be able to pay considerable compensation for one year but certainly not for two or more. Farmers, naturally, are quite resourceful people, particularly in Tasmania where the Acting Deputy President, Senator Aulich-I note him nodding with approval-and I come from. They are resourceful and resilient as can be seen by their advertisements in newspapers inviting the general public to come to pick peas for themselves. Senator Bell well knows the scenario, as he was teaching for a time on the north-west coast. Many of them, as we all know, are starting to bale the pea straw and sell it to nurseries in the hope they will be able to get some money to recover their costs for seed, fertiliser and irrigation. Unfortunately, little if any profit will be made.

This illustrates very well the impact of the downturn in one sector within the economy. The flow-on effects, unfortunately, of the policies which are predetermined by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the form of the recession that we have had to have are having an enormous effect on farmers. If farmers do not receive funds, they do not make machinery purchases; they do not go on holidays; and they do not spend as much money in the local stores. By the end of 1991 when the rural sector has experienced its full fall of not less than 67 per cent of farm income, there will be a lot of businesses in rural towns either financially ruined or certainly on the brink. Where all this will end is just too dreadful to contemplate.

I note that Senator Brownhill's motion mentioned that the Treasurer still keeps telling us that this is the recession we had to have. That is an issue that goes down very sorely in the bush. In a recent Australian Business magazine there was an article by Geoffrey Leahmann who raised the question of whether we are in a recession at all, or rather a long term decline. In Mr Leahmann's words, the word `recession' implies that our problems are just the result of a cyclical downturn. I remind the Senate that there is really nothing cyclical about Australia's worsening current account deficit. I would also add that there is nothing cyclical about the rural sector's worsening situation. The Australian Labor Party has a lot to answer for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: — I rise to support Senator Brownhill's motion and to remind the Senate, as someone who lives and works in rural Australia-when I am not in Canberra, of course-that it is hurting out there far more than Australians living in the cities realise. I speak as the wife of a farmer, the mother of a farmer, and the person who pays the bills for the farm workers on our property, so I really know what I am talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: I have listened at various times in this chamber to honourable senators from the Government talking about what Labor has done for rural Australia. What they do not mention is the exorbitant interest rates the farmers have to put up with under the Labor Government. They do not talk about the big overseas debt that we have acquired under this Government. They do not talk about the high fuel prices that we have under the Labor Government-which they do nothing to try to bring down.

Senator Brownhill's motion before us notes that farm incomes will fall 67 per cent in 1991, resulting in a drop of $5 billion for the economies of rural towns across Australia. The resumption of wool sales in the week beginning 4 March has seen a slump of 35 per cent in the price of wool, and corn, sorghum and other grains have fallen on the commodity markets by $30 per tonne. That sorghum really worries me because we have 140 acres planted at home and we know jolly well by the time we get the seed, and the fertilisers, and the fuel-here let me say that unfortunately this Government took off the subsidies from fertiliser which makes it even more expensive-and we pay wages, we will know that expenses have gone up and the price we are going to get on the market has gone down.
While the Treasurer, Mr Keating, keeps telling us that this is the recession we had to have, the situation in rural Australia is far worse. The motion continues:
. . . with banks increasing their farm foreclosures and increasing numbers of farmers left with no other option than to walk away empty handed and bankrupt . . .

It then points out that the Government had been handed 35,000 letters from `financially crippled farmers throughout Australia in an effort to demonstrate the severity of this crisis, but that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer chose not to meet this delegation'. It is good to know that so many Opposition members and senators-Mr Kerin was also there-went out to the front of Parliament House when those 35,000 letters were brought in by truck. We know, from what those farmers told us, how they are hurting. The motion also says that we should congratulate those who have attempted to bring to the Government's notice `the plight of rural Australia on which the future of this country depends'.

I can tell honourable senators that when these farmers send their letters to Canberra, it is not a publicity exercise. They are facing massive reductions in incomes; they are facing what is being quite commonly referred to in the press as `our rural crisis' all across the country.

The profound shift in Australia's export earnings from farm products to other economic sectors has left primary producers with shrinking incomes. The far-reaching changes that this shift is engendering are by no means complete, although they are being speeded up by historically high interest rates and the impact of technology on such areas as the fibre market. These changes mean that we cannot afford simply to sit back and wait for the farm sector to be virtually depopulated. That really is what is starting to happen all over Australia. It is not only happening in the south Burnett where I come from but also in so many other rural areas. It is in the interest of everyone to control the process, to ameliorate its worst effects and to approach the whole issue with a balance of sympathy and energy.

There is no doubt that rural producers are suffering. They are being hit by fuel pricing policies which might make a great deal of sense in bureaucratic compact Canberra but which add intolerably to the cost of living in remote parts of the country. These fuel pricing policies mean that the Federal Government Treasury coffers and the exchequers of the States, which impose the fuel taxes, are garnering rich profits from the crisis in the global oil market. This Government still believes that we need world parity pricing to demonstrate that we are fair dinkum about being part of the real world. In contrast, most people would argue that the national interest demands that we should seek to minimise the impact that events such as the Gulf war can have on our pockets through petrol prices and their effects on other costs.

Today, farmers are also being made to face financial risks associated with fluctuating commodity prices. Down the track, some of them will face virtual closure of their markets through changing demands and the advance of technology. Urban Australians-the great majority of this country's people-have very little grasp of the realities of making a living in the bush. To them, the country is a place to drive through on the way to a holiday. The problems of sheep farmers in the west, like those of Longreach grazier, Ron Button, which were featured recently in the Courier-Mail, are gross and intractable. Mr Button runs 9,000 sheep on a 12,000 hectare property, a business his family has been in for a century. This year will be very hard for him. Rising production and commodity prices, coupled with diving wool prices, are expected to reduce the family's income by more than 30 per cent.

Mr Button would not be the only one who will suffer in that way. I am not referring, of course, to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) when I am talking about this gentleman. Imagine the hullabaloo if workers on award wages were told that their pay packets were to be slashed by nearly one-third over the next 12 months. I can just imagine what honourable senators opposite would say if that were likely to happen.

Where it has not already fallen prey to agribusiness, the farm sector is very much a family affair. Yet such farms rarely make enough profit to pay each productive family member a living wage. I know about that because I have personal experience in this area. To that extent, farms are small businesses and should be seen as such by the tax man and the bureaucracy. But regrettably the tax man does not look upon it like that. Small wonder in these circumstances that farmers are getting restive. According to the President of the Queensland Farmers Federation, they are also getting ready to take to the streets. We had one example of that down south not so very long ago. Mr Lyndsay Hall, the President of the Queensland Farmers Federation, said that Queensland farmers will back a move by the National Farmers Federation (NFF) for direct action to highlight the fact that thousands of their colleagues are going broke.

Of course, one of those moves was the 35,000 letters which the Government received this week. I certainly believe that the Government should not be surprised if farmers decide to take further direct action. And yet, over the past months we have heard members of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) saying that there is no rural crisis. Mr Bill Bonthrone, the United Graziers Association President, said in a recent newspaper article:
The rural crisis was driving conservative, law-abiding citizens to call for militant action.
The anger is now so deep that only the catalyst is needed for an emotional explosion from the family. It could be fuel prices and interest rates that provide it.

The Government and many of its members representing rural areas in my own State of Queensland do not seem to realise that there is a crisis in rural Australia. After many months of telling the Government what was happening, only late last year the Chairman of the ALP Caucus primary industries committee, the honourable member for Hinkler, Mr Brian Courtice, told the Australian Rural Times:
I certainly do not believe or agree rural Australia is in crisis or about to collapse, but there is no doubt wool and wheat have difficulties to overcome.

Well, since he talked about that in the House of Representatives, there is no doubt that the crisis has come as far as wool producers are concerned and the problem regarding wheat growers is still to arise. I am sure that that will not be far away either. I do not think Labor politicians will be very popular in the electorate of Hinkler. Mr Courtice said that the Government's monetary policy was correct and that any easing of the policy could see demand go through the roof again.

Mr Rob Hulls, who took the late Bob Katter's place as the member for Kennedy, is a man who should know better than most ALP members about the plight of those in rural Australia as his electorate covers most of north-west Queensland. He rejected claims too that rural Australia was at crisis point. He said instead that the economic policies of the Government were working.

The same applies to Mr Lavarch, the honourable member for Fisher, the electorate which adjoins the electorate of Wide Bay in which I live. He said that the suggestion that the rural economy was going to collapse as a result of high interest rates was an oversimplification. Perhaps Mr Lavarch should speak to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who has admitted that his Government's high interest rate policy was causing undue hardship and damage.

Another member that they should also speak to is Mr Lloyd O'Neil, who said that many farmers might be asset rich but were income poor, particularly with the rural downturn. I have no doubt Mr O'Neil is certainly telling them the truth.

Beyond doubt, the farm sector must live with the strictures that apply to all components of Australian society. Nationally-and regrettably-we are uncompetitive in world terms. We are paying for past delusions. We must, though, recognise the need to regulate the effects of fast-moving change on sectors of the economy which impinge heavily on individual lives.

I would like to refer to a letter that was recently published in the Brisbane Courier-Mail. The letter contains the comments of an ordinary Australian who is fed up with what is happening to his country and makes a plea to the Government to recognise finally the mess we are in. The letter reads:
I have had enough of watching the Australian Treasurer, Paul Keating, telling us his economic policies are working. We have:
Record current account deficits.
The highest continuous interest rates historically, which are doing irreparable damage not only to small business, but to grazing and farming industries as well as the nation.
The letter continued:

The greatest number of small business collapses in our history outside the great depression; an Australian dollar so high it has priced the export industries off world markets and dramatically reduced our opportunities to trade; a national debt which has, in only a few years, escalated out of all proportion.
He also wrote that the Government has given us:
. . . a wheat industry which is about to receive the lowest first payment for many years; a beef industry struggling for survival . . .

I must say that over the years the prices in the beef industry have been reasonably good, and we certainly hope that they will not fall dramatically in line with wool and wheat prices. We all know that there are escalating costs and charges, as I said earlier.

The Government cannot claim that the rural crisis has only just hit. It has been warned continuously for years, and the evidence to show just what is happening outside our major cities has been around for quite some time. As long ago as 1989 we read of disturbing figures which showed that farmers were losing money fast, with costs increasing at twice the rate of income. This is under a Labor Government which then has the effrontery to claim that farmers are pleased with the Federal Government. I do not know what criteria the Government would use to make such a claim. But I can assure you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that if your income is being steadily eroded at the rate where the costs to earn it are twice the rate of the actual income, then I am sure that if you are a thinking Australian you would know that you were going backwards and you would not be too happy with that situation. Perhaps some honourable senators opposite would be happy to see their income being eroded as quickly as that.

There is not much point in producing something if it cannot be sold profitably. I have said many times at home to my husband, `I don't know why we are silly enough to be farmers, because you spend all your money on costs and you don't get enough back'. I think that is a very good point, but he does not agree with me, so we keep on farming.

Similarly, it is not much use to so rationalise our rural sector that we eventually see the demise of the family farmer-the person who spends unrecognised hours and efforts producing the end product. These are some of the problems, as I see them, from a personal knowledge of what confronts the man and woman on the land. I was very interested to hear the debate on the matter of public importance that took place today, when Senator Newman led the debate on how the present scene is hurting rural women. I am very pleased to have had this opportunity to speak to the motion which was moved by Senator Watson on behalf of Senator Brownhill, and I have very much pleasure in supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no argument with the figures presented by Senator Brownhill in the first paragraph of the motion. They merely confirm what we all know about Australia's farms-at least what is known by those of us who take the trouble to communicate with those who live and work outside our urban areas. I have no argument with the description in paragraph (ii) of the motion, which is a matter of statistics. I have no argument with what is contained in paragraph (iii) and the description of bank foreclosures on farm properties. It is a description of what is taking place and is a matter that we must constantly bring to the attention of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats would not dissent from the description given in the fourth paragraph of the motion which observes that the National Farmers Federation and the New South Wales Farmers Association delivered 35,000 letters to Parliament demonstrating the severity of the crisis. That event took place and it is to our shame that it was necessary. One of the reasons the event was necessary was that the people involved were feeling a sense of frustration because this Parliament has not demonstrated through its recent actions that it has understood the severity of the crisis facing Australian farmers. I would like to look at some recent actions in this Parliament and, for Senator Crane's benefit, I shall not refer to the recent wool debate debacle but, instead, to actions which took place earlier today.

Let me look at the actions taken during discussions on the social security legislation. Senator Alston described our present economic framework as this Government's `failed economic policies'. I do not intend to debate that matter right now, but what I noticed when that action was taking place was that rather than provide Australia with a set of detailed alternatives, the honourable senator then proceeded to berate the Australian Democrats for showing concern for those affected by those failed polices. There was more than a hint of jealousy lurking in Senator Alston's remarks. I wonder why he saw the need to moan about the Australian Democrats for a full seven minutes of his 10-minute contribution to the debate. It seems to me that without the Australian Democrats the Opposition would have little to oppose because the coalition seems to agree with the fundamental assumptions of this Government's economic strategy.

I refer to the approach to deregulation, privatisation, tariff reduction and targeting of welfare payments. It is the targeting that is causing what was described earlier today as `falling through the net'. The targets are defined with very little concern for those in the rural areas. By excluding from Government assistance and support so many of our Australian citizens who actually live in rural areas, this Government has revealed its ignorance of what really happens in our country areas and how the rural sector of our economy works.

In that targeting process, which is often described in this place with some pride by Senator Richardson, those families who own certain assets are excluded from certain benefits. Our farming sector is particularly disadvantaged. That sector of our community is sitting on a so-called asset, namely, the farm. The plight of rural Australia is made worse by this policy direction because farm families need to find cash to meet the shortfalls brought about by the very policies of this Government. Farming families, like all other families, need cash to meet the needs of young children. Although the family allowance is now not part of this target, the family allowance supplement is still put out of reach by the assets test.

Austudy in particular is a problem because, to send a young person off to tertiary study-to leave the family farm, to live away, and to be set up with the clothing, textbooks, chattels and accoutrements necessary for that venture-requires the sort of cash that many rural families are now finding hard to lay hands on. If the potential supplementation of Austudy is denied through the assets test, then the burden is doubly hard. It is also hard because there is very little that those families can do to avoid such a situation. It is hardly possible to sell off a paddock in rural Australia today to pay for the education of a son or daughter. Such a notion, which I have heard expressed, is put forward by experts from the towns, because things do not happen that way in the country.

Apart from those difficulties, the fundamental approach to economic policy is an approach which is shared by both the Government and the coalition, but it has been shown to be completely misguided. A very interesting, entertaining and informative article in yesterday's Australian was written by Dr John Carroll from La Trobe University. That article substantiates the sorts of policy directions which would be supported by the Democrats and which have been espoused by the Democrats.

Apart from the fact that the Democrats disagree with the appropriateness of the economic tools of measurement which are used by the school of economists who have risen to manipulate the economies of Western democracies in the twentieth century; apart from the fact that the Democrats would challenge how we measure progress, how we measure the state of the economy and how we evaluate whether we are doing well or not; apart from the Democrats' contention that we should evaluate our resources in a finite sense and measure whether we are using them in a sustainable way or whether we are squandering them- apart from all those things, while we are operating within the present framework and using the present economic tools and devices, it is patently obvious that the policies of deregulation and tariff reduction have failed. If that is not apparent to any observer of what is going on in the Australian economy, then that person is obviously blinkered and unwilling to take an objective view. The policies have failed. The economy, the economic tools of measurement-they have all failed. This commitment to deregulation and tariff reduction does not work. More of the same will not produce a J-curve.

The beautiful figures are only beautiful in the eye of the beholder. Only one beholder still sticks to that terminology. Rather than more of the same, Dr Carroll's article proposes that we should recognise that this Government's present economic plans are based on the hope that Australia would either continue a mining exporting boom which did not ever seem to start, let alone continue, or develop export markets for other primary produce.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was not big enough.

—Senator Watson said that it was not big enough. It was not long enough and it was never really there. To continue in the hope that such a thing will eventuate is really a cargo cult mentality which is pathetically misguided. Dr Carroll's article suggests two courses of action. I will quote from it in part. He says that the first course of action is to say that we cannot afford the imports, so we shall not have them; in other words, to forbid imports. Obviously, that is something which is politically and practically unwise and unattainable. The second course of action that he suggests is protection. He writes:

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, it is the only course of action because to ban all imports will prove . . . socially devastating . . . Protection means Australian economic policy being once again governed by what earlier and wiser administrators followed as their principal and golden rule: balancing the overseas account.
The concept obviously sounds simple, but he gives further details:
The real choice is between two types of protection: protection done badly and protection done reasonably well.
That sounds simplistic as well, but he does give details:

Many economic rationalists still claim that the policies of the 1980s were right, they were just not given time to work. Wait another five years, or 10, and Treasurer Paul Keating's `beautiful trend' upwards will appear, by which is meant a significant number of internationally competitive manufacturers exporting vigorously to the rest of the world . . . The arithmetic makes this policy ludicrous, for `significant' means in the order of $20 billion in extra export sales.

Whether or not that is sufficient to dissuade people from seeing that such an argument is patently uncontinuable-if there is any such word-the other aspect to be brought to that discussion is the fact that the continuation of such a policy for another five or 10 years is, in itself, untenable.

The nation has suffered enough already during the 1980s. For the vague promise of the beautiful trend somehow appearing, exports being brought up to that sort of figure is really quite a frightening prospect because it is really only a vague promise. Further into Dr Carroll's article we are reminded, as I am sure many honourable senators would already be aware, of the recent closure of the Black and Decker manufacturing facilities. He reminds us:
The recent Black and Decker case illustrates the futility of gearing manufacturers to export. The Victorian factory, the only manufacturer of power tools in Australia, has just been closed.
Black and Decker had pursued a dynamic industrial policy, introducing new plant and equipment, taking care over training and investing in research and development . . .
These well-intentioned managers of this particular factory had invested in research and development, which had paid off. He continued:
But production runs were too short. Export incentives would have had to be absurdly high to generate adequate sales, but Black and Decker could have done reasonably well in a protected local market.

It is our contention that such a local market should be seen not so much for its world competitiveness but for its benefit to Australia and also its strategic value to Australia-strategic in a social sense, as well as the usually emphasised military sense, and perhaps in an environmental sense-because to do what had been proposed just recently, to ship frozen potatoes from Canada to Tasmania to use in a processing factory located next to one of the world's finest potato growing areas, which Senator Watson has already referred to, is economic and environmental madness brought on by this notion that we have to be in the export business to survive. We do not. We can do everything we need to in Australia. For strategic, economic and environmental reasons, it is my contention that we should. There was another example given in the article that I have already quoted from of a Riverina company exporting pears to Japan:

The exporter was a medium-sized Riverina company which had done all that a government stressing exports might expect. It had found a good Japanese distributor which it had brought to Australia several times to observe the production process. It had regularly sent its own representatives to Japan. Its export was lean. But it could not match the advertising and sales expenditure of its larger competitors.

In other words, out in the jungle, in the free trade world, even though the quality of product was beyond comparison, even though the practices that had been followed here were impeccably well advised, the competition that that particular company faced in Japan was out of its league. Here we had an example of a company which had spent millions becoming involved in that and had lost millions of dollars when, in fact, it was a perfectly worthwhile and viable company in Australia. That is the sort of company that we have no right to advise to change its act, to get into this export business, or to try to save the country by causing chaos to its own industry at home. We would be better advised to protect what we have, to look after what we have and to look after what we know as well. That is the sort of policy which can do a lot better than this misguided, misinformed and unworkable policy direction that we are trying to follow at the moment.

In the very first instance it is my belief that we need to accept the responsibility of applying a penalty to imports which is equivalent to the costs of production that we impose on our local manufacturers. We impose those costs as a society and they are accepted by our rural producers. I mentioned yesterday, in my short contribution to a debate on a report of the Dried Fruits Research Council, that we expect our primary producers to pay Australian award wages and all the add-on costs of employment, be they in the form of holiday pay, sick pay, payroll tax or the penalty rates that apply to shift workers. We also expect our primary producers to pay excises and tariffs on imported equipment, fuel and energy taxes and income taxes.

These sorts of things support not only the primary producers themselves but also all members of our society, and they are for the benefit of our society as a whole. Therefore, our society as a whole should also accept the responsibility of ensuring that whatever is imported into our country as primary produce should have applied to it a penalty which is equivalent to the sorts of penalties we apply to our local producers.

If such were done I think our primary producers would recognise that as bringing the rest of the world down, up or across to whatever is our level. Then we can start talking about a level playing field, which is a cliche so often trotted out by commentators. Then we can talk about fair play and fair trade. Then we can talk about looking after our rural producers. Then we can look our rural producers in the eye and say, `We are actually doing something for you. We are valuing your contribution to Australia's economy. We are ensuring that you are not the subject of unfair competition'. We can then accept the communication from our farmers and our people in the farming country of Australia, and we can say to them, `We are looking after you'. Until we can do that we suffer the shame of having 35,000 of them trying to communicate with us and trying to tell us that we are doing the wrong thing, which I believe we are.
We will support this motion because it expresses some of the frustrations that we feel when looking at the economic and rural policies of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the motion moved by my colleague Senator Watson on behalf of Senator Brownhill which really addresses four major tenets that affect the rural community. Those tenets are, firstly, that farm incomes will fall this year; secondly, the consequences that are arising from a slump of 35 per cent in the price of wool; thirdly, that we are gripped by a recession that we had to have, according to the Treasurer, Mr Keating; and, fourthly, the plight of rural Australia that has been so dramatically illustrated this week by the delivery to this Federal Parliament of some 35,000 pieces of correspondence that have been brought together by the National Farmers Federation (NFF) and the New South Wales Farmers Association.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal with each of those tenets that I think we need to turn our attention to. The National Farmers Federation conducted a survey through the Australian National Opinion Poll (ANOP) which shows that farm incomes will fall by 67 per cent this year. A range of primary producers face massive falls in farm income. Cereal grain producers, for example, expect to lose 93.8 per cent of farm income this year along with wheat growers suffering 79.5 per cent, sheep meat producers 77.2 per cent and woolgrowers 66.5 per cent.

The worst is yet to come, unfortunately. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics says that although 1990-91 farm incomes are forecast to reach the 1982-83 levels in real terms, a further significant decline is projected for 1991-92.

The ANOP survey also highlights major areas of concern for farmers including the financial plight of rural families; the quality of life in rural Australia; commodity prices; banks; government charges and policies; production costs and access to government benefits. If anyone tries to argue that all of these factors will not impact on government policies, then they must have rocks in their head.

We need to look very carefully at the burden of high interest rates and the high personal tax rates that so many of the Ministers of this Hawke Labor Government are guilty of collaborating on. I am reminded that in the Northern Territory and other areas of remote Australia there has been no adjustment to the taxation zone rebate scheme since 1984.

The second tenet of the motion refers to the price of wool slump-some 35 per cent. The future for commodity prices is bleak. According to the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, world market prices for our commodity exports are likely to decline in real terms. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics also warns as follows:
If the slowdown in world economic growth were to be sharper and more protracted than assumed then medium term commodity market prospects would deteriorate further.

The third tenet concerns the recession that we had to have, according to Keating. Of course, people are waiting for the industry statement on 12 March to hear what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has to say about the future of industry in this country and, more importantly, how Mr Hawke and his colleagues intend dragging Australia out of Mr Keating's induced recession. Australia is now in a recession at least as bad as the one of 1983; in fact, it is now said to be the worst since World War II. Who can forget the words of Treasurer Keating in the last year or so? Let me quote some of them. `We won't let there be a recession'. Another one was, `We are bringing home the bacon'. Others were, `These are beautiful figures', `This is a recession we had to have' and, of course, `We have engineered this recession'.

The fourth tenet of the motion refers to the fact that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer are ignoring the farmers' delegations. Earlier this year the National Farmers Federation presented a submission to the Cabinet's structural adjustment committee in which it warned that the outlook for the farm sector was much worse than understood by the community or by the Government at that time. Indeed, it urged the Federal Government to address a range of matters in the 12 March industry statement. The accompanying letter to the Prime Minister from the NFF President, John Allwright, said:
If your Government is not prepared to accelerate the pace of industry reform, the farm sector may not be able to maintain Australia's mandate for leadership in the Cairns Group and the GATT process.

Certainly, a great deal of work is needed on the international front. Last year I had the pleasure of visiting a number of European parliamentary institutions on behalf of this Senate. I was deputy leader of the Australian delegation. We raised the issue of agriculture with members of the European Parliament. I will quote from our report which many honourable senators will have seen on their desks this week. It states:

The discussion on agriculture, at times, was animated, with members reflecting their political interests. The MEPs generally stressed political, social and security dimensions of agriculture for their constituencies, regions and countries. They stated that some reforms, which resulted in civil unrest and demonstrations by traditional farmers, have been introduced within the EC. It was claimed that since the War, 10 million farming families have been displaced in Europe and that as responsible MEPs they must look after the people's interests. An Irish MEP said that he advocated differentiated support rather than overall support in agricultural subsidies and the EC should aim for this eventually.
It states further:

Delegation members were at pains to point out that Australia understands and appreciates their internal problems, particularly in the more depressed areas of the EC, which rely on subsistence agriculture, but maintained that with political will, reform and internal restructuring of the agricultural sector, the benefits will flow to all sectors in the economy, not only within the EC but throughout the world. Australian examples were given where government decisions have affected the rural sectors in the short-term but with long-term benefits to the country.

Yesterday I also had the privilege of meeting again, during their visit to this Parliament, with many of those parliamentarians that I met in Strasbourg last year. I am sure that many members of this Parliament-the Senate and House of Representatives-took the opportunity to reinforce the views that we have to establish that we are not isolated. But it appears that the Government is isolated. I remind it that March is a make or break month. The ides of March is in fact upon this Government.

The Hawke Labor Government came to power on 5 March 1983. Now, eight years later, the Prime Minister faces one of the biggest tests of his political career with the industry statement of 12 March. Everyone is waiting to hear what the Prime Minister has to say about the future of industry in this country and, more importantly, how he and his colleagues intend dragging Australia out of recession. We want answers on unemployment. A recent Australian and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd survey showed that the number of job advertisements last month declined 11 per cent, spelling bad news for school leavers going onto the market. We want answers on the economy. Australia is now in a recession at least as bad as the one of 1983 and, as I said earlier, probably as bad as any since the Second World War.

So far the Hawke Labor Government has refused to explain the nature and causes of our economic woes, let alone tackle the fundamental tasks required to overcome them. The industry statement gives the Prime Minister this opportunity. I understand that Federal Cabinet has considered between 20 and 40 possible initiatives, including tariff cuts, improved labour market programs, and improved depreciation benefits on new business equipment. Whatever the case, I trust that the Prime Minister will finally address the problems of people living in rural and remote Australia, particularly those experiencing economic hardship as a result of Labor's mismanagement-some eight years of it.

Earlier today we were reminded that International Women's Day will be held tomorrow. We should spare a thought for the 2 1/2 million women in rural Australia who, as my colleagues Senator Jocelyn Newman, Senator David Brownhill and Senator Margaret Reid so adequately pointed out today, are the real victims of inflation, unemployment and high interest rates. The Prime Minister's industry statement certainly has a job ahead of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting Senator Brownhill's motion tonight I will take a somewhat different approach from that adopted so far in the Senate. Before I do that, I bring to the attention of this chamber a couple of figures relating to Western Australia which are worth noting. It is early days in terms of our problem. After two months this year we have already had 468 applications to the Rural Adjustment and Finance Corporation of Western Australia, RAFCOR, for assistance. The total for the whole of last year was 199. Another figure that is relevant here is the number of people who walk off their farms and get the $30,000 to $35,000 walk-off grant. Last year the figure was 16; this year, in the two months to date, it is already 20-and we have not even seen the door open fully.

SPEECH.PARA: I challenge the Government. I am pleased to see that Senator McMullan and Senator Giles are in the chamber. I want to table a document which was sent to me from the Hon. Ernie Bridge, JP, MLA, Minister for Agriculture; Water Resources; North-West and member for Kimberley. He is the Minister for Agriculture in the current Lawrence Labor Government in Western Australia. I would suggest that he is one of the few Ministers in that Government who has any rational integrity. I ask for leave of the Senate to table that document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will restrict my remarks because I know that other people wish to speak. In the time available to me, I will run through some of the recommendations made by the task force which was set up by the Hon. Ernie Bridge in terms of dealing with the rural crisis. I suggest to Senator McMullan, Senator Giles and other Government members who are listening that at least in Western Australia we have a Minister who is prepared to tackle this issue head on by putting together a bipartisan group which has come up with some recommendations which should be adopted. I agree wholeheartedly with many of these recommendations but I will not pass judgment on them all tonight. Obviously there are some that I do not support totally. I congratulate that task force and Minister Bridge for at least having the tenacity and the decency to tackle this issue head on.

SPEECH.PARA: I will run through some of these recommendations because they prove that something can be done in Australia rather than stepping sideways and blaming international markets and events overseas. I would be the last person to deny that they have not had an effect, but there is a hell of a lot that can be done in this country to overcome some of the problems not only in rural Australia but in Australia as a whole. Many of these recommendations go far beyond the farm gate; they go to the business people who operate in country areas and in the cities. First, I will touch on macro-economic issues. The first recommendation is:
The Commonwealth Government should allow the Australian dollar to reflect the underlying strength of the Australian economy on international foreign exchange markets.

That is a very important recommendation. We have been talking about this for a significant period. But this has come from a task force set up by a State Labor government. If the Federal Government will not listen to us, surely it will take some notice of some of its colleagues in the States. The second recommendation reads:
The Commonwealth Government should review its macro-economic policy settings with the aim of achieving a further easing of interest rates.

Once again, this is not only a very worthy recommendation but also a very achievable one. One might ask why Senator Peter Cook, who represents John Kerin in this place, is not here in this chamber when we are debating this issue. The next recommendation states:
The Commonwealth and State Governments should hasten the process of micro-economic reform in all areas.

Not only is the task force targeting the Federal Government; it is also targeting the State Government. The pace of the micro-economic reform has been quite disgraceful. Day after day we have listened to Senator Collins answering questions on waterfront reform. While I acknowledge what he said today about what is happening, I also have to ask what the hell has been going on for the last eight years. One can go even beyond that. I know this matter backwards. I know about all the reports that have been prepared. But why has the Government taken so long to act? There has been very slow progress. Recommendation 5 reads:
The Commonwealth Government should hasten the introduction of the recommendation of the Garnaut report on industry protection.

One could ask why the Government has waited until the twelfth of this month to even address this issue. At this point we have no idea whether the Government will address it. Recommendation 6-an issue of great concern to me-reads:
Productivity-based labour market reform should be encouraged by both Commonwealth and State governments as both major employers.

There is an enormous opportunity here for the Federal Government to do something in this particular area. When one looks at the abuse of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission which has occurred in recent times-I have raised this matter here before-particularly with regard to perishable products where we have the most callous application of industrial or union muscle being applied to helpless victims, one can say to those sitting on the other side of the chamber: why does the Government not address this particular issue? These are real issues, which the Government could help to overcome. These problems relate not only to the rural situation but also the Australian situation. Recommendation 9 in the report states:

Financial institutions should be required, by legislation, to disclose the effect of annual rate of interest on all borrowings. This should include all interest costs as well as all associated fees, charges and taxes.

Once again, this recommendation could certainly expose some of the so-called rorts that Treasurer Keating has been carrying on about in recent times. There are activities which are available to the Federal Government whereby it can expose some of these things rather than using rhetoric.

There are some 70 recommendations in this document. I have asked for it to be tabled. I have only touched very briefly at the edges of it because I know that others wish to speak on this matter tonight. I shall conclude by referring to just one other recommendation. I want to pose a question to Senator McMullan and Senator Foreman, who are sitting on the other side of the chamber, regarding this recommendation which states:
The Commonwealth Government should exempt all rail authorities from fuel excise on distillate . . .

It seems to me that one of the most iniquitous situations is that trains have to pay fuel excise which goes into road reconstruction. I ask those two honourable gentlemen sitting on the other side when they have ever seen a train trundling down a road. The payment of that tax by the rail authorities is the hypocrisy of lunacy. Why do the rail systems pay fuel excise which goes into the road systems?

I shall leave my comments at that. The document has been tabled. I want to give other people an opportunity to make some comments. But I shall throw down the challenge to those on the other side of the chamber and those who do not have the interest to come in here and to listen to the matter we are now debating that there are some opportunities where some action can be taken internally in relation to the opportunities that have been recommended by their colleagues in Western Australia, which could go a long way to alleviating the problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting Senator Brownhill's motion which is before the Senate tonight concerning the crisis in the rural community, it has been noted that the Government has just the bare number of people present-only the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is on duty, and the Whip; no-one else is interested in the debate. It is of great concern to me personally and I am quite sure to the rest of the community that the lack of interest in the Government benches is so marked.

SPEECH.PARA: The increase in the latest balance of payment figures is $1.6 billion, seasonally adjusted. Yet we have the Treasurer (Mr Keating) calling them beautiful figures; to be expected; on course and everything in the garden is lovely. He tells us that interest rates will not come down, although he does say that the banks could bring them down one half of one per cent. But he has no intention of taking any action that will bring them down.

The Opposition has asked time after time not only in this place but also in the House of Representatives when the Treasurer will resign. We have been through the whole bit with the Treasurer when he claimed that he was the best Treasurer in the whole wide world. We all remember his J-curve. Remember the J-curve? What happened to that?

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the glass of effervescent?

—We had the glass brimming over. We had his statements that Australia was well on the way to becoming a banana republic. We have had the downgrading of Australia's credit rating not once, but indeed twice. We went from a AAA credit rating that Australia had been proud of for all its history down to a AA1 and then to a AA2. What a disgrace! What an utter disgrace!

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, people do not understand that that makes borrowing that much harder. No so long ago the Treasurer assured us that he would not allow a recession to occur, that he would make sure it did not occur. Not only the Treasurer but also Mr Hawke assured the community and promised that there would be no recession. When we had the inevitable recession, we then had Mr Keating saying that it was the recession we had to have and even proudly saying that he had engineered it. We had to have it and he engineered it. He knew just what he was doing. We then came to the second phase when Mr Hawke, our Prime Minister-not exactly in tears this time but nevertheless apologistic-was saying that he would have done things differently in retrospect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Next time around.

—As my colleague said, in the Prime Minister's words, he would have done things differently next time around. It does not matter where we look in the bush-whether it be at wool, at wheat or at potato growers in the north west of my State or, indeed, at all the horticultural industries or at the citrus growers of Victoria-we find a disaster. The only bright spots on the horizon are beef and cotton and I wonder how long the beef industry will last.

SPEECH.PARA: We have the situation where the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) took absolutely no action when the employees of H. J. Heinz Co. (Aust) Ltd went on strike, when Heinz lost $1m a day, where 840 tonnes of tomatoes rotted on the floor of its factory, where 2,000 tonnes of tomatoes went uncollected from the farmers, and where $700,000 worth of tomatoes were left on the vines and had to be ploughed in. That has happened three years running. We have had strikes at the peak of harvesting.

What was it about? Two workers who repeatedly took long smokos or long lunches! One had had seven and the other had had nine warnings, and two written warnings each. They had had counselling and still they took long lunch hours. When they were dismissed the union called the employees out on strike. This devastation to the tomato growers and to Heinz was sanctioned and encouraged by the unions. An article in the Age newspaper stated:

Back in 1984, the Food Preservers Union lodged a claim for three hours off a week so that members could obtain art classes. Forty-three of the staff at Heinz were undertaking these classes . . . and the company was paying half their costs.
The painting and dancing dated back to the Federal Government's making grants to what Mr Ward called weird and wonderful groups.
This Federal Government was making grants to these weird and wonderful groups. When the grants ran out the whole thing finished. As Mr Ward said in the article:
`You live with lunacy for so long that it becomes normal'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—The manager of Heinz. This is what the Minister for Industrial Relations condones in this place. We have a section of our farming industry losing at least $700,000 worth of tomatoes left on the vine. It is unbelievable that the Government is so beastly careless about the whole thing. Australia has come to the end of its tether; bankruptcies are the highest in Australian history.

SPEECH.PARA: What has the Government done to help the farmers? I will tell the Senate what it has done: it has maintained high interest rates. We have the highest home loan rates; we have the highest real interest rates, that is, if we take inflation into account; and we have an arrogant Treasurer who says that it will all be maintained. The Treasurer is so arrogant that he would not even pay his income tax until he got a special letter from the Commissioner of Taxation saying, `Please, will you put in your tax return for this year? And, by the way, your tax return from last year is not in either'. The arrogance of the Treasurer is unbelievable, while other people get penalised if they are at all late.

We have the situation where farmers who in the early 1980s were, for economies of scale, deciding to purchase adjoining additional land. They decided that they would be very conservative about it. One farmer spoke to me about this. He said, `I went into great detail, making sure I could make my repayments. It did not matter if the prices of my commodities went down, I could still make my repayments. The only thing that I did not bank on was the doubling of interest rates'. It was the doubling of interest rates that finally got him.
These people's wives, the ones left at home looking after the farm because the farmer is out getting extra jobs, cannot survive. Last night, Mr Howard, in the other place, said:
Government distorts and lies about the past, misrepresents the present and gives false hope about the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been an interesting debate to have listened to. Some honourable senators who spoke said things that were interesting and worth while. I have not, of course, shared all their views.
—I rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I seek leave to have the motion put to the vote.
—Under what standing order?
—Order! There is no standing order which would allow the honourable senator to do that, except if he moved for the suspension of the Standing Orders.

—I want to comment on the contributions which some honourable senators have made. I do not want to enter into those who have given generalised discourse about macro-economic policy. I regret to say that we have had three matters of public importance in a row about that, and I do not think we need to get into that again. I would be happy to take that on on a different occasion, as we have done so often in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: I think, for example, that Senator Crane was at least one who made some attempt to look at issues that might be constructive-things that he thought the Australian Government might do that would be of assistance. I am not being critical of Senator Crane; I thought his was the most constructive contribution. Senator Crane raised certain issues that he thought the Australian Government should undertake, but none of them seemed to me to be things which were the policy of his Party or of the Opposition. He is entitled to raise issues without them being the policy of his Party or the Opposition; it is a democracy and this Senate is a chamber in which he is entitled to raise those issues. It seemed to me passing strange that the honourable senator would come in, raise issues about diesel excise, et cetera, indicating that he thought they were matters that the Australian Government should consider taking up when, in fact, they were not the policies of his Party.

In fact, we found a number of the proposals being put up in terms of criticism of the Australian Government did not reflect the policies of the Opposition. Of course, many of the issues that were raised, where blame was attributed to the Australian Government, were accurate descriptions of market circumstances. There was one exception, which, if time permits, I will refer to.

It seems to me rather difficult, for example, to say that the Australian Government is culpable for the circumstances in the wool industry at the moment. It was not an initiative of the Australian Government that made the absurd decision to increase the floor price to an unsustainable position so far above the long term trend and destroy forever the scheme which had been successful for a long time. It is arguable whether it was ever sustainable--
