DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON HEALTH LEGISLATION AND HEALTH INSURANCE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Hill)-by leave-agreed to:
That the report of the Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance be recommitted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance entitled Hospital Costs and Health Insurance because this is a major issue in the Australian community. It will not go away because, as the Australian population ages, health and health insurance will continue to be a major concern for policy makers and for us as politicians and parliamentarians in the coming years.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's terms of reference arose from the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989. The Committee's broad reference was to report upon the effectiveness of the current health insurance industry structure. In particular, I will confine myself to the problems of Medicare. In the second reading debate on the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, my colleague former Senator Puplick described the Bill as:
the next step to patch up this ramshackle, shambling and discredited health system of Medicare . . . in the face of all evidence that what Medicare in fact requires is radical surgery.

Senator Puplick's comments still ring true today. The Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Howe, has set up a number of inquiries to look into the present system, the national health strategy being the major one. We can only hope that out of all the inquiries and reports the Minister can implement some much needed reform.

This evening I particularly want to set the record straight in one part of the health debate, that is, the funding of Medicare. There seems to be a myth amongst the community that the Medicare levy, currently 1.25 per cent, covers the entire cost of medical and public hospital services. In fact, nothing is further from the truth. The Select Committee's report notes that expenditure on Medicare for 1989-90 was $7,497m, comprising $3,526.8m for hospitals and $3,969.8m for medical services. The Medicare levy raised $2,545m. The message that must be said again and again is that the Medicare levy contributes only one-third of the funding that is outlaid on Medicare programs. The Medicare levy does not cover medical and hospital costs in Australia-it covers one-third. The balance comes from general revenue.

Until that one-third figure is indelible in the psyche of Australians, we will have the myth that Medicare is a panacea for the illness of the Australian community. It would be an interesting exercise to find out what percentage of the public are aware of this fact. Surveys show that 70 per cent of the community think Medicare is wonderful. That is the 70 per cent who have not tried to get into a public hospital. I bet the other 30 per cent have been on the hospital waiting lists. A fact that is not known by the community is that the costs of their demands for public hospital and medical services significantly exceed the contribution that they make to cover those costs in the form of their levy.

This is one of the fundamental problems with the Medicare system. The absence of any real price signal means that the demand for medical services in particular is too high. However, the distortions on the supply side cannot be forgotten. Without any notion of the true cost of services demanded and supplied, it is no wonder that there is an overdemand for and oversupply of medical services. The recently released Deeble report provides figures that indicate the overdemand and oversupply. Included in the report is the estimate that the cost of health care could rise by 44 per cent in real terms in the next decade, and that is just terrifying. Put simply, Medicare encourages the wasteful use of Australia's health care system.

It will be interesting to see whether the Government moves in the same direction and introduces a price signal as it did recently with the introduction of a $2.50 charge for pharmaceuticals. So far there has been no move in that direction. The Government has been purely hypocritical in this approach. The Government has been tinkering at the edges- `We will not let people going overseas have Medicare cover because they go away without full insurance and, because they do not understand their rights, we will take away those rights'. This is the sort of tinkering at the edges that goes on in trying to make some savings in this area.

There seems to be no limit to the demand for increasingly costly medical services under this Government. This will not change as long as the Federal Government continues to spend only something like 3 per cent of its health budget on community health and prevention. The Government has succeeded in containing expenditure in a number of areas by, for example, reducing or cutting out Medicare rebates. I mentioned one of those earlier. The supposed high level of public support for Medicare will soon diminish if the Government continues to cut rebates and pass on the costs in the form of higher out of pocket payments by individuals.

Another matter I wish to raise is that of underfunding of the public hospital system. The Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Howe, has admitted that public hospital capital expenditure was running at 7 per cent and 8 per cent of recurrent costs through the 1960s and early 1970s and has declined to 3 per cent in the 1980s. Capital expenditure on public hospitals has since remained at about the same level as that for private hospitals, although public hospitals represent 75 per cent of all capital stock. If we look at this appalling situation with regard to capital expenditure and add it to the problems encountered in the private system, we see that our health system really is in a critical position.

The Government is making a good fist of destroying the private health industry. Today, just over 40 per cent of the population is privately insured compared with over 60 per cent when this Government came into office. By withdrawing its contribution to the health reinsurance pool, reducing the private hospital bed day subsidy and widening the gap between medical benefits and the schedule fee offered to private patients in public hospitals, and not permitting people to insure against that gap, the Government has massively increased the cost of private insurance, thus reducing the membership of and increasing the burden on health funds.

It has been estimated that a reduction of one per cent in private insurance membership equates to $120m in extra Government funds. It is no wonder that a number of the private health funds are struggling to keep their businesses open. What is the Government doing about this? Nothing.

The report of the Senate Committee says that the maintenance of a high quality hospital system must be the Government's first priority. The Opposition believes it is vital that we have a healthy private industry as well and that it should be allowed to compete with the public system. If there is no competition, there is no increase in incentives and no incentives for efficiency.

Australia needs to restore choice and incentive, which are currently lacking in the system-choice for individuals between care in the public and private systems and incentives to take out private health insurance. What is needed is a system which will encourage the private sector and more appropriately distribute the costs between the private and public systems.

What we do not need is the current system that creates two classes of Australians: those who are placed on hospital waiting lists-and, as we were reminded earlier today by Senator Reid, many of those are older people-and those who are not. Those who can afford to take out private health insurance are guaranteed ready access to the public hospital system. No such guarantee applies to Medicare patients.

Only recently an Italian gentleman came into my electorate office in Clayton and said, `It is wrong; my wife cannot get into hospital'. I bet that, if he were included in a survey on Medicare, he would say that it stinks. It would not be polite for me to say exactly what he said to me on the telephone about the fact that his wife was waiting, not for elective surgery but for emergency surgery.

It will be extremely interesting to see what changes the Government has in store for the health system. With the report of the Committee in hand and the recently released second report of the national health strategy-the Deeble report-there is definitely no shortage of problems in our health system. These problems have been highlighted and should be addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Patterson for at least giving me the time to get here with leisure and to have the opportunity to point out that she clearly has not read the report of the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance but has given us a preferred political speech from the Opposition that does not pick up on one of the issues in the report.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very disappointing, and not of Senator Patterson's general performance. I could be tempted to try to counter what she has claimed in terms of the political statement, but we are theoretically talking to this report. I would urge Senator Patterson in her leisure time to read it. One of the things it said in its opening chapter was that the cheap, political polarisation of the health debate in this country is one of the principle reasons why it has been so destructive and why there is no immediate prospect of having a proper debate about health care and health care costs in this country.

It is interesting, and I note that the honourable senator failed to say to us, that this was a unanimous report; that the Opposition members on the committee actually endorsed it. They in fact endorsed Medicare in this report. That also, I think, was not brought to the Senate's attention by Senator Patterson. I think it is a shame because what this report says is that we should actually start focusing the debate on health care and health costs in this country on where the real problems are, not on beating up the old political rhetoric about Medicare.

One of the comments that Senator Patterson raised that gives me great pause, and one of the confusions often led by the Opposition, is that if we only allowed patients to pay a little bit then there would be a restriction and a restraint built into the health costs of this area. Then she proceeded to go on to say that sometimes the Government reduces the rebate and the patients have to pay a little bit, and this is outrageous because it is denying them their right to assistance. I do not mind which way she decides, but I do not believe she can have it both ways. This is an argument often used by the Opposition: let patients pay a little as that will put some restraint into the system, and then complain bitterly when there is some restraint put into the system.

But the other interesting and important point is that Senator Patterson fails-and the Opposition continues to fail-to understand that costs in the health care system are not engendered by patient demand; they are engendered by doctors supply--

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—Well, rubbish is probably a clear assessment of what the honourable senator assesses in this debate, but I do not think it is constructive and it provides no information. In this report there is an analysis that the usage of medical services is consistent over about the last 20 years, that is, it is not engendered by patient demand but it is largely led by doctors supply. Patients are not in the position to determine, as they are in other commodities, that they may want to purchase what they need, much less what is best for them. Until the Opposition grasps that the ordinary economic analysis does not apply in the health care area then it will continue to come up with the most amazing sets of proposals for health care policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently floated was the voucher system. I do not understand how the Opposition can do so; it must have seen the effects of the voucher system when it put it up as one of the five policies it had under seven years of Fraser-not exactly implemented, but at least outlined. Here it is telling me, or at least Dr Hewson is telling me, that he would like to see smaller government, restraint of fiscal policy and reduction of public expenditure; yet the Opposition is proposing a voucher system for health care costs that is bound to cost at least $1 billion extra from the public purse; that is a very conservative estimate, and there is no suggestion about where the Opposition will get the money from.

In this report there is the very important canvassing of the issue of waiting lists. What we were able to conclude is that one cannot conclude about waiting lists because there is no reliable data. I was interested to read an article in a medical journal the other day-unfortunately I do not have it; it is in Adelaide, so I cannot give the exact source. Certainly an Australian group of professional health analysts can tell us that the waiting list for surgery in Victoria is 20 per cent overrated; that is, one in five of the people listed for elective surgery is not in need of it. That should give Senator Patterson pause. In other words, what we have by waiting list figures are very, very rubbery indeed and we should be cautious about what we conclude.

What the report is able to say-and this is based on fact-is that when the Government proposed and actually contributed dollars of expenditure to reduce the waiting lists, that actually happened. By and large, that money, matched by the States over three years, was directed to reducing the waiting lists through opening surgical theatres, by increasing the professional staff who were needed-particularly nursing staff, theatre staff-and directly targeting, not so much the capital requirements, but the professional and administrative and operational theatre provisions, and the waiting lists fell. My understanding is that the waiting lists in Victoria have turned around and are slightly on the increase.

I was also impressed in meeting and talking with some of the professional people from the Health Department in New South Wales who told me that there are two ways of describing what happens in our public hospitals in this country. The Opposition claims there are 100,000 people on the waiting lists in this country, but the best figure, even though rubbery, that anyone will come up with is 70,000. That can be said, but it does not tell us that in New South Wales about one million people attend public hospitals in the course of a year. Some 50 per cent of those people attend through accident and emergency and are treated and dealt with within 24 hours. Of the remaining 50 per cent, 49.5 per cent are treated within a week. We can still appreciate that there are some 20,000 people who, at any one time, might be waiting for elective surgery, but if we continue to carp on the waiting lists and do not address the facts of what is happening in our health care system in this country we will continue to get this distorted view and the debate on health care poisoned by political rhetoric.

There is much in this report that might help Senator Patterson and the Opposition. Indeed, we hope it will also help the Government, particularly through the Macklin inquiry. Our recommendations pick up the points about health insurance and the cost of it. We also make very significant recommendations in the area of private health insurance and recommend that there may even be an inquiry into this whole matter examining whether community rating and reinsurance is the way to go; it is producing its own inequities and problems, and it certainly is not assisting the private health insurance industry. That industry also needs to smarten its own game. We make comment about that in this report.

The debate is not conclusive or closed in the private health insurance area. I would say the jury was still out, if it has even been appointed. But one point that has been overlooked, and Senator Patterson certainly skidded past it, is that people with private health insurance actually are the people who can then receive their service from the medical professions in the private system, and that is where the doctors fees are not capped; that is where the doctors are not constrained by the medical benefits schedule.

One of the big complaints from people is that they say they have got their operation done through the private system and they have got a bill for many hundreds, even thousands, of dollars; this does not apply, of course, to most specialists, but there are some specialists charging well, well, well above the scheduled fee. They are only able to do that in the private sector for people who have private insurance. It is a very big area, and it is not assisted by saying, `Get people on private insurance and that will solve the problem'. What it will do, Senator Patterson, quite clearly, is blow out health expenditure in this country. She had better tell me whether she is planning, as the Opposition, to constrain health expenditure or whether she would prefer to go the way of America.

In Australia we have kept health expenditure at about 7.9 to 8 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) over the last seven or eight years. In England, it is somewhat less than that. Canada has also got a reliable and reasonable figure. In America, with the mismatch they have there, the private system and free for all, their health expenditure is about 12 per cent. There is no way it will come down. Thirty seven million Americans are not insured and have very limited access to health care.

I would strongly recommend that we look very closely at the very good system we have in this country, focus on those areas of difficulty and try to solve them. If Senator Walters and Senator Patterson have that view, I would ask them to speak to their Opposition colleagues who sat on this Committee and concluded, as we did, that this was the way to have a look at it. Let us remove from the debate the issues that are not going to lead to a constructive addressing of the problems of health costs in this country-problems of ethics, of equity, of priority and of resource allocation; very large debates which we recommend should come into the community. My time having run out, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this Bill, which the Opposition supports, is to implement the provisions of the Hague Convention on the law applicable to trusts and on their recognition. The Bill applies the Convention only to international trusts, not to domestic or interstate trusts, where it is possible that the law of the State or Territory may apply. States and Territories will be free to make their own laws to apply the Convention to interstate trusts.

SPEECH.PARA: The Convention was adopted in 1984 and became open for signature in July 1985. Pursuant to article 30, the Convention will not come into force until three countries have ratified it. So far only two have done so-Italy and the United Kingdom. A number of other countries have also signed it.

The Hague Convention on the law applicable to trusts and on their recognition is designed to address conflict of laws problems which may arise where some aspect of a trust, whether it be a beneficiary, trustee or asset, has a connection with more than one jurisdiction. This may arise, for example, where the settler and the beneficiary reside in different nations.

Problems are particularly likely to occur where one of the jurisdictions concerned is a civil law jurisdiction because they generally do not recognise the concept of trusts. The legal concept of a trust is peculiar to common law jurisdictions. The Convention requires civil law countries to recognise the trust; thus there is a clear benefit for common law countries, such as Australia, which become signatories. The Government has taken the view that common law countries should be seen to be enthusiastic about the Convention in order to encourage civil law countries, which do not derive a direct benefit in the same way, also to become signatories.

Chapter I of the Convention specifies the law applicable to trusts and governs their recognition. The characteristics of a trust are set out. Chapter II is about the choice of law rules. Article 6 provides that a trust shall be governed by law chosen by the settler or creator of the trust and where no applicable law has been chosen, a trust shall be governed by the law with which it is most closely connected. This is determined by having regard to a number of matters set out in article 7, although that list is not exhaustive.

The present situation with respect to choice of law is complex. Where a trust has aspects extending over more than one jurisdiction, the common law rules of conflict of laws will determine which domestic system of law governs the operation of the trust.

Chapter III provides that a trust created in accordance with the law specified by the preceding chapter shall be recognised as a trust and what legal consequences flow from that recognition. The general clauses of the Convention are contained in chapter IV. These relate principally to conflicts of laws and other matters, including article 22, which states that the Convention applies to trusts regardless of the date on which they were created.

The Opposition has particular concerns with respect to articles 16 and 22 of the Convention. Article 16 states that the Convention does not prevent the application of those provisions of the law of the forum which must be applied even to international situations, irrespective of rules of conflict of laws. The second paragraph of article 16 provides that if another state has a sufficiently close connection with a case, in exceptional circumstances effect may also be given to the rules of that state which have the character of the provisions mentioned in the first paragraph. It is provided in article 16 that any contracting state may, by way of reservation, declare that it will not apply the second paragraph of this article.

Australian courts will not give effect to foreign mandatory rules unless they clearly form part of the proper law of the trust. This article could create uncertainty for parties involved in setting up a trust; it does not specify what is a `sufficiently close connection'; further, it is discretionary in nature.

The Opposition has been urging the Government to consider making a reservation to this article. Unfortunately, our representations have so far been without success. The Government has argued that there is a presumption that a treaty will be implemented in good faith and Australia rarely makes reservations, preferring unanimity between parties on the basis of an agreed text. The Opposition contends that the text of article 16 clearly envisages that states will have reservations in relation to this article.

Furthermore at the conference at which the Hague Convention was formulated, Australia voted against the inclusion of article 16 on the ground that it was unnecessary because the Australian legal system would allow foreign laws of immediate application to be taken into account without any specific provision for that purpose.

The Government's refusal to consider making a reservation is particularly disappointing in view of the fact that this rejection may be based on a mistaken interpretation of the opinion of Professor Michael Pryles, the leading Australian specialist on conflict of laws, sought by the Government on the issue of reservations. The briefing paper for the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) on `Reservations to the Convention', which the Attorney provided to the Opposition, notes Professor Pryles's opinion of 1986 that the choice of law rules in the Convention are very similar to existing Australian common law rules and that the only real point of departure was the second paragraph of article 16. The paper goes on to state that Professor Pryles was again consulted on this matter in February 1991, on the effect of provisions of this kind, and that on this occasion Professor Pryles `noted that while this is a departure from traditional Australian conflict of laws rules, it has no significant consequences'.

The Opposition has been in contact with Professor Pryles who expressed some concern that this is not an entirely accurate reflection of his opinion. While he acknowledges that the principle contained in the second paragraph of article 16 would be infrequently used, as a matter of principle of law it represents a significant departure from the common law position. For the few cases that could be affected by the application of the principle in the second paragraph of article 16, the consequences would, contrary to the suggestion of the briefing paper, indeed be significant.

If Australia does not make a reservation to this article, it would not be the end of the world. But we should be aware that it has significant consequences. I understand that the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Peacock, may be writing to the Attorney-General in the near future to set the record straight in relation to Professor Pryles's opinion.

Article 22 provides that the Convention applies to trusts regardless of the date on which they were created. However, a contracting state may reserve the right not to apply the Convention to trusts created before the date on which the Convention enters into force for that state. Basically, this means that states can decide whether the Convention should operate prospectively or retrospectively. This is a significant departure from the usual application of treaties, which is prospective. Pursuant to this article, the Convention will apply to trusts created before its commencement, unless an appropriate reservation is made.

There would be an advantage for Australia in making a reservation in relation to this article in that Australian legal advisers would be given notice of the changes the Convention will bring about since it does not, after all, represent a departure from the common law rules. Naturally, it would be an advantage for Australia if civil law countries were to give the Convention retrospective operation, but even if Australia were to give the Convention prospective operation, it is unlikely that civil law countries would respond in the same way.

The Opposition urges the Government to consider making reservations in relation to articles 16 and 22. We have serious concerns arising out of the Government's refusal to lodge reservations to the Convention. We have formed the view that these issues are best canvassed in the context of an examination by a legislative and general purpose standing committee. As I understand that a decision has been made elsewhere than through the mechanisms of the Senate that this Bill be referred to the Senate Standing committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for a more detailed examination, particularly in relation to articles 16 and 22, I shall endeavour in the meantime to ensure that this anticipated exchange of correspondence between Mr Peacock and the Attorney-General takes place, and that might clarify or overcome one of the difficulties that I mentioned. I shall also take further instructions to see whether there are ways in which consideration of these aspects by the Committee might be limited to a manageable form, bearing in mind that I have received some representations about the volume of work that happens to be before this particular Standing Committee at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Trusts (Hague Convention) Bill 1991. The purpose of the Bill is to enact in Australian law the provisions of the Hague Conventions so that they may be given effect. The Bill is intended to provide machinery for identifying which country's law is to govern a particular trust and to provide guidelines for the recognition of that trust in accordance with that law.

SPEECH.PARA: As the name suggests, the Bill deals with the law applicable to trusts and the recognition of trusts. It is worth noting that trusts are a unique creation of common law countries and are generally not used in civil law systems. One cannot help wondering whether a large drain on tax revenue in our country is not in some way due to the invention of trusts, and I shall return to that point later. One may well wonder whether the comparatively speaking better state of the public exchequer in civil law countries is not due to the absence of trust provisions.

The Convention is designed to overcome potential conflicts of laws which may arise where certain features of the trust, such as its assets, beneficiaries or trustees, have connections with more than one jurisdiction. If the trusts are not recognised in one of these jurisdictions, as indeed is the case in civil law jurisdictions, the very existence and validity of the trust may be in doubt.

The provisions of the Convention are mirrored in the schedule of the Bill which is divided into chapters and articles. Chapter I defines the ambit of the Convention and whether the arrangement is a trust covered by the Convention. Chapter II identifies the national law applicable to any particular trust and prima facie the governing law is taken to be the one chosen expressly or impliedly by the settler. Chapter III deals with the extent to which a trust is to be recognised in accordance with the applicable law by states that become parties to the Convention. Chapter IV contains a number of general articles, several of which limit the effect of the Convention in particular circumstances.

I have examined carefully the learned contribution to the debate that was made by Mr Costello in the other House and have noted his suggestion that there is sufficient uncertainty in articles 16 and 22 to warrant reservations to be expressed when we ratify this Convention. It seems to me at this stage, on a fairly cursory examination, that there is indeed some room for uncertainty in considering article 16. I defer further consideration until after this matter has been examined by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

I do not share Mr Costello's view that article 22 contains similar uncertainties. I believe that it is fairly clear cut and certain and I cannot see the point of including that article in our further considerations. However, no doubt that also will be left to the consideration of that Committee. As a member of the Committee, I welcome the comment by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, that we will seek to find ways and means to limit the work of that Committee on this Bill, which does not require all that much detailed research.

I am pleased to have the assurance of the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) that the Convention will not impose new obligations on Australian courts to give effect to fraudulent or otherwise undesirable trusts. I am sure that everyone agrees that we already have a superfluity of such trusts in our legal and taxation system. I believe that the Convention allows precedence to be given to a contracting state's public policy. In other words, any amendments that we might wish to make in the future to our trust laws would not be impeded by Australia ratifying this Convention.

I turn briefly to some considerations that I have indicated before might be made on trusts and their use in our taxation system. The classical distinction in the taxation of trusts and companies can be attributed to the general position that a trust estate is not a separate legal entity, whereas a company has a legal identity distinct from its shareholders. For some considerable time now trusts have been used for tax minimisation, tax avoidance and tax deferral purposes. In addition, the exemption of certain trusts from the need to furnish annual tax returns has been a catalyst for the use of the trust form for tax evasion. This has been compounded since 1984 by the ability of persons to transfer funds to and from Australia freely, even to tax havens, although the tax screening measures which were part of that have recently been found to be ineffective and have been dropped.

The need to extend the company tax regime to trusts was recognised by the legislation in 1981 when corporate unit trusts interposed in company restructuring were used for tax avoidance purposes. Division 6B of part 3 of the Income Tax Assessment Act was inserted to prevent these practices. However, these measures do not apply to unit trusts if 20 or fewer persons hold 75 per cent or more of the beneficial interest in the income or property of the trust.

These remarks are simply to flag our intention to bring forward legislation at the appropriate time to ensure that trusts which do not fall into certain categories which warrant an exemption are indeed taxed as companies are. The trusts that we would exempt from such a measure would be non-trading trusts in the public investment area, estates of deceased persons in the course of administration, trusts in respect of compensation for personal injuries and the general category of charitable trusts. I conclude by saying that in general terms the Australian Democrats support the Bill and look forward to the resolution of the remaining queries in the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the second reading debate on this important Bill, the Trusts (Hague Convention) Bill. I thank the Opposition and the Australian Democrats for indicating their support for the passage of the Bill which deals with what I am surprised to learn is a purely common law phenomenon known as a trust. I must admit that I had not realised that the concept of equitable obligations resting on a trustee in relation to certain property held in trust for a beneficiary was not also a concept or an arrangement known to civil law systems.

SPEECH.PARA: I seem to recall reading in law school 25 years ago that trusts evolved, certainly in England, because the Franciscan friars, once they were seduced by the pleasures of living not in hedgerows but in buildings and yet maintaining their vow of poverty, arranged with the landowner to enter into what we now know as trust arrangements whereby the property would be vested in X, but the Franciscan friars would be the beneficiaries but, by not owning the property, would maintain their vow of poverty. I would have thought that Franciscans on the continent would have tried to do such a deal with their supporters also, but apparently they must have struck some other arrangement.

That makes the point that this Convention is for the benefit of those of us who live in common law jurisdictions. In order to have the trust arrangement recognised and protected by civil law jurisdictions, which otherwise would find it quite an alien concept-particularly where the property the subject of the trust is in a civil law jurisdiction-it is extremely important that the trust arrangement be protected and subject to a regime of law which enables the beneficiaries and the trustees to be certain as to the legal principles that govern the trust concept, its recognition and its practical operation.

I understand that the Convention is largely consistent with Australian common law rules of conflict of laws. I am told that adoption of the Convention would not require amendment of existing Australian statute law and would not cause substantial changes to existing Australian law. In particular-and I think this is important from Senator Spindler's point of view-it is true that those Australian laws which deal with matters of public policy and fiscal laws, as they are called in the Convention, would maintain their precedence. There is nothing in the arrangements that could be made by virtue of this Convention which would displace any taxation laws that attempted to regulate the use or abuse of trusts in relation to the moneys which should flow to the exchequer-I think that Senator Spindler adopted that particular expression.
I had a look at article 19 while Senator Spindler was speaking. It says:
Nothing in the Convention shall prejudice the powers of States in fiscal matters.

I think that is the key to the particular concern which Senator Spindler expressed. I am not saying that he was not aware of that particular article, but it does merit being put on the record as being something which those who drafted the Convention had proper regard to.

It is also the case that mandatory laws relating to insolvency, succession, transfer of property, exchange controls, protection of cultural property, et cetera, are also covered as having the sort of precedence which they deserve. It is interesting to note that in the history of the evolution of the support for this particular Convention by Australia it was necessary that the Standing Committee of Attorneys- General have regard to the impact which the adoption might have in their various jurisdictions. It was in 1987, I believe, that they accepted that the Convention ought to be signed and in due course ratified by Australia. I think that some of them are interested themselves in enacting legislation to apply the rules of the Convention to what we might call interstate trusts; that is, trusts domestic to the Commonwealth of Australia but operating over State boundaries.

Questions have been raised about the matter of reservations which might properly be made to the Convention. Article 26 provides that a State may make such reservations in relation to certain articles. Of particular interest to the chamber has been the question of whether the second paragraph of article 16 is such that the Government would consider it necessary to make a reservation with respect to that second paragraph. It should be noted-and I do not want to go over the whole argument because we will possibly do this before the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs-that the operation of that provision is attracted in only exceptional circumstances.

Whilst I think we need to concede, as apparently Professor Pryles indicated, that it could have significant effect in a particular case, those exceptional circumstances would arise, it is thought by the Government, so seldom that it does not consider it a cause for such concern as would warrant a reservation being made. In other words, I suppose that there is some trade-off, as Senator Spindler indicated, between certainty and uniformity. In this particular instance, whilst there might be some element of uncertainty theoretically introduced, given the fact that the second paragraph operates only in exceptional circumstances and admitting that it is subject to the discretion of the court-in other words, effect may be given, which is the expression used-on balance the Government believes that, because of the uniformity aspect in trying to get common law and civil law countries alike to adopt this particular Convention in its entirety and to encourage civil law jurisdictions to adopt this Convention by way of ratification, we should show wholehearted support for the Convention as it has emerged, though admitting that in the history of the putting together of the Convention Australia had misgivings about this particular second paragraph. That has to be admitted as part of the history of the matter. But it having been inserted and Australia, I believe, during that process having insisted on the adoption of the terminology `only in extreme or exceptional circumstances', I think the Australian Government takes the view that we can live with it; and the legal advisers can sensibly offer certain advice in relation to the operation of this particular Convention on trusts which operate in common law and civil law jurisdictions other than Australia.

There was also the question of perhaps a reservation to article 22 of the Convention. Once again, the goal of trying to attain greater international uniformity in the law relating to trusts is a strong inducement to the Government not to make a reservation in respect of article 22. I know that the Government considers that allowing the Convention retrospective operation will in fact better protect the position of already established Australian trusts where, as I say, for example, the property might be in a civil law jurisdiction.

I believe that I have dealt with the question of reservations in an adequate, if somewhat summary, fashion. I believe that the Bill to give effect to the Convention on the law applicable to trusts and their recognition and for related purposes deserves the support of the chamber. I am particularly grateful to the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) for his indication that he will try to facilitate the passage of this Bill through the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs so that the consideration, the deliberation, in that Committee does not become too lengthy. I commend the second reading of this Bill to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the order of the Senate agreed to earlier this day, the Bill stands referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for consideration and report by 11 March 1991.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Tate)-by leave-agreed to:

That the order of the Senate, this day, requiring the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs to present its report on the Trusts (Hague Convention) Bill 1991 by 11 March 1991 be modified to provide that the Committee present its report on or before 9 April 1991.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 February, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1990 is to increase the maximum levies payable for research and development from 50c to $1 a head, and the marketing and promotion levy from $1.50 to $2.50 a head on each pig slaughtered. The industry, through the Australian Pork Producers Federation, has requested the increase due to the fact that increases in the operative rate will allow the Australian Pork Corporation to maintain or expand its marketing and promotional program.

SPEECH.PARA: At present, the Government offers dollar for dollar funding for research and development to a maximum of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production. The pig industry currently pays about 0.35 per cent and wants to increase the amount. By doubling the legislative maximum to $1, there is the ability for the pig industry to lift its commitment to research to the 0.5 per cent level.

The whole range of research levies for agricultural industries is a positive policy. It means that these industries in Australia, matched with government support, provide a significant amount towards research in their respective industries. This makes Australian agricultural industries very productive as they are based on research and development.

Such advanced research within these industries means that the productivity in agricultural industries far surpasses that in other sectors of the Australian economy. In fact, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has indicated that the productivity level of agriculture in Australia was at least 50 per cent higher than it was for other sectors of the Australian economy. Consequently, if the productivity level was as high in other sectors of the economy, Australia would be a far more competitive country.

The second part of the legislation involves the $1.50 that pig producers currently pay per head for promotion and to run the Australian Pork Corporation. The Australian Pork Corporation and the industry have been involved in the new- fashioned pork promotions in an endeavour to increase the consumption of Australian pork. The pork industry wants to increase the levy for promotional activities from $1.50 to $2.50 a head. The actual increase in the levy to producers will be determined by regulation and obviously will be done over a period. The legislation will provide a gap or the ability for the amounts to be increased.

The increasing need for the Australian Pork Corporation and the industry to promote their products comes at a time when the industry is facing increased competition from international markets. The recent decision by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service in allowing Canadian pork into the Australian market will mean that the Australian pork industry will have to promote and market its product as free from disease and chemical additives. The industry will have to be one step ahead of its overseas competitors.

I have noted in recent days the annual report for 1989-90 of the Pig Research Council which has been distributed to all honourable senators by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. This report draws our attention to many areas of research that are required in this important industry covering such highlights as nutrition and growth, health and disease, genetics and reproduction, welfare, processing, marketing economics, housing, effluent disposal and utilisation, communications, education and training. Of course, the industry takes that report seriously and it has some degree of relevance to all of the issues currently under consideration by the Senate.

I have as a member of my staff a press secretary who has a very good sense of humour, and probably something of a fetish with regard to pigs. It was very interesting that, when I mentioned this evening that I was going to be speaking on this Bill, she pointed my attention to a recent odd spot caption that she had picked up and added to her memorabilia collection. I would like to share it with the duty Minister Senator Collins and other honourable senators. It states:

A British expert says pigs are intelligent and choosy about what they drink. He found pigs shunned salt water but liked orange juice and milkshakes. However, he said they were not social drinkers and would not drink unless thirsty.
Perhaps there is a lesson in that for all of us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do I follow that! The Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1990 is not contentious at all because, as we were told in the second reading speech by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), it is a levy increase which has been requested by the Australian Pork Producers Federation. It is also a levy which is appropriate and necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: For me this particular levy is yet another example of the reasons why Australia's rural industries are clean and more productive and more attractive than many of their competitors both within Australia-as Senator Tambling has asserted with greater productivity than the manufacturing sector-and internationally when competing directly on open markets with international primary industry competitors. As Senator Tambling mentioned, the prospect of Canadian pork being imported into Australia is one which is not particularly welcome but which will bring a challenge to our industry, and our industry will be capable of meeting that challenge because of its productivity and its attractive product.

It is my contention-and I mentioned this earlier tonight-that it would be logical to subject a competing product from overseas to an importing charge which was equivalent to the sorts of production costs which we, as a society, place on our own producers. We, as a society, place certain charges on our producers and we give our producers the responsibility of carrying them. They quite willingly do so because they contribute to the community. As a community as a whole we should then accept the responsibility of placing an equivalent order of costs upon those imports which we allow into the country.

I am sure that the logic should be continued to ensure that Canadian competitors in the pork industry face a charge equivalent to that which is put aside by our producers for research and development. We could follow that logic further and look at the other socially beneficial charges which we lay against our producers. That, to me, would be a way of ensuring that this Parliament could be recognised as playing its role in making the competition fairer.

It is with that contention that I suggest we approach this sort of levy which has been passed with regard to several of our primary industries in the last few days, and I dare say there are a few more levies, charges and adjustments which will be coming to us in the near future. For the reasons that I gave at the beginning, we will not be opposing this Bill. It has been requested by the industry and is a desirable expenditure of money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I can usefully add anything to that already contributed by Senator Tambling and Senator Bell. The levies collected by the legislation and increased by the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill are used to partially fund the operations of the Pig Research and Development Corporation and to fully fund the Australian Pork Corporation. I will vote for that. I conclude by thanking honourable senators for their contributions to the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or requests.

That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to put on the Senate record information about the establishment of two new units that have particular importance in this place and in the understanding and consideration of Australians in general about matters to do with health and prevention of disease. I am drawing on the South Australian Medical Review, volume 4, No. 1, February 1991, which is the official publication of the South Australian branch of the Australian Medical Association and the South Australian Postgraduate Medical Education Association.

SPEECH.PARA: Two articles in this publication are worthy of note in this place. The first relates to the establishment of a unit to look at road trauma. The article states that a national road trauma authority is to be established. In mentioning the establishment of this authority, I acknowledge the driving force of Sir Dennis Paterson, an Adelaide doctor who was honoured with a knighthood in 1976 for his distinguished services to medicine. He is also the immediate past President of the International Society of Orthopaedic Surgery and Traumatology.

Quite often in this place we fail to notice that every year in this country about 3,000 people die from motor car accidents. That is equivalent to one 727 airliner with 150 passengers aboard crashing without survivors every 18 days. About 10,000 people are severely injured in vehicle accidents each year. In aviation terms, this compares with a 747 airliner with 350 passengers falling from the sky every 13 days. The 13,000 killed or badly injured in car smashes represent one 747 aircraft crashing every 10 days.

I presume that this article makes such an analogy to point out that if an airliner crashed we would be outraged. There would be inquiries and a horrified response from the community. But there is nothing like that kind of response to the 3,000 who die or the 10,000 who are left severely injured as a result of car accidents. To this point we have not had a serious national commitment to recognising the extent of road accident trauma and death. We do not even have a national injury register. Indeed, that is the first part of the program.

This program has enjoyed the support of the Federal Government, particularly Prime Minister Bob Hawke. As I have said, a national road trauma authority is to be established. Also, there is a proposal to establish a national register to collect injury data. We need to treat this matter more seriously. We need to put these facts on the public record so that people can recognise the horrific costs that these figures represent, the pain and suffering of those people who have to deal with a death in the family and particularly the pain and suffering of those who are left with members of their family severely injured.

As we know, one of the regular recurring injuries suffered by the victims of car accidents is paraplegia or, worse, quadriplegia. There are not only very significant consequences for that individual and his or her family but also massive costs to the nation. The figures in this report indicate that road accidents are estimated to cost the nation more than $1.3 billion annually. It is quite clear that we are not outraged to the extent that those figures and costs deserve. We are not passionate enough about this situation.

I particularly congratulate Sir Dennis Paterson on his efforts to get the authority established. It has taken many years of cajoling and promoting to finally do so. We will now have a body that will be able to help us recognise the cost, the damage and the pain and suffering that result from motor car accidents. The authority has the bipartisan support of both State and Federal governments. As the authority establishes its work I hope that we see a change. Its principle functions will be to assess the causes of road trauma in Australia, in particular to identify areas of research that could assist in reducing the impact of road trauma; to advise governments on cost effective national policies that could assist in reducing road trauma levels; to take into account current industry practice and the need for international harmonisation of vehicle standards; to promote community awareness; and to identify the costs. Not only Sir Denis Paterson but also the governments, which have given the establishment of this authority bipartisan support, ought to be congratulated on getting this up and running.

I now turn to another item in the same report. The National Injury Surveillance Unit has been established under the national better health program. The Unit was recently officially opened by Hazel Hawke in Adelaide, where it will be based and administered by the Australian Institute of Health. This is another area that we have failed to recognise in terms of statistics, numbers and costs. I quote from the report:

In Australia, injury is the single largest cause of death of people aged 1-45. More years of potential life are lost through injury than heart disease and cancer combined, up to the age of 65. Yet injury is a health issue which has attracted comparatively little research funding, even though investment in this area can achieve excellent results in prevention.

The unit has two main tasks: to develop injury control as part of public health policy; and to provide technical support for injury surveillance and prevention activities at the State, Territory and local level.

My colleague in this place Senator Cook has often drawn attention to the appalling statistics and cost of accident and injury in the workplace. I have just cited figures for road accident and injury. Yet somehow we still do not give those figures the same seriousness nor do we place the same significance on them as we do the figures for other causes that seem to be associated with more hype or more excitement. If an aeroplane crashes, we are very perturbed; if three times as many people-indeed, one in every 18 days, if I remember the figures-are injured in car accidents or at work, we do not give that situation anything like the same attention or recognition.

There is no routine national collection of data on the incidence and cause of injuries that occur at home, at school or during leisure activities. Again, this unit will be looking at that type of data collection. Recently, the report by Dr Egger on sports injuries in this country was released. I heard Senator Patterson in this place earlier talking about waiting lists and the appalling insufficiencies of Medicare.

Dr Egger said that the reason that many people are waiting for hip replacements in our orthopaedic units around this country is not the insufficiency of the medical services or even the hospitals but because they are asked to wait for the urgent treatment required by sports injuries. That ought to give us pause, particularly as many of those sports injuries can be prevented.

It is terribly important that we begin to recognise and to focus on injury, particularly as it is so preventable, particularly too because we have not actually put real understanding on the dollar costs not only in terms of pain and suffering but also in terms of health costs. Again, I remind Senator Patterson in terms of the stress on waiting lists.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are picking on me tonight.

—I certainly am not. Mr President would know that I do not do that in this place. But Senator Patterson was claiming evidence about waiting lists to support a case against Medicare. I simply wanted to put that on record and to remind Senator Patterson what Dr Egger had to say. Until we actually have full information we cannot have an informed debate about health costs, about waiting lists or about the pain and suffering that go with accident and injury in this country. I commend my colleagues in the medical profession and in the national better health program for getting these two very important units up and running.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to speak in this adjournment debate on a couple of issues which I think are of crucial importance. I am glad that at this stage we have at least four of the Government senators in the chamber. I was rather disappointed that Senator Collins left the chamber earlier but no doubt Senator Robert Ray will take note of my comments.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing I wish to raise relates to the motion moved by Senator Brownhill earlier this evening. I was rather dismayed with the patronisation of Senator McMullan when he summed up. I invite Senator McMullan--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you coined that word?
—What was that?
—Have you coined that word?
—I cannot hear or understand that.
—Order! Ignore the interjections.
—I was rather dismayed by the patronisation because I came in here in good faith. I invite Senator McMullan to come into the chamber now and to listen to what I have to say.
—Did you give him notice?

—Senator Ray should listen. I was putting forward propositions that were put by a bipartisan task force-Senator Ray loved the bipartisan approach to the Gulf; he spoke about it and he applauded it. The propositions were put together by the Hon. Ernie Bridge, Minister for Agriculture in Western Australia, from a bipartisan group. Senator McMullan chose to patronise me and I am disgusted by it.
—`Patronisation'.

—Just sit down and be quiet for a minute. I am absolutely disgusted by it. It was done genuinely. It was done by a bipartisan group and it was a genuine attempt to address the problems in this country today. Although I did not go through all of the recommendations, I tabled the document. I would suggest that the Government should look very carefully at that document because it contains a lot of common sense. Senator McMullan had the cheek to stand up here-is Senator Ray listening-and to say that it did not reflect Opposition policy.
—Who did?

—Senator McMullan. How weak! Not only did he patronise me but he insulted the Minister for Agriculture in Western Australia who just happens to be in the Australian Labor Party there. I was not concerned with that; I was concerned with addressing the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Here they are in this place chatting away. It is absolutely unbelievable. The absolute bottom line was when Senator McMullan got to my comments in terms of the rail authorities paying fuel excise which was used to build roads. Can you not listen to this? I think it is very important. Senator McMullan had the tenacity to accuse me of putting forward propositions which were outside Opposition policy. That is absolute nonsense, total nonsense. There was not one thing that I said tonight in terms of that submission that is outside Opposition policy. Senator Collins is joking away in a jovial way and ought to go to his own seat so that he can interject and get involved in this debate. Why does he not?

TALK.START.PARA: —We are trying to ignore you.
—Order! Senator Collins did not interject and I ask Senator Crane to address the chair.

—Mr President, I apologise for not addressing my remarks through the chair. I am inviting Senator Collins to take a little interest in this debate. Some propositions were put earlier in a genuine approach to address some of the key problems which are involved here and Government members are not even interested in them. How weak can Senator McMullan get to come in here and try to patronise me and to suggest that it is not Opposition policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The other issue I want to address is the issue of the question that I asked in this place today with regard to the Heinz situation. That is a dispute that did not have to happen. It has cost $10m. It will send people broke because of stupidity. Why does Senator Ray not listen or does he endorse sending people broke? I suggest by his behaviour here now that he probably does. On that subject Senator Cook stated:
. . . this is a matter in the jurisdiction of Victoria, not in the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth.

I invite Senator Cook to come into this chamber this very minute. Senator Cook committed the cardinal sin of not knowing anything about a dispute that is not a State jurisdiction matter but a Federal jurisdiction matter. The letter I have here spells out the situation very clearly. I hope Senator Ray is listening. It states:

The award which covers food preservers at our Dandenong site is the food preservers interim award 1986. This is a Federal award to which H G Heinz Co. Australia and the Food Preservers Union of Australia are respondents.
I quote further:
A notification of an alleged industrial dispute was made to the Industrial Relations Commission of Australia.

That is the Federal jurisdiction. Senator Cook did not have a clue what he was talking about.
