TALK.START.PARA: —I must apologise to the Senate; I am going to be serious for a few moments. I acknowledge the promise from Senator Crane that he will come back another night, repeatedly as I do night after night, and as Senator Kemp does night after night; it will provide a bit of light relief.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure most of Australia now knows that today Westpac had a new found spirit of cooperation with the bank inquiry, and Mr Fowler, the Managing Director, appeared before the bank inquiry. All of a sudden injunctions are lifted, quite obviously in an attempt to put the best face possible on what was a public relations disaster.

We now find ourselves with access to these extremely important documents to which we have been alluding obliquely and directly for some weeks. I would like to respond to the public statement that was made by Mr Fowler today because he mentioned myself and John McLennan on quite a number of occasions in quite a long statement. Of course, that went to the nation tonight. Some of the points he made most definitely warrant at least an initial brief response, and later of course a more comprehensive one.

One of the things Mr Fowler has not acknowledged and it has not been generally acknowledged in this discussion for the last few weeks is a simple principle in law which was drawn to my attention some time ago, known as misprision of felony. Lawyers have a curious way of describing simple concepts with most unusual phraseology-misprision of felony. I would like to explain to honourable senators what this is. It means any person who becomes aware of the commission of a felony is duty bound at law to make full disclosure to the crown to facilitate the laying of charges. Any person who fails to do so commits the offence known as misprision of felony. In other words, it is an obligation on every individual to report to the authorities a knowledge of a felony.

The Westpac letters are in the hands of so many people, including all senators-I gave them a copy-and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), and Dr Hewson was fortunate not to have them because he returned them unopened, but the curious situation is that in law we all had the obligation not to return them to Westpac, as Westpac suggested in national advertisements that there was an obligation to return the letters to them, but quite the opposite. We all had the obligation to place the matter before the authorities. That is precisely what I was attempting to do by having them incorporated in Hansard and reported in the press.

This was not acknowledged in Mr Fowler's statement today. Instead, he projected a certain image of myself and John McLennan. To use some of his phrases, he said that the campaign we have been involved in has been timed to correspond with the commencement of the inquiry. That is true. It has been timed perfectly to correspond with the commencement of the inquiry. He said that it has been conducted by certain journalists and interest groups-one of the interest groups he is referring to is the Borrowers Association which is extremely interested in what is happening. He then referred to others who are prepared to traffic in stolen documents.

He did not explain what he meant by the term `traffic in stolen documents'. On the theme of stolen documents, my attention was drawn to apparently somebody who was standing outside a borrowers meeting recently and who had a sign up which simply said, `All the banks want back is their stolen documents'. Somebody stood next to that person with another sign which said, `All we want back is our stolen money'. It is a question of where one is placed in this whole hideous exercise.

I was accused today by Mr Fowler of being in breach of the spirit of the ruling of the President of the Senate on the sub judice principle. The only obligation I had under that ruling of the President was not to table and not to incorporate. It placed no further obligations on me, and the President acknowledged that only a few nights ago. Mr Fowler goes on in a series of quite empty allegations about what he sees as my obligations in relation to the Westpac position. He actually accuses my colleague, Mr Gilfillan. He says:
He is not only a member of the Australian Democrats, of which Senator McLean is a member, but must have been aware of the sub judice ruling of 12 February 1991 by the President of the Senate.

The President of the Senate gave his opinion and ruling but it was not the only opinion about this set of circumstances. In fact it was an opinion which differed from some of his principal advisers. There were quite a lot of opinions about whether the principle of sub judice applied. The fact that Mr Gilfillan chose not to share the opinion of the President of the Senate is utterly irrelevant. He goes on to say:
This campaign has placed unprecedented pressure on the bank.
That is for sure. I do not feel in the slightest bit guilty about that.

He went on to say that it placed unprecedented pressure on the parliamentary inquiry-it sharpened the focus of the inquiry-and that it placed unprecedented pressure on the legal system and the judiciary in New South Wales. I would be surprised if the judiciary in New South Wales feels as if it is under unprecedented pressure by what our campaign to expose the corruption of Westpac has revealed.

He has the unmitigated gall to cite the principles of the bank in relation to bank customer confidentiality. I have tabled in this place over and over again examples of clear breaches of customer confidentiality by banks, including Westpac. He cites yet again the rather spurious argument about legal professional privilege. I have answered that on several occasions by citing the fact that legal professional privilege stopped at the point where Allen Allen and Hemsley proceeded to aid and abet. He goes on to cite the fact-and this is really the most devastating aspect of his statement-that:

Partnership Pacific Limited was a merchant bank subsidiary of Westpac. It was not wholly owned until November 1984 . . . it no longer operates and represented a very small proportion of the group's assets.
I do not think the proportion in which it was owned by Westpac matters a damn. That is an utterly irrelevant observation to make. He goes on offensively to say that:
Fewer than 100 PPL clients had their accounts managed.

It does not matter if it was one, 100 or 1,000 who were destroyed by this process of fraud and corrupt practices. The fact is that the letters admit. The number of cases that it applies to is to be established by the bank inquiry or by a royal commission. He goes on to say that:
When Westpac became aware of these matters, as disclosed by the confidential letters, they were addressed in a timely and appropriate manner.

The appropriate manner was to cover them up, to enter into agreements with clients which required them in fact to concede their entitlement to litigation and even to enter into non-disclosure clauses. These were the appropriate arrangements, so-called, that were recommended by their legal advisers. The absolute absurdity comes in the final statements made by Mr Fowler when he said:
However your committee and the public should know that in relation to Westpac's approximately 850 loans offshore-
I do not know how that ties in with the 100 clients, the 50,000 documents referred to in the letters and the $8.6 billion of trading in one six-months-

at October 1985, there have been no bankruptcy notices issued, only 10 matters where action has been taken in respect of security and only three of which have resulted in the sale of security properties.

Of course there have been only that many, for the simple reason that these poor people were enticed into a situation where they actually accepted concessions in exchange for legal releases and non-disclosure processes. That was precisely the strategy recommended by Allen Allen and Hemsley; it was precisely the strategy adopted by Westpac; and it is exactly the reason the figures are, as Mr Fowler says, speaking for themselves. My legal advice, which I will not table because it is referred to within this reference as preliminary legal advice to me, although I will certainly put it before the inquiry on Friday next week, is that my legal advisers have addressed the question of whether, on the material before us-that is, the two letters tabled and incorporated today-there is a prima facie case of criminal activity. The advice goes on to say:

The material before us is sufficient to make out a prima facie case of obtaining financial advantage by deception, as contained in section 82 of the Crimes Act 1958, Victoria, as amended, which has been duplicated in the Crimes Act of New South Wales, 1900, as amended.

The advice may also raise a prima facie case concerning related offences dealing with false accounting, et cetera. The money earned from point taking and deal switching was used for the financial benefit, financial gain and financial advantage of PPL and, ultimately, Westpac Corporation.

The advice goes on to say that the most serious question is that advice given by Allen Allen and Hemsley renders the advisers liable; in other words, the lawyers themselves are liable. The advice states:

In our view, there is a strong prima facie case that the author of the Allen Allen and Hemsley letter has committed a transgression of the criminal law relating to aiding and abetting a criminal offence and/or of being an accessory after the fact to the criminal offence and perhaps being guilty of a conspiracy related to these activities.

In our view, therefore, there is a prima facie case of evidence that the solicitor concerned aided and abetted and was an accessory after the fact to the Commission of obtaining a financial advantage by deception. Indeed, it is arguable that there is a prima facie case that the solicitor and all the chief executives of Westpac Banking Corporation who were privy to the solicitor's advice were guilty of the conspiracy to do so.

There is, on the evidence available to us, a prima facie case to make out that such offences have been committed. The matter requires a full and complete investigation and could, in our view, only be properly accomplished by a full judicial inquiry such as a royal commission.

Criminal conspiracy is a crime under statutory legislation and is also a crime at common law. It basically may be defined as an agreement explicit or implicit of two or more persons to do an unlawful act or to do a lawful act by unlawful means. A conspirator may not necessarily have to do the act himself provided he agrees or consents to them being done and with full knowledge of them doing done. A conspirator may join a conspiracy after its commencement and thus be guilty of conspiracy.
With respect to aiding and abetting an offence, Lord Goddard CJ in Carter v Mace said:

If a person shuts his eyes to the obvious and refrains from making any inquiry where a reasonably sensible man would have made an inquiry, I think the court can find that he was aiding and abetting, certainly if he shuts his eyes to the obvious. We advise that this opinion has been confirmed by a senior consultant to this firm and also by a senior barrister at the Victorian Bar who specialises in prosecutions of white collar crime.

In closing, I am simply saying that the legal advice I have is that on the basis of the letters which I have now exposed publicly there is a clear prima facie case that criminal offences are being committed by Westpac, PPL and Allen Allen and Hemsley. I will naturally be placing the matter before the banking inquiry in the hope that that will lead to a royal commission and eventually that justice will be done on behalf of the many Australians who came forward in good faith to find themselves devastated by corrupt bankers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak on a matter that is rather curious, to say the least, but I think it is a matter that should be cleared up and on the record. I am referring to an article that appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser of 26 February 1991 on page 27, as part of the column called `What's your problem?' This is a regular column in the Advertiser most days. It is a column that handles such devastating issues as `Where do you get a Norfolk Island pine?', `What legislation covers LPG?' and so on. It is obviously a service column that is well read in the Advertiser, and most daily newspapers have similar columns. On 26 February part of it was headed `New World Order: What is it?' Mr or Ms A.A. of South Plympton had written in and asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Are you able to explain (and print) the One World Order which President Bush and Mr Hawke appear to be ushering in lately?

This is the astonishing answer to that question. Obviously the person who wrote in was referring to the phrase which was mentioned many times in our debate on Tuesday in regard to the statement on the ending of the Gulf war. I quote the Prime Minister's statement, in part:

I want to turn lastly to the new world order. The phrase has been much discussed in recent months. Most of what has been said has missed the fundamental point that the end of the Cold War has ushered in a new world order whether we like it or not.

Because that phrase has been around, as the Prime Minister's statement said, for some weeks, this person wrote to the Advertiser. Whether this letter was written to the newspaper as a matter of genuine information or was a set-up job I do not know, but this is the astonishing answer that the Adelaide Advertiser provided to that question:

The New World Order was the brainchild of Dr Adam Weishaupt, a German Jew who, in 1776, founded the Order of the Illuminati (a secret society). The concept was of a world government with a single economy. Dr Weishaupt also was involved in the French Revolution. From Illuminism came the Protocols of the Learned Elders of Zion. Although banned and discredited in many countries, these protocols are identical with the aims of communism for the Western world. These originated from the Bolsheviks who brought about the 1917 revolution, of which the leaders mainly were Ashkenazi Jews. These aims were recorded in the United States Congress in the 1960s-presented by Dr D. Dodd, a former member of the Communist Party of America. Both the Aims and the Protocols were directed towards a New World Order. Dr C. Quigley, prestigious American historian, wrote in his book Tragedy and Hope that the people working towards a New World Order were highly cultured, well educated and had the best interests of the human race at heart. He studied their network of operations for 20 years from the early 1960s and documented links between big international finance and the formation of the NWO. Prominent international bankers, wealthy industrialists and politicians are involved in the implementation of this New World Order. President Bush frequently refers to it as do other prominent politicians, including Mr Hawke and President Gorbachev. According to Time Magazine, of January 23, 1989, the formation of a United States of Europe is planned for 1992, and this is a move towards a New World Order. The aims are a one-world super government and a one-world economy.

That completes the answer that the newspaper gave to that simple question and, as can be imagined, it created some astonishment in the Adelaide community. I did not read it, I must confess-I am not a great reader of `What's Your Problem?'-but although the answer may sound so ridiculous as to create levity, for the Jewish community of Adelaide it was an outrage. They wrote to the Prime Minister of Australia and sent a copy of the letter to me because I happened to be in recent contact on other matters with the President of the South Australian branch of the Jewish Community Council, Mr Jack Hines. Part of the letter that he wrote to the Prime Minister read:

Obviously the Jewish community here is incensed and I would imagine that you would be rather concerned to have your name attached to this type of reply. I am in the process of arranging an appointment to meet with the Editor of the Adelaide Advertiser to discuss this letter, and others.

I want to give some information further to this astonishing answer in regard to the background of this extraordinary description of the Protocols of the Learned Elders of Zion. I have been provided with information in an extract from the Encyclopaedia Judaica. This has a section explaining the background to this extraordinary fraud, and I will read it to the Senate to put it on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can incorporate it.
—I know I can incorporate it, but I think I would like to read it into the record of the Senate instead.
—It will still be on the public record.
—I choose to read it:

SPEECH.PARA: Elders of Zion, Protocols of the Learned, anti-Semitic forgery aimed at showing the existence of international Jewish aspirations bent on world power. The specter of a worldwide Jewish conspiracy aiming at reducing the gentiles to slavery or exterminating them loomed up in the Christian imagination during the Middle Ages, growing out of legends about well-poisoning and plague-spreading. Some such stories claimed that a secret rabbinical conference had been held to work out a detailed plan for ritual genocide of the Christians. From the time of the Renaissance, at first in Spain, these legends turned on a political plot rather than a religious one: similar notions circulated in France and Germany, after Napoleon's convocation of the Great Sanhedrin . . . in 1807. They did not gain widespread popular credence, nor at first did the versions launched during the second half of the century by French Catholic authors . . . who associated Freemasons and Jews in an anti-Christian plot. In its latest version, the legend of the ``Elders of Zion'' was concocted in Paris in the last decade of the 19th century by an unknown author working for the Russian secret police (Okhrana); in all probability, it was intended to influence the policy of Czar Nicholas II towards the interests of the secret police. For his purposes, the anonymous forger adapted an old French policital pamphlet by Maurice Joly attributing ambitions of world domination to Napoleon III . . . which does not contain the slightest allusion to Jews or to Judaism. This ``dialogue'' was transformed into the ``protocols'' of an alleged conference of the leaders of world Jewry, who stated in summing up that, under the cloak of modern democracy, they already controlled the policies of numerous European states and were therefore very close to their objective. However the calculations of the Russian police misfired on that occasion: Nicholas II, impressionable and anti-Semitic though he was, detected the fraud, writing ``One does not defend a worthy cause by vile means'' in the margin of the manuscript submitted to him. The first Russian public edition of the Protocols, which appeared in 1905, did not attract much attention and was taken seriously in a few mystic and sectarian circles only.

The worldwide success of the Protocols dates from 1919 to 1921: after the widespread slaughter in World War I, the Russian Revolution in 1917, and the risings in Germany, many people felt compelled to discover a ``hidden cause'' for such tragic and momentus events. The text was widely circulated during the Russian civil war by propagandists seeking to incite the masses against the ``Jewish Revolution'' and undoubtedly contributed to the extensive pogroms perpetrated in southern Russia between 1918 and 1920. After the defeat of the White armies, Russian emigres publicized the Protocols in the West. Translations followed, but most reputable European news- papers, such as The Times of London, questioned their authenticity. In 1921 the English journalist Philip Graves pointed out the close similarity between the text of the Protocols and Joly's pamphlet; from then on, balanced and responsible circles refused to take them seriously. This was no bar to an enormous circulation of the text, which was translated into all the main world languages. In the United States it was even sponsored (until 1927) by the influential and popular Henry Ford I.

However, well before the Nazi rise to power, the Protocols found the largest number of adherents in Germany. The theory of the occult power of the Jews, sworn enemies of German-Christian culture, perfectly suited those reactionary propagandists who attributed Germany's defeat to ``a stab in the back.'' Right from the start the Nazi Party propagated this theme. The Weltdienst organization of Erfurt was specially formed to diffuse it and to strengthen ties with anti-Semites in other countries. In Berne in 1934 the Jewish community of Switzerland brought the distributors of the Protocols to trial, establishing in court that the work was a forgery, but this did nothing to diminish the zeal of its propagators. During World War II, the Protocols of the Learned Elders of Zion became an implicit justification for the genocide of the Jews; and Nazi propaganda relied on them until the last days of the Third Reich. Although since 1945 no more than bibliographical curiosity in the majority of civilised countries, the Protocols have been reissued in numerous Arab states and President Nasser of Egypt publicly vouched for their authenticity. A Spanish edition, published in 1963, was probably an attempt to prevent the revision of the Catholic Church's traditional attitude towards the Jews at the Ecumenical Council Vatican II.
That was a very long quote. I appreciate the patience of the Senate in allowing me to read it in full. I wanted to put it on the record.

In conclusion, I draw attention to the fact that I hope that the Adelaide Advertiser has the courtesy to apologise and retract the disgraceful answer that it gave in a column that, I would have thought, was not really there to deal with the propagation of anti-Semitic views. I certainly understand why the Jewish community of South Australia is so outraged that the only morning daily newspaper in South Australia, which has a very wide circulation, would allow itself, even unwittingly, to publish such tripe, which even the most junior journalist reading any of the material would realise was obviously fraudulent and should not have been published.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to share with the Senate a couple of thoughts about what is happening to our environment, what is happening to our country, and a little bit about recycling. On 25 February, last Monday week, the Litter Research Association in Sydney, in conjunction with some Sydney companies, took a group of us for a look around what is happening as far as recycling in Sydney is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Recycling is the fastest growing waste management technique employed by governments worldwide. For any waste management strategy to be successful, though, it must have the support of the public and industry, as well as State, local and Federal governments. That is why I am talking about it here in the Senate tonight.

`Why recycle?', it is asked. The answer is that it reduces solid waste, conserves natural resources, reduces pollution and litter, conserves energy, generates jobs, and encourages and educates the community to protect the environment. I believe that recycling policies will be a part of everyone's future. This will demand lifestyle changes-some as simple as learning to separate the recyclables from the rest of our discards. The question is not if, but how and when. Because recycling on a large scale is new, it offers us an opportunity to plan it properly and get it right the first time around.

In the United States and Canada, a landfill and incineration capacity gap is developing rapidly. Both Canada and the United States have adopted national polices to divert at least 50 per cent of garbage going to the tips by the year 2000. Over the past 40 years the mix of materials in municipal solid waste has changed in the United States. Most of the materials have increased in tonnages discarded over the years, with paper and paperboard, aluminium and plastics having especially notable increases. Other materials such as glass, ferrous metals, rubber and food wastes have shown very little growth or even declines. Glass and the ferrous metals, for instance, have often been replaced by other materials, notably plastics and aluminium.

The quantity of solid waste generated is growing in terms of tonnage and volume. Public awareness has increased. There is more recognition that all solid waste is of concern, not just specific components. There is much more emphasis on alternatives to landfills today than in the past. Specifically, the public attention is focused on recycling, reduction, degradability and packaging, especially for plastics.

Australia leads the world in the recycling of aluminium cans. Over 50 per cent of aluminium cans have been returned for recycling every year since 1981, which I think is a statistic that a lot of us might not have known about. There are over 1,100 buy-back centres throughout Australia. In 1988, over $24m was paid by industry to can collectors.

Polyethylene teraphthalate (PET) bottles are lightweight plastic drink bottles. The latest technology allows for the effective reprocessing of used PET bottles. About 50 per cent of soft drink consumed in Australia is packaged in those PET bottles. PET is recycled as a polyester resin to be used in the manufacture of items such as fibreglass boats, surfboards and artificial marble vanities. Many household food and beverage products are packaged in glass bottles and jars and these, importantly, are 100 per cent recyclable. Thirty-five per cent of new bottles are made from old ones, which I think is quite an interesting statistic as well. Currently there is a 25 per cent recovery of glass for recycling, and the chopped up glass is selling at about $90 per tonne.

As far as paper is concerned, there are currently extreme difficulties with the paper industry, which has dropped the price by more than half. I know that that has caused problems for the people who collect paper, especially in country areas. They want to do the right thing but they are not getting a good enough market for paper in the major cities. Perhaps Australia should be looking at decentralising some of the areas that take in waste paper. The price is dictated by the world market price for waste paper. There is a worldwide glut of waste paper at present and obviously that is why the price has dropped.

As far as New South Wales is concerned, many councils are updating their recycling programs. Some have more than doubled their participation rate, with some introducing cash rewards for residents and some having contractor runs on a weekly basis. All of them are getting a very positive response. In the Local Government Association 42 councils have formed their own recycling cooperatives because they were receiving a raw deal from companies which buy their waste paper. Recycling companies are dropping their prices, forcing the councils to use their own funds. Recycling companies are cashing in on the increased environmental awareness of the community-which is great. Councils say that any profits should be ploughed back into local schemes or used to educate the public on the benefits of recycling.

When I was in America representing this Parliament at the United Nations I had the opportunity to visit people in New York and look at the economic problems of recycling, the need for more collectors, and getting a market for the recycled product, which is one of the big problems there. Obviously they have to educate people to use more recycled products. There is a lead time to get people used to using recycled products. In New York, for example, there is 27,000 tonnes of garbage per day and 13,000 tonnes of that per day is now being handled in pits as well as being landfilled. Of that, 10,000 tonnes is being picked up by private collectors to recycle. Of course, they are running out of landfill areas, which is one of the reasons why they are looking much more closely at recycling.

The State and Federal governments will give incineration facilities only if people recycle, which I think is well worth a thought. On the bigger scale, in America 160 million tonnes of garbage per year has to be disposed of. As I said, they are running out of landfill so they are moving more into the recycling mode. There are three different ways of recycling material: the drop-off method, which recovers up to 10 per cent of available recyclables; the buy-back method, which recovers up to 20 per cent; and the comprehensive kerbside method, which picks up 70 per cent to 90 per cent-that is in the PET recycling areas.

In the comprehensive kerbside method of recycling they collect aluminium, glass, PET, steel and newspapers. They use large 20-gallon storage bins for each house, which can be supplied as an incentive by the council. They use 30-cubic yard collection trucks for their recycling and they pick up the recyclables every week on the same day as the garbage pick-up, which is very important for people to get used to doing it all the time. They sort recyclables at a central facility and they keep participants aware and enthusiastic through education and promotion.

I think we have to look at this in Australia. I commend the people in Sydney who are doing the recycling. On World Environment Day-which is 5 June 1991-the Keep Australia Beautiful Council will present its Vision for Australia award. Last year's winner was Comalco Aluminium, and it is doing a wonderful job in this area. I commend those people for the work they are doing and I thank the Senate for allowing me to speak for some seven minutes in the adjournment debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to refer to one of the consequences of the war in the Gulf, that is, the human cost not of the 100,000 or more people who have died in this tragic war but of the victims who are, sadly, refugees or injured people, or those who have suffered because members of their families have died in this war. I think it is the international responsibility of all countries, particularly those which were involved in the war, to help with the repatriation and the clean-up operations environmentally. They have a particular responsibility from a humane point of view to help people in all the countries that were affected by the war.

SPEECH.PARA: The International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War Inc (IPPNW) is an international body which was the recipient in 1985 of the Nobel Peace Prize. On 13 February, three Jordanian members of the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War group began a rather dangerous journey from Jordan into Baghdad. The members of the group learned through eye witness accounts that there is a desperate need for nurses, anaesthesia and basic medical supplies to treat wounded Iraqi civilians. Of course, this has all been expanded now that the war has finished. But this report was gathered by these three brave Jordanian doctors who went into Iraq while the bombing raids were still raging.

Reports of amputations being performed by sawing off limbs without anaesthesia have come to us from the three physicians who have just returned from Baghdad, according to William Monning of the IPPNW's executive. They told of harrowing scenes in Iraqi hospitals with people screaming constantly because there was a lack of anaesthetics for operations that were being performed. The group also reports the destruction of at least five churches, 25 mosques and four hospitals in the Baghdad area. These people took their lives into their own hands to go in and make this report which has come out through that committee.

On 27 February-which was very recently-the IPPNW produced a report on refugees and displaced persons who will be the ongoing victims and the ongoing tragedy from this war. The report states that as the Gulf war ends, there are, in addition to the direct victims of the bombing and fighting, thousands of civilian victims in the Middle East, especially those in Iraq and Kuwait, and they are often unrecognised victims.

Civilians in Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Israel and other parts of the region may suffer and die as well. They die not only from direct hits or flying debris but also from epidemics of respiratory infections, diarrhoea and malnutrition. People who are displaced from their homes are forced to flee their countries and they will fare the worst. They will experience death rates so high that they may exceed those of the combat soldiers.

This report from IPPNW looks at the impact of the war on the region's public health systems which were not all that fantastic to begin with in the pre-war situation. IPPNW estimates conservatively that over the next six months, in addition to many refugees who may be able to escape to neighbouring countries, approximately 5 per cent of the Kuwaiti and Iraqi population-close to one million people-will be displaced from both of those countries. It is also known from past experience that these internal refugees will die at rates far greater than those who have not been forced to flee-at a rate of one to two deaths per 10,000 people per day. This translates into an extra 15,000 to 33,000 people dying in six months, mostly children under five years old.

With attention, international aid and implementation of a coordinated plan, almost every one of these deaths could be prevented. This, I think, is the very important message that we, as one of the countries involved in the war, really have to take very seriously. Death and sickness rates will continue to rise as water mains and sewerage pipes remain destroyed and as overloaded health systems can no longer vaccinate children, let alone look after the sick and injured. This is not a new story but it reflects lessons learned from past wars and past dislocations. We have also learned how to prevent this death and disease. Thus, the challenge confronting the international medical community and public health officials is to act quickly to prevent as much unnecessary death and disease as possible.

Historically, wars create two types of newly vulnerable civilian population: refugees who, by definition, end up outside the country of their nationality, and internally displaced persons who flee their homes to seek more secure areas within their own country. Of course, as we know from the massive internal disruption that is occurring in Iraq now, unfortunately, this will be a very familiar story there as well as in Kuwait.

As many as 1.5 million people may flee Iraq and Kuwait as a result of the Gulf war. Jordan, Turkey, Syria and Iran may receive an influx sufficient to precipitate public health emergencies in those countries. Past experience has shown that refugees will suffer the highest death rates in the period immediately following displacement. Experts count these rates in deaths per 10,000 people per day. Death rates for refugees will be far higher than for residents of the recipient country. Deaths will disproportionately affect children under 14 years of age, and of course in all of the countries of the Middle East that I have mentioned there is a very high percentage of the population which is under 15 years of age.

Infectious diseases, such as measles, diarrhoea and acute respiratory tract infections in association with malnutrition, will claim most of the lives, along with epidemics of diseases such as meningitis. One report estimates that as of 4 February 1991 more than one million people have fled Baghdad since the beginning of the war.

In the past, mortality rates amongst the displaced populations within a country have been far greater than for the non-displaced. One difficulty that hinders aid to internally displaced populations is that they are protected only in a limited way by international agreements on refugees. The Geneva Convention, the only agreement that protects their rights, requires only that the warring parties provide access to the International Committee of the Red Cross. In addition, relief programs directed at displaced populations are often the target of violence themselves.

The Persian Gulf region already has a legacy of displaced persons. The eight year Iran-Iraq war first created both a major refugee problem and large internally displaced populations. Prior to the Gulf war the United States Committee for Refugees estimated that there were already 350,000 Iranian refugees in Iraq and Pakistan; 500,000 Iraqi refugees in Iran; 500,000 to one million internally displaced people in Iraq, and one million people who were displaced in Iran. So there was already a massive problem before this Gulf war appeared on the scene.

Refugees and those displaced within their own countries are desperate people who may become completely dependent on outside means of support. Many have already suffered major physical and mental trauma as a result of war, and when they do gain refuge, it is often in crowded camps with the associated loss of dignity, privacy and control over their own destinies.

There is justified concern that many refugees from the Gulf war may remain in closed refugee camps for many years. For example, in 1987 only 1.5 per cent of the world's refugees were voluntarily repatriated; 12 per cent successfully settled in the country of first asylum, and 1 per cent resettled in a third country. In addition, there are 2.27 million registered Palestinian refugees in Jordan, Syria, Lebanon, the West Bank and Gaza. They have been refugees since the creation of the state of Israel in 1948, and the plight of the Palestinians deserves special attention in this situation. The Palestinians, as far as I know, are still living under a state of war in Israel because the curfews imposed upon them by the Israeli Government have not been lifted since the direct killing in the war stopped a week or so ago, so they do need special attention.

Most countries in the area immediately affected by the Gulf war have poor health status and low per capita gross national product compared with that of industrialised countries. For example, Jordan, Turkey and Iran have moderate infant mortality rates of 54, 74 and 91 infant deaths per 1,000 live births. But pit that against west European countries where infant mortality rates are eight to 10 per 1,000 live births.

Similarly, Jordan, Syria and Turkey, which have gross national products averaging around $1,500 per capita, compared with $19,000 per capita in the USA, will have great difficulty assisting their own displaced populations and refugees without international assistance. Iraq has a high infant mortality rate of 67 deaths per 1,000 live births, and 45 per cent of its population is younger than 15 years of age, so it is really a crucial situation in Iraq in particular.

IPPNW lists two phases of help which are urgently needed. The emergency phase, the first phase, is the one month to 12 month period during which death rates are greater than one per 10,000 per day, depending on the initial health status of the refugees and the response mounted to provide care and refuge for them.

High emergency phase death rates are mainly due to communicable diseases such as measles, diarrhoeal diseases and acute respiratory infections in conjunction with under-nutrition and vitamin deficiencies. Disease transmission is enhanced by crowding and poor housing, lack of sanitation and poor water supply. Resistance to infection is reduced by malnutrition, physical trauma and psychological stress. During the emergency phase death rates rise in all age groups but the increase is expected to be most dramatic amongst the one- to 14-year-olds.

In the post-emergency phase, death rates generally fall to the same level as those in the surrounding population and illness patterns begin to resemble those of the host population. However, many refugees suffer long term effects of exile, political repression and torture, including posttraumatic stress characterised by intense fear and sleeping disorders; depressive disorders that may or may not be accompanied by violence, substance abuse and suicidal behaviour; and psychosomatic disorders and psychosexual dysfunction. These are the long term effects of what it must be like to be in a refugee situation or permanently dislocated.

The International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War group recommends four basic measures to minimise death rates and to shorten the initial post-displacement emergency phase. The four measures are the timely provision of: first, sufficient food rations containing adequate amounts of calories, protein, and essential vitamins and minerals; secondly, sufficient quantities of clean water; thirdly, appropriate interventions for the prevention and treatment of specific communicable diseases, including measles immunisation, oral rehydration for diarrhoea, and effective detection and case management of acute respiratory infections and malaria; and, fourthly, establishment from the start of a health surveillance system, especially surveillance of mortality, nutritional status and important epidemic diseases such as measles and cholera.

The next question that IPPNW asks is: whose responsibility is this situation? In any refugee crisis, the recipient country has ultimate responsibility for the care of refugees. However, the international community must provide resources and technical assistance to the countries that border Iraq and Kuwait who will otherwise have to shoulder the burden alone when facing a sudden influx of people. Yet promises of aid for refugees are not enough. Jordan has yet to receive adequate reimbursement from the international community for the $55m it has spent for refugee assistance following the August invasion of Kuwait by Iraq.

IPPNW suggests the following steps for the prompt implementation of refugee programs: first, strengthen the capacity of recipient countries-that is, Jordan, Turkey, Syria and Iran-to provide technical assistance; secondly, fully involve the displaced communities in relief health programs; thirdly, ensure that the donor governments provide relief supplies that reflect the real needs of the refugees; and fourthly, where possible, provide alternatives to closed refugee camps to prevent the crowding and poor sanitation associated with closed settings.

In the past, donated resources for refugee populations have varied in quantity according to the strategic importance of the host country to major donors, the level of media coverage, and the ease of access to the affected region. In the present crisis, the response through January was encouraging, with an estimated $61m out of a required $175m for 400,000 refugees for three months already donated or pledged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I have sat here very patiently. I know that Senator Vallentine has great concern about this area but she is reading from copious notes. We have had this issue out before. It is coming from the heart, so she should be able to say it without referring to her notes. I ask that she give her speech without referring to notes because it might be a little briefer. It is very late. She is in breach of the Standing Orders. I ask you to direct her not to use copious notes.
—Senator Vallentine can use copious notes but she cannot read her speech. I remind her of that.
—I was about to conclude, as a matter of fact. The $61m which has been donated so far represents about one-tenth of what the allied forces had spent through the month of January to prosecute the war.

SPEECH.PARA: From Australia's point of view, only last week we voted through a special appropriations Bill allocating an extra $55,500,000 to cover Australia's effort in the war. My plea to the Australian Government and the Australian people to lobby the Australian Government to this extent is that for every dollar that was put towards the Defence budget to pay for the Royal Australian Navy's efforts in the Gulf, that is, the ships which went to the Gulf to support the cash box coalition, the Australian Government has an equal responsibility to provide a dollar to aid the victims of the war in terms of either supporting the refugee programs or environmental clean-up. We have a far greater international responsibility to assist with the clean-up operations than many other countries because we were involved in the destructive process. For every dollar that we spent on the war effort we should be spending an equal amount on the reconstruction and clean-up efforts. That is my plea to the Australian Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 10 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister's department or any agency for which the Minister is responsible entered into any contracts with Gary Morgan's company, Roy Morgan Research Centre, since 1975; if so, for each contract since 1975:
(a) was there a specific contract; if so, what were the specifications of the contract and was it altered after it was entered into; if not, why not;
(b) what was the fee;
(c) was the contract put out to tender, if so, why was Roy Morgan Research Centre chosen; if not, why not, and why was the Centre chosen;
(d) was the Centre specifically asked by the Minister's department or agency to supply a copy of the questionnaire;
(e) did the Centre supply a copy of the full questionnaire used to conduct the survey; if so, please provide a copy of the full questionnaire;
(f) if a part only of the questionnaire was supplied, was the Minister's department or agency aware of the exact nature of the full questionnaire;

(g) if a part of the questionnaire was supplied, was the Minister's department or agency aware of the exact nature of the full questionnaire; if not, why not, and what safeguards were taken to ensure there was no conflict of interest or subject bias;
(h) please provide a copy of the Centre's report;

(i) if, for whatever reason, the Minister's department or agency will not provide a copy of the report, please provide an outline of its contents and an explanation as to why the Minister's department or agency refuses to provide a copy;

(j) was the Centre specifically asked by the Minister's department or agency to provide a computer printout of the survey; if so, did the Centre provide an interpretation of the survey results; if not, what special skills and qualifications does the Minister's department or agency have in the interpretation of attitudinal survey data and please provide an outline of how the survey data was interpreted;
(k) how were the survey results used by the Ministers department or agency; and
(l) did the proposal to commission the survey emanate from within the Ministers department or agency or from within the Minister's office or another department or agency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce has entered into three (3) contracts with the Roy Morgan Research Centre since 1975. None of the agencies for which the Minister is responsible have entered into any contracts with the Centre.

(a) (i) In 1989, the Centre was engaged to design and conduct a telephone survey of 350 people in Sydney and 350 people in Melbourne to determine the public knowledge of, and attitudes to, the Multifunction Polis program. No alterations were made to the original contract because it was considered satisfactory.

(ii) In 1990, the Centre was engaged to arrange and conduct discussions with a range of young people so as to evaluate the public knowledge and perception of the Multifunction Polis program. No alterations were made to the original contract because it was considered satisfactory.

(iii) In 1990 the Centre was engaged to design and conduct a telephone survey of 350 people in Sydney, Perth, Adelaide, Melbourne and Brisbane so as to evaluate if there had been a change in the public knowledge of, and attitudes to, the Multifunction Polis program. No alterations were made to the original contract because it was considered satisfactory.

(c) (i) This contract did not go out to tender as Departmental instructions only require the use of the tendering process when the anticipated cost exceeds $30,000. The Centre was selected on the recommendation of the MFP Communications Working Party.

(ii) This contract did not go out to tender as Departmental instructions only require the use of the tendering process when the anticipated cost exceeds $30,000. The Centre was selected on the basis that it already had the expertise to undertake surveys concerning the MFP.
(iii) As for (c) (ii).
(d) The Roy Morgan Research Centre was asked by the Department to supply a copy of the questionnaire for the three surveys that were undertaken on MFP.
(e) The Roy Morgan Research Centre did provide the Department with copies of the questionnaire for the three surveys. (attached).
(f) n/a.
(g) No. There were no questions asked by the Roy Morgan Research Centre that were not included in the copies of the questionnaires that were supplied to the Department.
(h) Copies of the Reports are attached.
(i) n/a.

(j) The Roy Morgan Research Centre did provide a computer printout of the results for the three surveys. The Centre was asked to undertake an analysis of the survey conducted on youth groups (ii) and provide the Department with an interpretation of the results. No interpretation of results was carried out by the Centre for the two telephone surveys (i) and (iii). The analysis of those results was carried out within the Department's Marketing area, which has special skills in this area and which is familiar with the nature of the MFP project.

The two telephone surveys were interpreted on the basis of attitudes towards the MFP project by State and segregated according to whether those interviewed were considered to be Managers or representatives of the general public.

The data was then analysed according to these broad groupings on the basis of their attitudes towards the MFP, for example whether they had heard of the MFP, and whether they thought it was a good idea etc. The data outlined in the surveys undertaken in 1989 and 1990 was then compared to see if a shift in attitudes towards the MFP had taken place, and what factors had influenced this change in attitudes.
(k) The results of the surveys were used as input into the Community consultation process that is now occurring.
(l) The proposal originated from within the Department.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 6 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the `Estraderm' patch that is designed to be applied to the skin and deliver a predetermined dose of oestradiol, has the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (ADEC) reached a decision on its safety and efficacy.
(2) In what way does the patch which was being considered by ADEC to determine whether it meets Australian standards differ from that used by women in the United States and other western countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Oestradiol patches have been considered by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (ADEC) on eight occasions since December 1988. Consideration of the marketing application has been protracted because of the difficulty in identifying which actual formulation/delivery system had been used in those clinical studies presented in the marketing application.

This is important because patches used in early studies or marketed elsewhere might deliver the drug in a different way to the patches intended for Australia. This variation in drug delivery could result in differing clinical effects in Australia to those observed in the majority of trials presented.

Recently, the sponsor company, Ciba-Geigy, has been able to address ADEC's concerns, and, at its last meeting on 22 February 1991, ADEC provisionally recommended that `Estraderm' patches be given general marketing approval provided all outstanding quality and product information issues are resolved.

(2) The way in which the patch proposed for marketing in Australia differs from others used in some overseas countries would be regarded by the sponsor company as commercially confidential information. I believe it would not be appropriate for me to supply this information at this time. I can assure you that the differences in patch designs were significant to the extent that concern was expressed at the clinical consequences of the variation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 15 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the drug morphine sulphate, which alleviates the pain and discomfort for cancer sufferers and which is used widely in other western countries, available for use in this country; if so, what restrictions are there on its use, if any.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The narcotic analgesic, morphine sulphate, is currently available in Australia, and has been for many years. It is available in oral forms such as tablets and in injectable forms.
Being a narcotic it is a Schedule Eight drug and, under State statutes, specific actions and limitations in relation to prescribing and dispensing apply.
(2) Morphine sulphate is available as a pharmaceutical benefit as tablets of 30mg and injections of 10mg in 1mL, 15mg in 1mL and 30mg in 1mL.
The tablet is available for severe disabling pain not responding to non-narcotic analgesics. The injections are unrestricted.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Counter Staff

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the average age of: (a) all staff; and (b) counter staff, working in the department's regional offices around Australia.
(2) What basic qualifications are regional office counter staff required to have as they begin employment with the department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1a) The average age of all staff working in the department's regional offices is 33.7 years.

(1b) The department's personnel record system does not maintain records of counter staff separately. However, based on the classification profile of counter staff, the average age of that group is estimated at 33.2 years.

(2) Regional office counter staff do not require formal educational qualifications when they enter the department. All permanent base grade staff, including potential counter officers, must have sat the Administrative Selection Test. Departmental Additional Selection Criteria (ASC) are being introduced according to the Structural Efficiency Principle Agreement between the unions and the Government. The criteria to be applied for entry to the DSS regional network include:
- interest in and motivation to work in the DSS network;
- ability to communicate effectively with people of differing cultural backgrounds;
- sound oral communication skills; and
- ability to cope with difficult situations.
The ASC are to be used in conjunction with a structured training program to ensure that staff have the skills required to serve clients directly.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans on Logistical Support Vessels

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 22 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Vietnam veterans who served on HMAS Sydney and other logistical support vessels currently receive a service pension.
(2) How many veterans who served on HMAS Sydney and other logistical support vessels receive a service pension for other service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It is not possible from records held by the Department of Veterans' Affairs to distinguish veterans who served in Vietnam on logistical support vessels from other veterans serving on Special Overseas Service between 31 July 1962 and 11 January 1973.
